LEBRET SASK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

January 29th 1940

Dear Sir,

Re- Yours 114-0-5

I beg to inform you that on receipt of your letter of November 23rd the same day, a cheque of $5.50, No 578 was issued on the name of that Company as stated by their answer Nov. 27th.

That now they dare to claim from the Department another payment cannot be understood by me else than they must be lost between their different branches.

Our payment was made to Regina, which transferred same to Winnipeg, now I do not know if that claim went further to Ottawa Branch.

I am writing to them today again to tell them that they should rather check up their account between their different branches than to go to our headquarters to bother them when it is unnecessary.

Thanking you for having called our attention upon that matter, I remain

Your obediently

M.de Bremne O.M.I
Principal.

R.A. HOEY
Superintendent of Welfare & Training
OTTAWA Ont.

March 27, 1940

Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Attention Mr. A.R. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

We have your letter in reference to the freight bill of .34¢ for shipping machines from Regina to La Bret Indian School. On looking up our records we find that our agent, who resides at Fort Qu'Appelle, was in Regina at the time these machines were to be delivered and it is usual for us when Machines are delivered we check them over for satisfaction. He took this machine in his truck and we allowed him the freight charges. I am enclosing his receipt.

If this is not satisfactory to you, send us a check for the amount of the Sewing Machine only. (e.g. $80.40)

Yours truly,

SINGER SEWING MACHINE COMPANY

J.B. Brown M.S

August 6th, 1940.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that we had often asked the Department to grant us a new Dough Mixer for the Bakery.

We would appreciate very much your cooperation in a way that that purchase that had been promised by the Indian Department be made during the time of holidays.

Thanking you by anticipation, I remain yours very truly,

"Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I.
Principal."

Mr. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Regina.

Sir,

Re- The enclosed invoices -

I beg to submit to you the invoice in triplicate for the repair of our Bread mixer, as ordered by Dr Simes because our mixer was absolutely unserviceable and that we cannot go along without that machine for a household of the size of our.

We had at different times submitted to the Department our need of a new mixer, but we found that making some repairs we could use yet our for a probably long time.

We wish that you will understand our request and kindly have the payment amounting only to $30.00 forwarded to the shop that performed that work.

I remain, dear Sir, yours

very obediently,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I

LEBRET SASK
Indian Res., School
June 9th 1941

Dear Sir,

Re- Yours June 5th 1941-

I beg to inform you that indeed we have extended our barn according to the plan I had when you visited the School.

We have extended the barn on the North by moving a former and very inconvenient cattle shed near the cow stable, opened one side, joined the walls made a litter-loft, divided the inside for growing heifers and steers, provided 2 bull-pens, and another year completely paid with our own resources built another addition for the calves by altering half of the old silo and making 2 pens on the cement floor erected on the top of that silo. All partitions are in iron buried by the foot in cement and all the underflooring is cement too. The system of ventilation is the last model and very efficient. Consequently we can assert that these improvements are permanent and an asset to the School.

The chicken-coop was built since your visit too and in the same manner, as well as the ice-house etc.

If I insist on the details of these constructions it is with the purpose of showing you that a great deal of work had been done by the School staff and gave us, with the minimum of expenses incurred by the Branch, an opportunity to extend our buildings and create work for our big Boys, who without benefiting of what some call "vocational training", got at least a beginning of the working habit, that unhappily they lose so easily when they leave so young our hands.

I remain,

Yours very obediently,

Rev. M. de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that the Reverend Father de Bretagne, Principal of the Lebret Indian Residential School, has brought to my attention on several occasions while at this office that there is a crack in the wall of the School building on the east side of the south-west corner. There is an open gap where the mortar that holds the bricks together seems to have been washed out. There is also a stone facing around the wall about 6" or 8" wide, and it is probably a foot or more down from the top of the wall. This is giving way because I can see from the ground that in places the facing is protruding about an inch out from the wall, and it will only be a matter of time until the stone facing starts to drop and may fall on someone down below.

Dr. McGill was visiting the School the same day I was there and he can probably explain it to you better than I can in a letter. However, on refreshing my memory the same thing exactly happened in connection with the St. Mary's School on the Blood Reserve, and we had to spend several hundred dollars to have the wall repaired. This was about seven years ago.

Now, the question is, are Smith Brothers and Wilson responsible or should we obtain the services of an outsider. I was talking to the above mentioned firm over the telephone during the Summer and they promised to go down and look at it to see if they were responsible. If they were they stated they would repair it and if they were not they promised to advise me what was necessary to do. However, up to the present time they have not gone down to the School. If you wish, I can again interview them but I shall take no steps until I hear from you. I think it would be a good idea to talk this over with the architect down there. No doubt you have the plans of the School and if the stone facing near the top of the wall has loosened in one place it will probably become loose all around the School.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to your file No. 114-0-5 regarding the condition of the wall on the east side of Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret.

I have contacted Smith Bros. and Wilson, Limited, General Contractors, and have today received a reply from them. They state that on November 8th they visited and examined the brick work and cracks in this building and they believe the cracks were caused by water seeping in the joints of the stone belt course, which freezes then and thaws again, thus forcing the stone and brick work to move. This, they go on to say, happens on buildings where the mortar joints in the stone or brick work become faulty and are not repaired. Their advice is to examine mortar joints every few years in a cold climate such as in Saskatchewan, and wherever any signs of depreciation are shown the holes should be patched with caulking compound or mortar to prevent water seepage.

With particular reference to this building Smith Bros. and Wilson further state that the movement of stone and brick has not yet reached a danger point as there is still a good deal of bearing left for the stone, and in their opinion there is no danger of any brick falling at the present time. They think it is too late in the year to do any permanent repair work to the brick and the matter of repairs should be postponed until Spring as it is so hard to get brick layers at present. However, the joints in the brick work and stone should be caulked with oakum and caulking compound to prevent any seepage of water behind the masonry as if this is not done further freezing and thawing of the water will shift the brick work to the extent where it will become dangerous. In their estimation the cost of this work would be about $35.00 in order to make the cracks water-proof for the Winter, and they are willing to arrange to have this work done and are awaiting instructions on the matter.

This is the information given to me and I am forwarding it on to the Branch for further action.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Reverend Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Qu'Appelle Residential School on October 20 Inspector G.J. Buek writes as follows:

"The temperature of all of the seven classrooms is much too low for pupil health and good work. The average for the four days of the inspection was between 34 and 56 degrees Fahrenheit. It felt really cold. By actual count over 75% of the 264 children had colds in one form or another, and according to the Principal had had them for several weeks. According to the Indian Act it seems that the Agent in charge has some responsibility in these matters. The same deficiencies were reported last year, but apparently nothing was done about it. Other official visitors to this school have made similar observations."

I should appreciate your advising at once why the above condition prevails.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

January 9th 1942

Dear Sir,

Re- Yours 114-0-5 Dec. 31st -

I beg to inform you that at the time of the visit of the Inspector Buck the temperature outside was not really cold and consequently did not necessitate the school buildings to be heated as much as in the winter weather. We have indeed the habit of keeping the temperature at 70° in the hall during the winter months and I never begrudged coal to the engineer.

At the time of the visit of the Inspector Buck we were enlarging the coal bin capacity and digging an outside ash-pit to keep our boiler room clean and to save the health of our firemen. And it might have been that the fire was a little neglected to give satisfaction to the School Inspector G.J. Buck who seems to have a hobby of carrying thermometer along in his visits.

Now, to say that the cold prevailing at the time of the visit of the said Inspector was due to the poor way the building was heated up is certainly an exaggeration because nearly all the children came back from their holidays with a bad cold contracted in the poor quarters occupied by their parents in the nomadic peregrinations in which they usually delight but that took place this year during an exceptionally cold month of August, similar in the West this year to what we used to have in September if not worse.

Practically all schools were quarantined this year for mumps and grippe, and ours was one of the last to be treated so by medical authorities, and had that quarantine lifted up at the same time as the others. Nothing abnormal had to be observed in that fact consequently.

The reports concerning the health of our children was to my knowledge excellent and Dr Simes is always eulogizing our success in that matter. Our children gain considerable weight, are fat and the pride of their parents who are after all the best judges in that matter.

Wishing that these explanations be satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours obediently,

R.A Hoey
Supt.of Welfare & Training
Mines & N.Resources.

March 4th 1942.

Dear Rev.F.Plourde,

We would badly need a new kitchen range for our school and I would be very thankful that you insist to the Department to secure that purchase.

We were given 2 light ranges at the time of the fire of the old school and these ranges are inadequate for their purpose, the ovens in spite of the work done on them do not get warm at least two of them, they burn an awful amount of fuel and wood is very scarce here now and we are in the necessity of using coal for which fuel these ranges are not made up, consequently the tops warp.

In spite of the economies required by the hard present times I would have to apply for one good kitchen range with one fire box only and 3 ovens, called by the General Steewares Ltd #30 Chef Junior with double deck high shelf, straight water front, equipped with Ni-resist top over firebox, at the price of $459.25, fed. tax not included.

This is our urgent need and wish you do your utmost to get authorization for its purchase.

Yours very truly,

Rev.M.de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

PS. I have already done a lot of expenses supported by the school to finish equipping that kitchen: a stainless boiler with fire box for cooking the soup, a canopy to take away fumes and heat etc., and I never asked for any reimbursement for same.

October 14th 1942

Dear Rev. F. Plourde,

I take the liberty of sending enclosed the invoices of cement, dimension lumber etc., bought for the construction of the pigery I have started to erect.

Owing to the fact that it is already late in the season and that the main part of this building is to make the cement one, I could not take any chance for waiting (long time for an answer to be authorized).

The pork meat is very high and there is no better opportunity to use the barley harvested by our farm and to follow the instructions of the Government than to raise as many pigs as we can; consequently we have to do it right away on account of the season. Sooner we could not think about it because we did not know how our crop was going to turn out.

Now I know that I should not exact that way if I want any reimbursement, but I leave the matter into your hands owing to the fact that I have bought already with our own money the lumber necessary, and for which I don't exact any reimbursement. If you don't expect the payment by the Department for this invoice, kindly send it back right away to me that I pay it as soon as possible. It is difficult to secure any material for building purposes now and the best prices are given by our Lumber yard of Fort Qu'Appelle the closest and the best supplied. You will notice that the cement for instance, with the discount is $1.10, nobody sells it here around cheaper.

Yours very truly,

Rev. M. de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal

Under date of the 14th instant I wish to inform you that I received a letter from the Reverend Father M. de Bretagne, O.M.I., Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, Lebret, advising me that they had experienced a series of misfortunes at the school with their machinery and that owing to the fact that immediate action had to be taken he did not have an opportunity to write to this office or Ottawa to obtain authority, but was forced to have repairs made at once.

I informed Father de Bretagne that all I could do in the matter was to forward the invoices to Ottawa and under the circumstances recommend that payment be made.

First of all the frigidaire at the school stopped working and it was necessary to have a man from the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company, Regina, put it back in shape. I am therefore now forwarding our Voucher No. 227 for $88.13 for this.

Next the Reverend Father had trouble with the stokers and had to order new pulleys from the Vulcan Iron Works at Winnipeg. The invoice for this has not as yet been received.

Trouble was also experienced with the switch control of the Vacuum system and when the defect was found by the head engineer of the Sanatorium at Fort San they had to wire to Montreal to secure the worn out parts from Darling Brothers Limited.

The invoices from the two last mentioned companies will be forwarded just as soon as they are received and I would ask that the one in favour of J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company be paid if possible.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

We have been receiving communications from Father M. de Bretagne, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School at Lebret, with respect to the twin boilers at the school.

The flues of these boilers need replacing as they are leaking and Father de Bretagne notes that the boilers are in a very bad condition according to a report made by the Provincial Inspector of Boilers here. He further notes that every precaution was taken even to using soft water but after eight winters it seems they are playing out.

They have already changed 5 flues at the school but it now becomes necessary to change them all and in this connection I would refer you to Departmental letter No. 114-0-6 of June 27th, 1941, when authority was given to repair some tubes at that time which were badly worn. Each boiler consists of 44 tubes 3" in diameter and 7' long and 46 tubes 3" in diameter and 6' long, making a total of 584 lineal ft. of tubing for each boiler. These boilers were made by the Vulcan Iron Works, of Winnipeg, and their make is V.I.O.L.A.

Two years ago the Vulcan Iron Works made an offer to repair the boilers for $277.65 each. At the present time a Mr. Pertle, owner of the General Repair Shop at Fort Qu'Appelle, has offered to do the work for $300.00 that is installing the new tubes, cutting the old ones as well as cutting the smoke stack.

I am giving you all this information and at the same time would point out that this work must be done during the Summer months before the cold weather again sets in next Fall.

I have just received a quotation from the Vulcan Iron Works of Winnipeg, this morning and from this you will note that they will supply the tubing for each boiler and install it at a cost of $498.00 each.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the Qu'Appelle Residential School.

School desks are very hard to obtain at the present time and the only ones we can secure are wooden desks. There are no more metal parts. I cannot understand why the first grade at the Qu'Appelle School has only 24 desks. We have not received any similar request since the school was opened. I wish you would investigate this matter further. In any case we will have to have more specific information along the following lines:

Size No. 5 for pupils 5 to 8 years of age
" No. 4 " " 8 to 10 "
" No. 3 " " 10 to 12 "

With reference to the blackboards, you do not state the width required, nor if they have moulding and chalk trough.

We have been turned down on all requests recently for typewriters. Consequently I doubt if there will be any possibility of securing these.

With reference to item 8, I find that the Qu'Appelle School followed out instructions by forwarding their requisition for books for the academic year 1943 early in January last. Regina, January 29th, 1945.

Report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School

I wish to inform you that I inspected this institution on the 17th and 18th instants. Father Piche, the Principal, happened to be here in the city on Wednesday, January 17th, and since he was leaving for Lebret at 6:00 P.M. that evening I took the opportunity of going down to the school with him.

At the time of my visit there were 172 children in residence and that is 22 over the allotment. The children were all happy and healthy and to the best of my knowledge there was only one little girl ill in one of the dormitories and she evidently had a slight touch of cold. The rest certainly looked well.

I found 75 head of cattle at the school and at the time of my visit they were milking 30 cows. Each day there are 40 gals. of milk given to the children and the balance is sold to the creamery at Melville. They were also raising 40 hogs at the school, 12 horses, and 315 chickens, and they were building an addition to the chicken coop when I was there. This was just about completed and the work had been done by the teachers and the boys. The chicken coop is two storeys high. The material was furnished by the Department.

The Principal brought to my attention the water softener plant was not in use as it was too small for the school. Further, all the classrooms required battleship linoleum for the floors, and I am herewith attaching the size of the different classrooms. Father Piche also stated some paint was required especially for the top floor, and they are asking for 50 gals. of white paint and 50 gals. of a primer coat. In addition, he pointed out that the top floor was cold as the ceiling was too close to the roof and to remedy this it was necessary to put sawdust or shavings between the roof and the ceiling. To do this they would have to get someone from Regina but I have no price on the work.

The school require four new sewing machines. They claim these are necessary when they have so much old clothing to make over. The machines requested are the kind used by tailors.

Regina, July 25th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

In 1935 the water supply intake from the lake to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School was erected under the direction of Mr. D.B. Gow, District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service. I find no information on file about this by which I could give a Department file number for reference. I have, however, a letter from Mr. D.B. Gow to this office dated January 1st, 1937, in which he says he encloses a plan of the construction of this water intake. I am unable to locate the plan in the files of this office.

From information obtained from various sources I understand that the following is a rough description of the intake: an iron pipe 4" or possibly 6" extending a distance of about 300' into the lake adjacent to the school. For the purpose of protecting this pipe a framework of heavy timber about 10' wide has been constructed and this framework was secured with stones and gravel.

Pressure of the ice in the winter has moved this protection considerably to a position where I would expect that another winter's action by the ice would ruin it entirely.

At a point not far distant from the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School the Fort Qu'Appelle San has a similar pipe supply intake with no protection whatever. It is merely a pipe about 1500' long, being a great deal longer than the one at the school, extending from the boiler room through the ground below the frost line out into the lake where the water is deep enough that ice in the winter will not interfere with the pipe. This has been working efficiently for three years and shows no indication of giving trouble in the future.

Why such an elaborate construction was made at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School I do not know as the conditions are very similar with the exception that at the latter point the length of the pipe is a great deal less.

As I am afraid there may be trouble with the intake at the school either during the coming winter or immediately thereafter I would suggest

that the Department communicate.........
that the Department communicate with Mr. D.B. Gow at Winnipeg for the purpose of obtaining from him a description of his work at the school and his opinion of the possibility of damage which might result from the ice pressure moving the framework considerably out of its original position. It would be interesting also to enquire why the elaborate protection was necessary when it does not seem necessary at the San under similar conditions.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Re: Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

We are enclosing copy of a memorandum by Mr. G. M. Lyon, engineer of this staff, relating to the condition of the water supply intake at the above mentioned school.

Under date of January 19, 1927, we forwarded our Controller at Ottawa three copies of the plan of the water intake at Lebret, being one print each for our Controller, Indian Affairs Branch and the Director of Surveys and Engineering Branch. Copies were also forwarded to the Principal of the School, to the Inspector of Indian Agencies at Regina and to the Sanitary Engineer, Department of Health at Regina. Again, under date of February 25, 1929, we forwarded you, along with other plans, duplicates of the new water intake at this school. Accordingly, you will have available detailed plans of the present water supply intake at this institution. In 1941, the writer visited the school and found the intake in fairly good condition except for insufficient filling. It was suggested to the Principal that he have some additional earth filling placed on the structure and I believe this was done. A photograph taken upon the occasion of the visit is enclosed for your information.

Mr. Lyon in his sketch plan has shown in detail the movement of the crib work. We do not definitely know in what way the ice pressure has caused this movement but the writer is inclined to believe that it has been caused by combined ice expansion and wind movement rather than by floating ice movement at the time of the spring breakup. If this view is correct, then it will be difficult to combat such pressure or protect against it.

Referring to the letter of Mr. J.F.D. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Regina, I might say that we are not familiar with the new water intake at the Provincial Sanitarium near Fort Qu'Appelle. They probably had suitable equipment for dredging out a channel for the intake and they also had the advantage of the more regulated level of these small lakes and accordingly did not have to protect against low water conditions. In 1936 we had to provide for a possible low water elevation of 63.0 on the lake. Now, however, with such a low elevation pretty well guarded against by the dam at the outlet of Katipwe Lake, we could dispense with the outer 300 foot section of cribwork protection.

As pointed out in Mr. Lyon's memorandum, there does appear to be no immediate necessity for repairing the crib or providing additional protection for the pipe line. If the deterioration continues throughout the coming winter, it may become necessary to give further consideration to what is required or what should be done at the site to protect the pipe line itself from rupture.

Memorandum

Mr. D.B. Gow

Re:-Water Supply Intake at Indian Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan.

In accordance with your instructions, this school was visited by the writer on August 12th last.

The water supply intake consists of a 4" Universal Cast Iron Pipe Line, 1220 feet in length, of which 950 feet was added in 1936 extending the line west from the original well supply to a lake intake. The intake 790 feet of the pipe line is offshore and 440 feet of this adjacent to the shore have been protected by a clay and rock filled timber crib. This crib was deemed necessary to protect the pipe line from freezing and from the movement of ice.

The necessity for such protection depends on the relative elevations of the pipe line and the depth of frost penetration or ice formation. Continuous records of the water level in Lebret Lake are not available. Based on the datum at the school, frequent records show fluctuation from 84.8 to 85.7; the elevation being 85.5 on August 12th. From information obtained by Mr. W.T. Rose in 1936, a probable minimum water level of 80.0 was deduced. Allowing for a maximum thickness of ice of 3 feet, the necessity for protection for the pipe line where it is above elevation 80.0 is indicated. This coincides with the position of the end of the crib as constructed in 1936. Therefore, to maintain the present pipe line in service, protection for it will have to be supplied in the future as in the past.

An examination of the crib and contained fill was made by the writer which showed that considerable movement has taken place due to ice pressure from the south where a lake expanse about one mile long exists. The north side of the crib is not subject to comparable ice pressure because it is not more than 1/4 mile from the shore. Attached are a sketch showing cross sections of the crib at 50 feet intervals, and a photograph looking west towards the intake from the high portion of the crib at station 300. It is evident that differential vertical movement has taken place varying from nothing up to a maximum of 2.0 feet in a particular part of the crib. Some lateral movement towards the north has also taken place but its extent was not determined. The whole structure has moved as a unit with the exception of some of the 3 x 10 cross brases which have pulled away from the piles; the piles, sheeting and longitudinal wellings on each side have maintained their original relative positions. The clay fill topped with rock has not shown appreciable subsidence except at the extreme west end where it is 1.3 feet lower than constructed.

D. B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
532 Dominion Public Building,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.
CONCLUSIONS:

At the present time there is still sufficient protection for the pipe line, as the crib and clay-fill, although displaced, are largely intact. The water level at elevation 85.3 is high enough to protect the pipe line against ice, even without a protective covering. Hence there is no immediate necessity for reparking the crib or otherwise providing additional protection for the pipe line. If another winter causes further deterioration in the crib and the water level in the lake drops appreciably, then consideration will have to be given to some method of assuring adequate protection for the water supply intake.

(Sgd.) G. M. Lyon

Re: Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

The above school is in need of the following which, it hopes, will be supplied out of the present year's estimates:

1) Material for insulating the ceiling of the entire building. I am informed that, regardless of the efforts of the engineer to heat the dormitories, there is a difference of as much as 12° between the temperature of the two lower storeys and that of the top one. This is due to the kind of construction used in the roof of the building and the only means now known to correct it is the placing of isolated material between the ceiling of the dormitories and the school roof.

The ceilings of the school are all of cement and only the ground floor ceilings were ever painted. This lack of finish was due possibly to the depression and later on to war conditions. Now that paint can easily be secured, it is hoped that the Department will supply same immediately. The quantity required is estimated at 100 gallons with a proportional quantity of oil and terpentine. Four paint brushes should also be supplied.

The floors of all the class rooms are of cement and cause considerable trouble particularly due to the dust that is raised by the children's feet. It is eminently desirable that linoleum be placed on all these floors. It is estimated that 200 yards, double width, would suffice to cover the great part of these floors.

Memo:

Mr. D. R. Gov

Re: - Lebret Indian Residential School.

An inspection was made of the sewage disposal bed at the above school on May 16th.

Present Conditions:

On the day of inspection, one break existed in the disposal bed area. Flow of apparently the same magnitude as the outflow from the septic tank was coming through the break and running out onto the ground surface, about 50 feet from the main distributor line near the bottom of the disposal area. Four other similar breaks had occurred this spring in the disposal bed on the other side of the main distributor pipe but were not flowing on May 16th. These had been stopped by merely excavating the soil down to or close to the tile and then refilling the excavation again, sealing the backfill in solidly. The maintenance crew had applied the writer's presence to the present break and no further outflow took place during his visit. However, an excavation to the tile, 10 feet farther away from the main distributor pipe, showed that the tile was locally blocked with black solid material and only a slight seepage of water was evident in the tile. It is probable that the tile in the whole disposal area is in much the same condition.

As the surfaces of the disposal bed has been used by the school for a garden, the school authorities were reluctant to have it torn up in order to clean out the tile. I, therefore, suggested that they attempt to clean out the tile by forcing clean water under pressure from the school's pump back through the tile to the main distributor line and then out by removing the plug at the end of the line. They said that they would try it and let us know the results.

If this method is unsuccessful, it will probably cost $1,000. to remove the soil, dig up the tile, relay and backfill it.

The crib, which protects the intake for the water supply, appears to be in much the same condition as it was when the writer made an inspection of it on August 12, 1946. The water level in Lebret Lake is 0.5 feet higher at 85.6 than it was on that date.

(Signed): G. M. Lyon.

D. R. Gov., Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
532 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
For your information please.

Please note there is a possibility that $1,000 may be required this summer for cleaning and relaying tile. We will advise you again when a further report from Mr. Gow is available.

Dear Sir,

I wish to bring to your attention our laundry problem in this school. We wash the clothing for 300 inmates. The water used for this purpose is pumped from the lake; the hardness of this water, as per letter enclosed, has 35.0 grains of hardness. We use about 4800 gallons of water for each laundry and in order to get little results we have to use a great quantity of soap, crystal Brite water softener (chemicals), soda etc. The results are rather poor, moreover we damage the clothing.

According to Mr Smith, the superintendent of the Laundry Division, for the Sanatorium of Sask., we could cut the quantity of soap used to one third, by using a softener. We could also eliminate the use of the chemicals, and the results on clothing would be far better.

When this school was built, a small softener was installed which is insufficient for our requirements. This softener has a capacity of only 640 gallons between regenerations. The factory recommendation for our requirement would be a 210,000 grains, priced at $633.60. To be able to use the softener we have now, we would need a large storage tank (4000 gals), that would cost nearly as much as a new softener, and there is no room in the power room or laundry room for same. Besides this, the water in the laundry machines is heated directly by steam, which, according to an expert, has a very bad effect on the fibres of clothing. By installing a storage tank of 500 gallons (for which there would be room) we could heat the water directly in the tank at the necessary degree of 100° or 150° for cotton & wool.

Quotations:
Softener........$633.60
Storage tank..$260.00
Total........$893.60

AUG 5 1946
I believe that this installation would be a valuable improvement in this school. Soft water could also be used for shower baths, washing dishes. The saving we would make on soap, on clothing, elimination of chemicals, would compensate greatly for this expense. The little softener we have now could also be sold or used in a smaller school.

I wonder if the Department would consider to undertake this expense in favor of this School.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re: Lebret Indian School.

With reference to the recent examination of the above building by yourself and our Mr. Johns. After discussing this matter fully with Mr. Johns we believe that the movement of this brickwork is caused by condensation freezing on the roof joists and shiplap, and in a thaw this would possibly drip onto the concrete slab and drift over to the corner of the building against the brickwork. At that point freezing and thawing could occur and move the brickwork out. It seems to us this is the only satisfactory explanation for the movement taking place although we are not absolutely certain on this point.

We estimate that it would cost approximately $425.00 to pull down the brickwork of the south west corner to the belt course level, reset the belt course stones at the corner and rebuild the brickwork. This price is approximate and we would be willing to carry out the repairs to this corner on a basis of cost plus ten percent.

We understand that there is a slight movement taking place in the north west corner but our price is for the work in the south west corner only.

We think it might be advisable to put in some ventilators to the roof space on this building. This would eliminate a good deal of condensation freezing on the under side of the roof deck. This would not cost very much and might possibly cure the whole trouble.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) E.S. Lord, Engineer.

Re: Indian School - Lebret, Saskatchewan.

I wish to report that the Superintendent of Indian Affairs for Saskatchewan informed me that a dangerous crack had appeared in the brick work at the above building.

On August 7th I visited the Indian School at Lebret in company with Mr. Johns of Smith Brothers and Wilson, contractors of Regina, who erected the said building. We inspected the building and found that a portion of the South West corner of the parapet wall had moved out, and was in a dangerous position at the break, which is at a point two lengths of stone band from the corner. At this point the stone is hanging out about two inches beyond the face of the other stone band, and as the face brick is above the stone and flush with the stone band, this too is hanging out about two inches.

In my opinion the cause of this is that rain has found its way in the weathered mortar joints of both stone and brickwork and entered into the cavity between the face brick and the back brick of parapet wall, and during cold weather has frozen, thus causing a movement, similar to the movement of the stone coping on the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. The inner brick wall of parapet wall was in perfect condition, no cracks were noticeable.

We were informed that this movement has been going on for years, however this spring it seemed to move more than previous years. In view of this and in view of the fact it is a school where 285 children are playing around I requested Mr. Johns of Smith Brothers and Wilson to
forward me a letter with a quotation to repair said parapet wall as I do not wish any accident to occur. I here-with enclose said letter with a quotation of $425.00 to repair said parapet wall.

I consider the price to be fair and reasonable and the work absolutely necessary and in the public interest and shall be pleased to receive your authority for this expenditure as quickly as possible as this repair work is urgent.

I may further state that other portions of the parapet wall showed signs of slight movement but not dangerous.

An enlarged photo of crack is being prepared and I will forward it to you as soon as I receive same.

Norman L. Thompson,
District Resident Architect.

Re: Report of the Dietitian on Qu'Appelle Indian School - Kitchen Equipment needed.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Your dietitian on the occasion of her visit to the above school, on October 21 to 22, 1947, recommended the following:

1. Replacement of the present cook stove or the installation of steam equipment to cook satisfactorily for over 300 people. Prices have been asked for a stove large enough for this school, and will be submitted to your Department shortly. Of course, if you wish to install steam equipment, the same will be favourably considered by the Principal.

2. This school lacks proper pot washing facilities in the kitchen and must be provided with them as soon as possible.

3. A dish-washing machine is also advised. If the purchase of this machine was thought too expensive, proper dish-washing facilities should be provided in the dish-washing room.

4. The replacement of the old and worn bread slicer.

5. The Principal bought a War Assets electric mixer for the price of $250.00, and has already asked your Department to assume the payment of this machine but you have been obliged to refuse. He still insists that it is a departmental obligation and that the grant is not sufficient to allow him to assume such purchases.

The financial limitations were given by the Principal of this school as well as by all other Principals, and they all find it impossible to procure the quality, quantity and variety of foods asked for by your dietitian under the present financial set-up.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Proposed Technical School - Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.

In answer to your memorandum of June 22, the following is the information requested concerning the above subject:

(1) That the Oblate Order is at present operating a scholasticate or junior seminary some two miles from the present Indian residential school at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

(2) That the Oblate Order has the opportunity to rent a building near St. Norbert, Manitoba, which would be more suitable for their requirements than the seminary building at Lebret.

(3) That the Oblate Order is prepared to rent this seminary building to the Department of Mines and Resources for use either as an Indian residential school or as a vocational or technical school for older Indian boys and girls.

(4) That our Regional Supervisor for Saskatchewan has made the following comments concerning the need for such a technical school in Saskatchewan:

"This report was handed to me by Reverend Father Piche, O.M.I., Principal of the Qu'Appelle School, and the points raised were discussed with me. There are many things in connection with the report which deserve serious consideration by the Department, and the need..."
of a residential school for Indian young people in the higher grades to take additional technical training should be faced if it is decided to give higher education to Indians.

"Many of those past grade 8 do not wish to go on, and with those very little can be done. However, those who do wish to go on will be served better through the discipline of a residential school where their working hours are under some control, as well as their recreational and study periods, and are much more likely to be successful than if they were sent into a town or city on their own responsibility at the dangerous age for Indian young people."

"It would appear that much of the hope for success lies in the right kind of discipline, with competent instruction both during study hours and during recreation.

"I would be glad if the officials of the Department would seriously consider this report. Many things about it seem practical and in line with recommendations made by and before the Joint Committee. Further instructions with regard thereto will be appreciated."

(5) That the Provincial of the Oblates has submitted a report to the Department concerning the proposed technical school in which a thorough outline has been given of the type of education which would be offered therein. A copy of this report is attached hereto.

I have seen the plans of the seminary (erected of brick veneer about 1925) and feel that it would be suitable for our needs. We could house approximately 20 older boys and girls in the building and could use the farm and farm buildings for horses in farming, farm mechanics, carpentry, brick laying, auto mechanics, etc. It will be necessary that a careful educational survey be made by our Supervisor of Vocational Training to determine the number of graduates from our Indian day and residential schools in Alberta,
Saskatchewan and Manitoba who can take advantage of the technical courses proposed at Lebret. It will also be necessary to assure ourselves that we can hire a staff of qualified technical teachers. There is a great shortage of trained personnel in this field and it may be necessary to approach officials of the Canadian Vocational Training Division of the Department of Labour in this regard.

Director.

Dear Father Piche:

We have recently received a letter from Reverend R. Dion, O.M.I., regarding the request for new flooring in the boys' playroom at the Qu'Appelle Residential School.

From the information given by Father Dion it would appear that the cost would be slightly over $900.00 to supply and install tile flooring. We doubt if this type of flooring would prove satisfactory for the rooms in which it would be placed. It is presumed that one of the main reasons for asking for new flooring is to keep down the dust and we would like to know if you have ever tried painting the floors with a good cement paint. Two coats of good quality cement paint to cover 2,200 square feet costs approximately $50.00 and should give satisfactory at least for several months when the process could be renewed.

If you do not consider this satisfactory we suggest that you obtain prices for applying plastic rock to the floor. We understand that this material gives a good covering.

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM

The Deputy Minister

Re: Lebret Scholasticate - 25605

I desire to place before you the following additional information regarding the Lebret Scholasticate, Lebret, Saskatchewan, for the purchase of which representations have been made to the department. You will have on file my previous memorandum to you, dated January 7, 1949, on this subject.

1. Report of the inspection of the buildings by the Donald Inspection Limited.

2. Report received from Mr. C.A.F. Clark, our Educational Survey Officer.

3. Memorandum on the suggested purchase, dated January 22, 1949, from Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor, Saskatchewan.

4. Summary of the Indian children of the Roman Catholic faith attending residential schools in the western part of Ontario and the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

Taking into consideration the total number of children in Grades 7, 8, 9 and 10, as shown in the summary, only a small percentage of whom would be available to attend, if we should use Mr. Ostrander's figures for Saskatchewan as a guide, it is not seen how the purchase of this school, for the training suggested, could be justified. It is difficult, as well, to find firm...
grounds on which purchase could be recommended, in view of the relatively small number of children for whom schooling would be provided, compared with the much larger number to whom education could be extended through the construction of Indian day schools for the same outlay. Apart from this, however, it is doubtful whether we have yet secured sufficient information on which to make a decision, considering the large sum involved and the other matters of equal, if not greater, importance in the picture.

I can see no justification for purchase by the government.

Director.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

In answer to your letter of March 8th regarding the stokers installed on our kitchen range. These stokers have been in operation for 5 months, and no signs of warping are showing on the range. This will eventually happen when steam or hard coal are being used. But in our case, with the use of Lignite soft coal, no intensive heat is produced.

Prowse Co. of Montreal, who sold the range, assured me that their range was being built to be equipped with stokers. The top of the range is very heavily built.

Similar installations are being used in two of our large houses in Manitoba with very good results.

Engineer, Frank Arnusch, of Regina, whose recommendation was being followed to install the stokers, told me that the installation would solve the problem of lack of draft. It must be taken into consideration that the draft, here in the valley, is very deficient on certain days. Since we are using these stokers we have never experienced any handicaps; the heat on the range and ovens is even at all times.

The economy of operation of this installation is a recommendation that speaks for itself.

Yours very truly,

Regina, March 23rd, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 1st instant, File 660-5 (E.1), regarding the installation of a stoker and other equipment at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, I am enclosing herewith copy of my letter of the 8th instant, File 463-315-11 ARC, addressed to Reverend Father Piche, and copy of his reply dated March 14th, 1949.

While I do not approve of the manner in which Reverend Father Piche purchased and installed the stoker without reference to the Department I believe that it is proving entirely satisfactory and, so far as I am aware, no difficulty has arisen, or will arise, by the use of the stoker.

There is a situation at the Qu'Appelle Residential School which is somewhat out of the ordinary. The school buildings are in a valley close to the north side, with the result that north winds sweep down over the sides of the valley hills, sometimes causing considerable trouble in chimney drafts. This, alone, was sufficient reason for installing the blower, as the oven heat can be completely controlled with that installation, which was impossible previously.

I would recommend that future requirements for the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School be referred to Indian Superintendent Frank Booth, whose office is now only ten minutes drive on a gravelled road from the school at Lebret, and, of course, easily contacted by telephone. If that action were followed in the future we would not run into difficulties of this kind where purchases are made contrary to regulations. In the meantime, I would recommend that the account referred to be paid as the installation was practically a necessity.

AIR MAIL

Regina, April 16th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 14th instant, File 660-5 (E.1), regarding the cost of moving the two bungalows from the former file hills Agency to the site of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, I did not have a written quotation from Messrs. Stewardson & Sons, Lebret, and I was unaware that someone had given incorrect dimensions of the building referred to when Messrs. Stewardson & Sons gave a quotation to Reverend Father Piche of not less than $800.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for the job. Reverend Father Piche telephoned me and informed me that he had this quotation, and did not state that there was any question of the sizes of the two buildings. Actually, it is my opinion that as the work of moving such buildings consists mostly of raising them on to wheels or skids for towing purposes, and nowhere else thereafter I can see any reason why there should be such a difference of $200.00 in the cost. I would repeat that there was some question as to the possibility of the cost being $800.00. When comparing that quotation with the amount now asked of $1,000.00, otherwise an increase of 50%, I believe the increased price is even less justified.

As I realize that the matter is urgent in view of the fact that it is desirable that the cost thereof be made from Appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49, a long drawn-out controversy is undesirable. If the Department is prepared to delay payment, to be a charge against the 1949-50 Appropriation, and I am so advised, I would like to have the opportunity to go further into the matter before I would be willing to definitely recommend that the price of $1200.00 be accepted.

Consideration should be given to the fact that when Messrs. Stewardson & Sons commenced work on the two buildings they certainly must have ascertained that the buildings were larger than they had anticipated. That would have been the time for another telegram to be sent to the Department, revising their quotation, not waiting until the work was finished to make the protest. The receipt of the letter referred to is the first intimation I have had that there was any question of the cost exceeding $1,000.00. The account of C.H. Stewardson & Sons is returned herewith.

J.P.B. Ostreider,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Regina, April 27th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 22nd instant, File 660-5 (E.1), regarding the cost of moving two houses from the site of the former File Hills Agency to the site of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, I discussed the matter of the account of Messrs. Stewardson & Sons with Reverend Father Piche yesterday.

Father Piche informed me that Messrs. Stewardson & Sons were given the incorrect measurements of the building by his Assistant, but that they discovered the buildings were larger than anticipated before they started to move them. There was some discussion at that time as to the price. Finally they decided to move the buildings without amending their quotation, and have done so. I may say also that I examined the buildings at the new site, and I find that an excellent job of moving has been done. One of the buildings arrived at the school with no damage whatever to plaster or stucco work, the other building has no damage to the stucco, and only slight plaster damage.

Messrs. Stewardson & Sons hoped that they could be paid an additional $200.00 for the job, but admitted that the Department is well within its rights in refusing to pay more than $1,000.00 under the circumstances, and they have consented to accept $1,000.00 in full settlement, considering the matter closed.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:

(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and

(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:

(a) the safety valve is set to relieve at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;

(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;

(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Re: Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Saskatchewan.

You are advised that we are in receipt of a letter from Mr. W.W. Perrie dated September 24th together with a report and sketch prepared by Engineer F.J. Clark, with reference to the high pressure boilers and laundry service at the above.

An immediate inspection was urgently requested by Regional Supervisor Ostrander, and Mr. Perrie acted without delay, and before this request was forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Mr. Clark's report (substantiated by the Provincial Boiler Inspector) states that one of the two 10 horsepower vertical high pressure boilers, has been condemned and that the other unit, while in good condition, will have to be re-tubed at an early date. The report goes on to describe the items of laundry equipment requiring high pressure steam service. The load, based on the machines listed in the report, requires about 700 lbs. of steam per hour; this is equal to about 20 horsepower.

It would appear advantageous at this time to replace these boilers with one new vertical high pressure boiler, having a capacity of 20 horsepower, thus combining one firing and maintenance operation. As this type of boiler requires almost constant attention during its use, it follows that one unit to handle the entire laundry load would be desirable. The cost of re-tubing the 10 horsepower boiler plus one new 10 horsepower boiler would be approximately $200.00 less than the cost of one new 20 horsepower boiler, but the resultant fuel savings together with a much more desirable and safer set-up, would be in our opinion, in the best interests of all concerned.

It is therefore recommended that at an estimated cost of $2,000.00 one new 20 horsepower vertical high pressure boiler built for 125 lbs. working pressure be installed at the above. You are advised that we are in receipt of a letter from Mr. W.W. Perrie dated September 24th together with a report and sketch prepared by Engineer F.J. Clark, with reference to the high pressure boilers and laundry service at the above.

Mr. Clark's report (substantiated by the Provincial Boiler Inspector) states that one of the two 10 horsepower vertical high pressure boilers has been condemned, and that the other unit, while in good condition, will have to be re-tubed at an early date. The report goes on to describe the items of laundry equipment requiring high pressure steam service. The load, based on the machines listed in the report, requires about 700 lbs. of steam per hour, this is equal to about 20 horsepower.

It would appear advantageous at this time to replace these boilers with one new vertical high pressure boiler having a capacity of 20 horsepower thus eliminating one firing and maintaining operation. As this new boiler requires almost no attention during its use, it follows that one unit to handle the entire laundry load would be desirable. The cost of re-tubing the 10 horsepower boiler plus one new 10 horsepower boiler would be approximately $200.00 less than the cost of one new 20 horsepower boiler, but the resultant fuel savings together with a much more desirable and safer set-up, would be in our opinion, in the best interests of all concerned.

It is therefore recommended that at an estimated cost of $2,000.00 one new 20 horsepower vertical high pressure boiler built for 125 lbs. working pressure be installed at the above. This boiler to be complete with fire and ash doors, grates and grate bearers, smoke bonnet, tube brush and rod and to have the following mountings—steam gauge and siphon, water glass, try cocks, safety valve, blow-off valve and nipple, feed and check valves, together with a new injector and the necessary piping.

We have no information relative to the size of the high pressure steam main from the existing boilers to the laundry machines. This main should be not less than 1/2". If found to be smaller, the main should be increased to the size mentioned, in order that excessive pressure drops be avoided. Should it be found necessary to replace this line, the cost will be extra to the estimate given.

Condensation should be reclaimed from the ironer and the dryer and returned through inverted bucket traps and piping to a steel condensation barrel set up adjacent to the boiler. This return line should not be smaller than 3/4".

In accordance with my letter of instructions, dated 6th Feb., 1898 No. 128, I proceeded to the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and beg to report as follows:

The piece of land required to square up and enlarge the garden North of the Institution is situated as shown on the annexed sketch and colored yellow.

I found all traces of the lines forming the Eastern boundary of the School lands, as surveyed by D. L. S. Du Berger, have entirely disappeared, and before a description by metes and bounds, of the proposed addition can be made, they must be re-surveyed, but I did not feel that the value of the proposed addition justified me in making such a survey at this season of the year, when I found the depth of snow, and other physical difficulties which exist, would so largely increase the ordinary expense.

In event of the Dept. deciding in favor of acquiring this land, a survey can be made in the Spring of the year with comparatively small expense, and at the same time, I would draw attention to the importance of having all

the boundaries of the School lands, permanently established with Iron posts.

The garden as it exists at present, is not of sufficient extent for the requirements of the School, and from an examination of the plan, it would appear that sufficient ground could be found, on the prairie portion for a much more extensive one.

Gardening has been tried on the prairie portion, but it has been found quite impracticable for the reasons, of the impossibility of the boys ascending and descending a hill some three hundred feet in height in going to and from work, the impossibility of overseeing them at work, the poor nature of the soil for garden stuff, and its being required for pasture.

Sir,

Referring to your letter No.126 of Feb.8th and to the survey of Mr. Ponton of a piece of land to be purchased in order to square our vegetable field and make it sufficiently large, I have the honor to inform you that the title of the Mission to the land is clear, the Patent being in their hands and Mr. Ponton having seen it.

Mr. Ponton was unable to do the survey properly, owing to the impossibility of finding the former posts or even the line, at this time of the year.

When the first survey was made here the Surveyor simply drove a two foot post into the ground at every corner without holes or mounds round them.

It would be impossible for any but a Surveyor to point out the exact line. As there are at least fifteen angles in it, between the lake and hill, the necessity of having this line between the Mission and School properties permanently laid out with proper iron posts and holes, is obvious. There is still a more urgent reason for having the land surveyed again.

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
The public trail from the Le Bret settlement to Touchwood and to the settlers in that direction passes through our land, and until it is transferred to the municipality we will have to keep it in repair at our own expense, although it is practically a public road.

This road requires repairs every year. It runs at the feet of, or between the hills, for a mile and a half and gets washed away considerably every Spring.

There is also a bridge on it which we had to build ourselves and keep in repair at our own expense. The municipality would take over the road and keep it in repair if it was properly surveyed and permanently located.

Until that piece of land, asked for, is purchased from the Mission the road cannot be properly located, having the land will be a great advantage to us, as it will enlarge our vegetable fields and render its shape fit for cultivation.

In the present Municipal Council there is a majority who are willing to have the road transferred to the Municipality. It is very doubtful if another Council would be willing to have this done, as it is our only road to the farm and for our own interests we have to keep it in repair.

It is therefore very important and necessary that early in the Spring steps be taken to have a proper survey made to purchase the piece of land from the Mission, and to survey and definitely locate the road preparatory to having it properly transferred to the Municipality who will then have to keep it in order.
We have frequently been delayed when we had other pressing work to do, repairing the road or bridge. Sometimes the teams have had to work on it for several days at a time.

Mr. Ponton having seen the place I would refer you to him for further particulars if any are necessary.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM.

This Department has always been accustomed to treat the Industrial School appropriations as granted for the general purposes of these schools. It would be manifestly impossible to foresee with absolute accuracy the needs of any one of these Institutions for a year, six or seven months before that year commences, and we have accordingly allowed ourselves considerable latitude for expending the aggregate sum voted by Parliament. No special appropriation has been made in the current year's Estimates for buying hay lands for the Qu'Appelle and High River Industrial Schools, but as this land is necessary, and as there is no available Government land in proximity to the School, I see no reason why the purchase should not be made. We require the hay lands, and to pay for them from existing appropriations simply does away with the necessity of
of making additional provision. From present indications I think we will have a surplus in the vote for Industrial Schools of about $15,000 or $20,000.

February 20th, 1894.

As the Department has to supply hay to the Industrial Schools the undersigned recommends the following purchases of hay lands:

For the use of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School:

For use of St. Joseph's Industrial School:

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it is time steps should be taken to fence in our hay lands in order to protect them against roaming bands of cattle and horses, as otherwise the land recently purchased for hay purposes would be valueless.

Last year we had to go 15 miles and over to procure hay for want of a fence round our hay lands and we have had to purchase 40 tons as well. We have now three quarter sections of hay land either belonging to the school or purchased for it. To fence in this land with two wires and willow posts 3600 of the latter would be required, at 2 cents each and about 3600 lbs of wire with staples.

The quarter sections are the N.W.¼ of 22, 21, 12 reserved two years ago and the N.W.¼ of 34, 21, 12; the N.E.¼ lately bought from Mr. Crabbe and the N.W.¼ reserved.

Indian Commissioner

Regina
both these pieces of land lie in the same township as the school and are therefore at a convenient distance and if properly fenced will I hope yield a sufficient quantity of hay.

The willow pickets at 2 cents each will be exceedingly cheap, as they are very scarce in this vicinity; but the half breeds are in such destitution now that I can procure them at that price. I beg to be authorized to purchase the willow pickets while I can procure them at the above price and so as to have the fencing done before the hay can be destroyed.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient Servant

(Signed) J. Hugonnard

Sir,

In reply to your letter 82/42 of 25 October regarding section 6.22,12 W/2M which was reserved for hay purposes for the school in Department's letter 1107 of Jany.21st,1891, I would say that this section has not had sufficient hay on it to make it worth our while fencing in or cutting it for over six years now; prairie fires having destroyed the bush that formerly surrounded the sloughs there has been insufficient moisture in that district to grow hay since.

The land is very rolling and consists mostly of sand and gravel ridges; the bush that surrounded the sloughs, before it was burnt, used to collect the snow in winter and prevent evaporation in summer and at the time it was reserved and for a few years after there was a fair amount of hay on the section each year.

As hay land it is useless to us now and it is too far away and the grass too scanty and soil too light to be of other use to the school at present.

The last few years we have been taking out permits for hay land about 20 miles north or buying hay from the settlers up there, but the Roumanians are fast cutting off our supply in this direction and the closer settlement now taking place all over the neighborhood will shortly deprive us of this source of obtaining hay altogether.

A good supply of milk is an important item in the diet of so many children; to obtain this it is necessary to keep quite a number of milch cows and to keep the cows we must have grazing land, hay land and land for root crops. The increased farming operations in the district render it impossible to let our cattle range at large in the summer, and have cut off our former hay supply, necessitating our growing fodder of some kind for winter feeding in future.

The land we own in the immediate vicinity of the school is light, slopes to the south and embraces the hills facing the south so that after July, in a season like last year, everything gets scorched up and there is very little pasturage; in consequence we have to rely on land lying further back from the valley for farming operations, pasture, fodder, supply, etc.; and as mixed farming is the occupation most of the pupils will follow in after life it is most important that facilities for successfully carrying it on at the school are secured while available.

In the event of the Indian Department not being able to secure other land more suitable I would advise retaining the whole of Section 6.22.12 W 2 N, at any rate for another year.

At the request of this Department in 1891, Sec. 22-13-W.2 M. was reserved for hay purposes for the use of the Qu'Appelle Industrial school.

In 1894 the Northeast quarter of Sec. 34-21-13-W.2 M. was purchased from Mr. Crosbie together with his pre-emption right to the Northwest quarter of the same section.

At the time the said purchase was made it was intended to notify the Department of the Interior that the above mentioned section 6 was to be relinquished. This notice, however, was not given and consequently the said section is still reserved for the use of this Department.

In October of last year the Department of the Interior requested to be informed whether the said section 6-22-12-W.2 M., was still required as a reservation for hay purposes for the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

The Indian Commissioner at Regina was asked to state whether the said section was still required. In reply he forwarded a letter from the Rev. H. Hugonard, Principal of the School stating that the said section was too distant from the school, and not suitable for growing hay. He strongly recommended that an exchange of half of the said section be made for a quarter section which he represented to be better land, and which was situated much nearer to the School.

The Department of the Interior would not entertain a proposal to exchange a half section for a quarter section.
On again referring the matter to the Indian Commissioner, the Principal again urged the exchange above referred to, and if this were not possible then he wished that the said section should be retained by this Department at least for another year to afford him an opportunity of ascertaining whether he could make any good use of the land in connection with the school.

The owner of the quarter section referred to has refused $6. per acre for it, but is willing to accept as stated half of the said section 6 in exchange. Sir:

I beg to submit to your favorable consideration the following report respecting the farm connected with this school.

Towards the year 1890, the Department bought for this school the north-east quarter of section 34 township 21 range 13 and reserved also for us, the north-west quarter, making a half section viz the north-half of section 34 township 21 range 13. This half section is over five miles from the school and was intended chiefly for hay land.

Since that time, the farming has become more important and //is now the principal industrial training for the eldest pupils. We are endeavouring to carry out the intentions of the Department by farming more extensively than before and teaching it to the boys. Having not enough of cultivable land, we had to farm on the section adjoining the school, on the above mentioned half section what is fit for it.

But the distance makes it almost impossible to farm properly and successfully. It is too far to go there every day. To go there for the week means the loss of half a day to go and half a day to come back. It takes one to do the cooking. The boys working there cannot be overseen nor trained as easily as if it was near. The least brake, the wanting of a bolt, or grain, or hay, or provision, or clothing necessitates a trip of ten miles to get it.

It is therefore very desirable that the farm should be nearer. A section 15 township 21 range 13 of land situated half a mile from school, and adjoining on two side, the lands on which the school is built, as per attached sketch is now for sale and could be almost exchanged with the half section above referred to.

This section 15 township 21 range 13 is the only one whose location is suitable for this school and it would be regrettable
to miss the opportunity of securing it at a reasonable figure.

This section can be obtained for $16.00 an acre or $10240.00 and the half section above referred to could bring $30.00 to the acre in a few years, being only two miles from the Patrick station and having 150 acres cultivated on it. At the present time it would bring no more than $20.00 to the acre, and we need it until the section 15 will be sufficiently cultivated.

As it would be necessary to secure the section 15 now, otherwise it will be sold to others, and as the half section 34 is still needed and could not yet bring its full value, I would ask the Department to advance five thousand one hundred and twenty dollars ($5120.00) to pay half of the section 15, or the whole sum $10240.00 which could be returned in full or nearly when the half section would be sold. If only a part is paid now, interest will have to be paid for the balance.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Sir,

I beg to refer to my Letter of April 24th 1907 No 7524 and to your Letter No 116578/22 of 7th May 1907 re the exchange of our Farm situated five miles away.

The experience of every year proves more and more that it is impossible to cultivate at that distance without loss to the school and in the manner required for the proper teaching of the pupils in farming.

What I propose amounts to an exchange although, at the present time, it will require the purchase of a farm conveniently situated but as our land is the same size and about the same value, the sum required to purchase could be entirely returned to the Department as soon as the far away school land would be sold.
