Dear Sir:

Re boundary between Industrial School Grant and Oblate Father's Property-2 and 11-21-13-2 at Lebret.

Acknowledging your letter of the 29th inst., in reference to the above, I may say that the purpose of my former letter was to bring the question of the discrepancies regarding this boundary officially before you. My right of way survey was made connecting with the boundary line as shown on the plans sent you and of course all necessary ties were made to the lots of Plan S3784 which will all be shown on the plan of right of way now in course of preparation and on the plan of resurvey of part of the Ellisboro Long Lake Trail which is in course of being submitted to the Department of Highways. The point to be decided is whether the line as defined on my plan can be regarded as the original line of division between these properties, notwithstanding that the bearings and lengths of the several courses do not agree with the original survey as evidenced by the official township plan and the description in the Oblate Fathers' title.

On first discussing these discrepancies, I am rather inclined to the opinion that the iron posts found by me represented a survey of this boundary made without reference to the survey shown on the township plan but on studying the question further am now disposed to think that the iron posts were put in to replace the wooden posts of the original survey while the wooden posts were still in evidence and that the differences in lengths and bearings are due to errors in the original survey, the whole survey being over very difficult ground.

I referred to this question to the Surveyor General in August last who in reply stated that this line was established in 1885 by C.C. Du Berger D.L.S., as shown on the official township plan dated Sept. 20th 1890 and that no further surveys affecting this line have been made under instructions from his office. Commenting upon the difference in lengths and bearings, the Surveyor General stated "Discrepancies such as you find between the township plan and the monuments as they are on the ground are not uncommon in surveys as far back as 1885."
As far as my survey is affected, I required only the portion of this line between the posts which I have designated Nos. 5 and 6 on the plan. Post No. 6 was readily found as it is referred to in Plan S.3794 and was well known to many of the people living at Lebret. A Mr. Chisholm who is employed at the Mission knew of the post shown on plan S 3794 on the west boundary of Lot 1 having frequently seen it before the ground at this point was cut away in grading a road running north from the Fort Ellice Trail at this point. This is the post shown on my plan as No. 5 and to reestablish its position, I relocated the S.W. corner of lot 1 from original posts found on the ground, joined that point with post No. 6 and produced the line so obtained northerly, a sufficient distance to give 8.82 chains between posts 5 and 6. In connection with the resurvey of the land I also required to know the direction of the next course of the boundary north of post 5 and being unable to find anyone at the time who knew of any posts farther up the coulie, I decided the quickest way to determine whether any such posts existed was to retrace the west and north boundary of section 11 and from that retracement to reproduce the line from the township plan southerly from the north boundary of section 11. In doing so, I found the posts marked 1, 2, 3, and 4 and later from information brought down by Mr. Loucks we located the iron post shown at a short distance (984 ft) southerly from No. 4. Post No. 4 was then joined by a straight line with Post No. 5 as reestablished.

South of post No. 6 towards the lake, I ran the next course on the bearing and for the distance given on the township plan but found nothing. From the end of that course I ran out the next course on the bearing S43°35'W and at 5.55 chains reached the lake shore. The Mr. Chisholm referred to above mentioned to me in this connection that the lake had encroached on the shore at this point from time to time and that the fence had been moved back on several occasions. This may account for the fact that the length of this course to the shore as it existed last August is considerably short of the length of this course as given on the Township plan.

This portion of the boundary is however shown on plan B.I.3065 made in recent years by Mr. W.R. Reilley, S.L.S. but as no evidence of Mr. Reilley's survey was found on the ground I decided not to make any reestablishment south of post No. 6. I can however furnish connections between the portion of the boundary between posts 5 and 6 and the lots of the subdivision shown on plan S3794 if desired.
It seems to me that if these discrepancies were brought to the attention of the department of Indian Affairs and the Oblate Fathers' that they would readily consent to have the necessary order made correcting the titles affected. I discussed the question with the Secretary of the Industrial School and the Parish Priest at the mission and both gentlemen were reasonably certain that no objection to the course would be raised by those in authority.

Yours truly,

Edgar C. Brown.
Land Surveyor.

Dear Sir:

You will recall our discussion last August regarding the boundary line between the Industrial School Grant and the property of the Oblate Fathers in sections 2 and 11 tp. 21 range 13 west of the second meridian at Lebret.

I explained to you at that time that in retracing this division line, I found certain iron posts evidently intended to define this limit instead of wooden posts as shown on the township plan and as mentioned in the certificate of title to the Oblate Fathers' property. These iron posts were not at the points where the wooden posts should have been according to the township plan. The Dept. of the Interior has no record of any survey of this limit on which iron posts were used and I have been unable to ascertain on what authority the iron posts were planted. The posts themselves are of an unusual type being solid cylindrical bars about 3 feet long with a foot plate of iron about four inches by six inches rivetted to the lower end to prevent removal. As nearly as I have been able to ascertain they were put in by A.W. Ponton D.L.S., about the year 1890, Mr. Ponton at that time being surveyor for the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

These posts have been accepted as defining the boundary for so long that in my opinion it would be advisable to have the records amended so as to give them proper legal standing, for any attempt to reestablish on the ground the boundary as shown on the township plan and as described in the Oblate Father's certificate of title would lead to confusion as such a reestablishment would place the division line between the properties a considerable distance to the east of the line as at present defined and at the south end would encroach upon the lots shown on Reg'd. plan S.3794.
I am sending you a duplicate tracing which I have prepared showing my retracement of this boundary and am satisfied to have you make such use of this plan or any other information regarding this boundary that I may have in my possession, as you see fit.

Sir:

Re Boundary Line between Industrial School Grant and Oblate Fathers' Property, Sec's 8 and 11, Tn. 21, R. 13, West End Dist., at Lebret, Sask.

During the season of 1918 Mr. H. C. Brown, S.L.S., the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway Company's Land Surveyor, while resurveying this Company's line from Melville to Regina found it necessary to re-establish the boundary line between the Industrial School property and the Oblate Father's property at Lebret.

As the survey monument on this line immediately to the North of the right of way had been lost, probably due to the road being graded at this point, Mr. Brown made a retracement of the boundary line from the extreme limit of Section 11 to the North shore of the lake. In making this retracement he found monuments consisting of iron bars of an unusual shape, being from 3 to 4 feet in length with a foot plate of iron about 4 inches by 6 inches rivetted to the lower end to prevent removal. The township plan shows that wooden posts were originally located at these points, and the Certificates of Title refer to these wooden posts and to the measurements as shown on the Township Plan. A thorough enquiry was made from the old time residents at Lebret and from the interested parties at this place, as well as from the Surveyor General and the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa but no authentic record of the survey with iron posts could be found.

All parties consulted however, seemed in agreement as to the time and manner in which this survey was made, viz:-

In 1890 by J. W. Ponton, D.L.S., then in the employ of the Dept. of Indian Affairs. As the original survey of the line was made in 1885 it is quite probable that Mr. Ponton found the old wooden posts at that time, but he received his instructions from Regina, and the records of such instructions or of his survey are somewhat vague at the present time at Ottawa. Personally, I am of the opinion that from the evidence submitted the above noted conclusions are reliable, and the iron posts found should be accepted as defining the boundary line. Moreover, these posts have been accepted as such by the various owners and residents of this vicinity for a good many years, and while the retracement survey joining these posts disagrees somewhat from the measurements shown on the township plan it seems desirable that the records based on same should be amended to agree with the present position of the iron posts.

Mr. Brown made a thorough investigation of this matter and
I am prepared to accept his re-establishment of this line for the purpose of tying in his right of way and road survey. In making the survey he retraced the East boundaries of Sections 3 and 10 from the lake Northwards and terminated his survey at Station 6 opposite the Industrial School. He made a careful search for monuments between this point and the lake but could find none.

It is now proposed to accept Mr. Brown's survey and this Department has agreed to extend his survey to the lake, together with such further additions as may seem necessary and file a plan showing the results of this survey. It is then proposed to have the Ministry of Titles issue an Order to the Registrar of the Aboriginal Land Titles Office, in which district the lands affected are situated, directing him to record all titles to the property on either side of the above mentioned boundary line, placing an endorsement on all such titles affected by this boundary, to the effect that the description referred to in such titles are to be interpreted according to the plan made by Mr. Brown R.L.S., acting in conjunction with this Department, this latter plan to be taken on condition that you, and the Minister of Indian Affairs give your consent to this procedure. Plans will of course be submitted to you and to the Minister of Indian Affairs for approval and signature before they are filed.

As stated above no changes whatever are to be made on the ground. The survey and plan are merely for the purpose of recording the true bearings and distances connecting the various monuments now in existence and which have been accepted. The missing monuments are to be restored in accordance with the data shown on the township plan.

In connection with the improvements affected, it is noted that the stone fence to the East of the Industrial School does not agree with the surveyed line. The L.P. at Station 6 is some distance South and East of the bend in the fence near this point. The fence between Station 5 and Station 6 crosses the survey line and is partly outside and partly inside the boundary line. From Station 5 to the lake the stone fence will fall back to the West of the line.

Enclosing herewith a Blue Print showing the results of Mr. Brown's survey. In black are shown the proposed additions made by agreement from this Dept. In red I have indicated the measurements shown on the township plans and over which the survey was based. To reproduce the measurements shown on the township plans would result in the boundary line falling about 20 feet further East in the townsite so that it is apparent that the measurements are inaccurate, due no doubt to the time of year and the difficult nature of the ground over which the survey was made, the lines crossing deep ravines and high hills.

Sir;-

Re N.W.T Sec 22, Tp 21, R 13, your letter of March 26th last No 71156,

This quarter section is without doubt the best piece of farm land the school has and to have it cancelled at this time would mean a severe loss. The quarter was secured years ago for hay purposes but in later years was cultivated and seeded. At the present time there is only a small part (about 25 acres) from which we get hay. Last year produced about 30 loads. About 100 acres is now plowed and the balance will be plowed this spring and sown for feed.

With the number of cattle and horses raised here it is essential that a large quantity of feed must be grown as it would be impossible to buy sufficient for use.

The school has neither too much arable or pasture land and to cancel this quarter would be depriving the school of a source of revenue which is so badly needed.

CRIME REPORT

Re: EDNA NAHNEPOVIS AND JULIA MISSENS - Truant Indian Girls from Lebret Indian Industrial School.

26-9-28

Long distance phone call received at this detachment from H.S. Davis, Indian Agent of Qu'Appelle Indian Agency requesting the assistance of a member of this detachment to locate and return the above mentioned truant Indian girls to the Industrial School at Lebret from which point they had absconded on the 25th inst.

I left Balcarres this am and patrolled to Qu'Appelle Agency by private auto where I picked up Mr. Davis who accompanied me in making a search of the Pasqua and Muscopeguing Indian Reserves, finally locating Edna Nahnepowis and Julia Missens at Rafferty's home, ascertain that the said Julia Missens had been taken back to the Lebret School by her mother. I continued my patrol to Lebret where I handed the girl Nahnepowis over to the Principal of the School after obtaining the usual receipt and returned to Balcarres this late p.m.

Re: Margaret Whitecloud - (Lebret Indian School Pupil) -
Griswold, Man.

Acting on instructions received, I left Brandon at 12:30pm of the 16th inst., and proceeded via C.P.R. on patrol to Griswold.

On arrival there I met the Indian Agent, J.F. Clark, who drove me out to the Oak River Indian Reserve.

A search of the reserve was made for the above girl, but she could not be located. Information was later forthcoming that she had left the reserve that morning with her father by auto, and it was expected that she would return the following day.

Late in the pm of the 16th inst., information was brought to Mr. Clark that the girl had returned to the reserve. The father was summoned to the Agency where he was instructed to have the girl at the Agency at 7am of the following date. Arrangements were made that the girl's mother would act as Matron.

At 7am of the 17th inst. the girl appeared at the Agency, but the mother stated that she could not proceed with the girl. The Grandfather was then appointed to act as Matron in the capacity of Matron.

I left Griswold at 8am, per C.P.R., and proceeded to Balcarres, Sask., where Mr. Clark had arranged that one of the staff of the Lebret School would meet me. I handed the girl over to Joe Doll of the Lebret School Staff, obtaining his receipt.

The Grandfather proceeded on to the school with the girl.

I left Balcarres at 3pm of the same date, and returned to Brandon, reporting at the detachment at 11:30pm.

(J.M.Berryman/Reg No. 10278)

The Officer Commanding,
R.C.M.P. Police,

Winnipeg, Man.

CANADA
Qu'Appelle Indian Agency
Muscow Sask.

November 1st, 1928

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith application for admission into the Lebret School together with certificate of health of one Annie Bruba.

The parents of this girl are non Treaty Indians and the father and this girl have lived as far as I can gather the information on the Piapot Reserve for a number of years.

The mother deserted the father some years ago and the girl has been brought up with the father.

I have signed the form of recommendation in order for the same to be in order if you think fit to accept the application.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 7th, 1928.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the first instant, I beg to say that, in view of your report, the Department considers that Annie Bruba comes within the terms of the Department's ruling regarding the admission of half-breeds to Indian residential schools. You may, therefore, inform the principal of the Qu'Appelle Residential School that her admission to that school is approved.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Jaw, Sask.

If you can take them I will send them along with the other boys that are to return to Lebret school in a week or two. Kindly let me know, and send application forms if needed."

I then wrote to Mr. Scott advising him that I would accept these boys and that it would not be necessary to have applications made out as Father Perrault had consented to having them transferred here.

Sir,

In reply to your letter 114-0-10, dated the 11th instant, in connection with Rosie Daniels, daughter of Albert Daniels and Justine Daniels.

Mrs Justine Daniels is the daughter of William Desnomes and is paid under ticket No. 128 Peepeekisis Band. She married Albert Daniels about eight years ago and immediately after her marriage left the Reserve and for some time resided in the United States. They came back some years ago and have worked around this district and part of the time they have lived with Mrs. Daniels' parents and they have also worked for Indian farmers on the Reserve. Albert Daniels is at the present time looking after the farm of Jack Fisher, but it is only as a hired man, as the horses, implements, buildings, etc., belong to Jack Fisher, and it is not certain how long he will remain in this position.

The matter of the eligibility of this girl for admission as a grant earning pupil has not previously been taken up with me nor have I any knowledge of an application form having been prepared. I have read very carefully the Deputy Superintendent's letter dated Nov. 9th, 1922 and I do not think that the above mentioned girl is entitled to be admitted under the Department's ruling shown in that letter. I must point out however that while Daniel's is working on the Reserve the chances of this girl getting an education other than through an Indian school is extremely remote. I hesitate to make a recommendation in this particular case, though I would like to see the girl in school, for fear that it would be referred to as a precedent, in future applications of a similar kind.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,
Indian Agent.

Possibly I am in error in interpreting your instructions. Albert Daniels is a half-breed and generally works around this district. When he is out of work he has from time to time come to live on the Reserve with his wife's parents and have occasionally employed him to work for Indian farmers which he is doing at the present time. If this is considered living the Indian mode of life than Daniel's children would be entitled to admittance to Qu'Appelle Residential School.

I have pointed out the facts in this case so carefully as the Department have issued instructions not to recommend children for admittance to schools where they had come to live on the Reserve for the purpose of qualifying. I do not think this has been done in this particular instance, but as there are quite a number of Indian women married to half-breeds and most of them are desirous of putting their children in Indian schools, there would be nothing to stop them from coming to stay with the woman's parents and possibly do a little work around the Reserve and then putting their children in the Department's schools. I thought Daniel's application would create a precedent that would be pointed to in subsequent applications of a similar nature.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith copies of letters from H. E. King, Overseer at Wood Mountain, also copy of letter written to Mr. King by Rev. Father Leonard, asking him to sign 'Applications for Admission' of a number of half-breed children to the Qu'Appelle School, who have no right whatever to be admitted.

I may say in the first place that Father Leonard knows perfectly well that he should not admit any children to that school without having the proper authority to do so, and it looks to me as though he is deliberately ignoring the instructions of the Department.

You are aware that at one time (about 15 years ago) nearly half the children in this school were halfbreeds. We succeeded in getting every one of them out, and made it a hard and fast rule that the only halfbreed children who could be admitted were those who were living on an Indian reserve as Indians.

The parents of every one of these children are voters, and when the children become of age they will have the right to vote. They are not a charge on the Federal Government at all, and if they are to be sent to school the expense should be borne by the Provincial Government.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt., General
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

We have had cases of this kind before, and I have consistently refused to have anything to do with them, so that if these admissions are permitted we will have done an injustice to other applicants and schools. We will also have opened up an avenue for the admission of hundreds more of the same type.

I would ask for your authority to have these children returned to their parents. There is no doubt there will be a long controversy if the Department is not emphatic in the matter.

I may say that I know the cases in question well, and they do not come under the category of those who should be admitted to an Indian School. I am rather annoyed with Father Leonard's action in this matter. He must have known that these children should not have been admitted, and if he had any doubt in the matter he could have called me up. Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 27th ultimo, No. 114-0-10, and the application for admission of Bill Alary to the Qu'Appelle Residential School, I beg to say that I am informed by Rev. Father Carriere, Principal of the Cowessess Residential School, that he, personally, knew the father and mother of the boy in question and that they both died within recent years. Their names were Louis Allary and his wife Alexandra St. Pierre and they were both half-breeds. The boy in question, Father Carriere states, was adopted by Alex Peepetch about two years ago.

I might mention, in this connection, that I would interview Peepetch and the boy personally if possible, but they are living on the Little Bone Reserve and it is impossible to reach that point at the present time without a long train journey. However, the circumstances of this case are practically the same as in the case of Celina and Harry Allary, two other adopted children of Alex Peepetch, who were admitted to the Qu'Appelle school under authority of Department letter number 114-0-10 dated 26th June, 1938. The boy for whom application is now made is no doubt a half-breed living the Indian mode of life on an Indian Reserve, and would therefore appear to be eligible for admission as a grant-earning pupil.

In my opinion, the only unsatisfactory feature of these cases is the fact that half-breed children who should be depending upon the Provincial Government for their education can be adopted by an Indian and with a little encouragement from church authorities, can become a charge upon the Federal Government for their education.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 23rd instant, No. 114-0-10, in connection with the application for admission of Bill Allary to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, I beg to say that I had a conversation with Alex Peepeetch and his wife recently, also other relatives of the family and the only information I was able to obtain was to the effect that this boy's step-father is still living, but his address is unknown. Apparently the step-father has never had much to do with the boy since the boy's mother died and the boy has been wandering about from place to place, often at Alex Peepeetch's, but as often at other homes and the actual adoption took place only last fall before the boy was placed in the Qu'Appelle School. Other relatives of the family say that the mother of the boy asked for Alex Peepeetch and wife to look after the boy when she was dying and, outside of this, there was no adoption.

I asked Alex Peepeetch and wife whether anyone made any suggestion of adoption and placing of this boy in school. His reply was to the effect that Father Leonard advised him to do it, but I would not place much confidence in Peepeetch's word. He is the type of Indian who might, on being asked the same question to-morrow, deny having made the statement.

Your obedient servant,

J.F.H. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant No. 114-0-10, informing me that a boy named Bill Allary, aged thirteen years, was placed in the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School a few months ago. You state that he is a son of the late Louis Allary and the late Alexandra St. Pierre, both of whom were half-breeds.

I may say that I knew the parents of this boy very well, and he is no more entitled to be in the Qu'Appelle School than any white boy in the district.

I note you state that reports received from Mr. Agent Ostrander indicate that it is doubtful if this boy could be considered a ward of the Department. The question is, why was he admitted to the school? If the Principal of this institution had paid any attention whatever to the regulations of the Department he would not have been admitted. As long as the Department treat the matter of halfbreed children in our schools as lightly as they do we will not get anywhere. I should like to have the money that is spent in our schools on halfbreed children, who, when they leave school take the status of white citizens; this money would go a long way in feeding destitute Indians.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I have not been successful in getting much satisfaction when I have brought similar cases to the attention of the Department. These children should not be admitted to our schools under any consideration, and nothing short of strict instructions to the Indian Agents will bring this about.

I am taking the matter of this boy up with the Department of Neglected Children, but it is difficult to get children transferred to the care of that Department once they have been admitted to our schools. I have had similar cases to deal with in the past, and this has been my experience.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir,

With further reference to your 306-11B of October 13th, last, enclosing copy of a letter received by you from the Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the question of the auspices under which the Stevenson children should be educated has been receiving very careful consideration by the Department.

While it is agreed that both Stevenson and his wife are Protestants, I may advise you that two older girls of this family were admitted to the Qu'Appelle Residential School in 1924 and remained there for several years. In the meantime, three boys had been placed in the File Hills Residential School.

Mr. Agent Davis was asked to interview the parents and he replies, in part, as follows:

"I have interviewed the parents of these children and the mother gives as her reason for wanting them placed in the Qu'Appelle School is that, as she is blind, she would like the children close to home.

"They also state that the two older girls are Roman Catholics and the family are divided in religion in any case and, rather than not have the girls put in the Qu'Appelle School, they would place the boys there also."

It appears from the above that the parents are very insistent that their two girls should be placed in the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. However, the Department is not prepared to accede to this request at the present time and, for your information, I enclose copy of a letter which is being directed to Mr. Agent Davis.

You may inform Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School, regarding the Department's action.

Ottawa, February 3rd, 1934.

Reverend Sir,

I desire to refer to your letter of November 15th, last, with further reference to your request for the admission of Florence and Nora Stevenson to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. The Department is aware that two older girls of this family were admitted to the Qu'Appelle Residential School in 1924, but it was not intended at that time that their admission was to form a precedent. It is the intention of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act that children of Roman Catholic parents should be educated under Roman Catholic auspices and children of Protestant parents under Protestant auspices.

It is definitely reported to the Department that Thomas Stevenson, father of these two girls, and his father before him were Protestants. Stevenson's wife also comes from a Protestant family. Three boys of this family have been educated in the File Hills Residential School and two of them are still in that school.

As a general rule, the Department considers that it is in the best interests of all parties concerned to comply with the intention of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act and, with this in mind, the Department feels that the Stevenson children should be educated under Protestant auspices. It is noted from your letter that you state that both parents desire their two girls educated in the Qu'Appelle School. However, the Department is not prepared to accede to their wishes at the present time.

The two girls should be returned to their parents and Mr. Agent Davis is being informed that the Department will not approve of their admission to any Indian residential school during the next six months. At the end of that time, the matter will again be considered.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to refer you to previous correspondence with reference to your request for the admission of Alice Starr to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

The Department has made very careful inquiries with regard to the religious antecedents of this girl.

It appears that the father, Sidney Starr, is a Protestant, also that the deceased mother was a Protestant.

Mr. Agent Dodds further states that, during the time that Sidney Starr's first wife was alive and after she died, Sidney Starr and Cowicket lived together. Mr. Dodds states that it is equally true to say that Cowicket lived with Sidney Starr instead of Sidney Starr living with Cowicket. They have lived that way ever since Alice Starr was born. Cowicket sent his own children to the File Hills School and it would appear from this action on his part that he was recognized as a Protestant.

The Department considers that it is in the best interests of all parties concerned to adhere to the intention of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act. In view of the fact that Alice Starr's father is a Protestant, the Department believes that this girl should be educated under Protestant auspices. Under these circumstances, we are not prepared to approve of her admission to the Qu'Appelle Residential School and I should appreciate if you would have her returned to her home at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

Letter # 10743.

Dear Sir:

As requested in your letter of June 15th, No. 1-1-10, I am enclosing a list of the pupils shown on our report who are over sixteen years of age.

In a great number of cases we believe it is not in the best interest of the pupils or parents to discharge them at sixteen. There is a tendency in most Indian families to cater to the wishes of their children with the result that when pupils are discharged from school they become virtual managers of their own and at an extent of their parents' affairs. At sixteen they are not qualified for this role and may eventually become unmanageable and a problem on the reserve. We have co-operated with the different Indian Agents and have discharged pupils at sixteen when we considered their home conditions warranting it and the parents had requested their discharge; in other cases we have kept pupils up to the full age of eighteen years when we considered it in their interests to remain in school.

We are, however, attaching a separate list only of the pupils who have special reasons to remain in school, with the reasons in each case. Nearly all the others will be discharged in the September Report.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, July 9, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to pupils sixteen years of age and over who are in the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

The Deputy Superintendent General's circular of the 15th ultimo did not state that children must be discharged at sixteen years of age, but simply pointed out the requirements of the Indian Act viz., that, when children over sixteen years of age are being kept in a residential school, permission must be obtained. The Department realizes that there are often very good reasons for keeping children in residential schools after sixteen years of age, and we are prepared to consider any representations that Indian agents and principals make in this regard.

In order to carry out the requirements of the circular letter recently sent to you, you should, at the end of each academic year, forward the names of the children in the Qu'Appelle School who are sixteen years of age, and, in the case of those whom you wish to retain for a further period, you should ask permission to do so and give your reasons for making this request.

Letter # 10758.

Dear Sir:

When you wrote to us on Feb. 3rd, 1934, Letter No. 114-6-16, refusing, for the time being, admission to this school of Pilgrims and Nora Stevenson, you promised to give the matter further consideration after a period of six months. We now understand that these girls have been sent to File Hills school and that the parents have not signed the Application forms and still wish to have them sent to this school. We would like to have your definite decision in this case.

It is not our wish that section 10 [1] of the Indian Act should be entirely ignored but it would appear to us that in many cases it has been rather differently interpreted, and in these cases it has not been to our advantage. We will call your attention to the following cases so you may see that we have some grounds for this belief.

We had correspondence with the Department with reference to the children of Alex. Ackusis. (See our letters No. 10483 Jan. 5th, 1931 and No. 10487 Jan. 31st, 1931. Department replied No. 111-1-10 Jan. 14th and 21st, 1931 and Feb. 16th, 1931.) The Department decided that these children should remain at File Hills school. We can produce an affidavit from Alex. Ackusis that he is a Roman Catholic and wishes his children to remain Roman Catholics and have them sent to this school.

We have recently had a letter from James T. Ross of Griswold requesting that we take his three children, Elizabeth, Eva and Stephen, who are now attending Portage La Prairie school. Their parents are Roman Catholics. Eva was baptized May 8th, 1921, by Father Walsh, Brandon, and Stephen Oct. 10th, 1920, by Father Etienne.

We have also been informed that there is another Roman Catholic girl attending Portage La Prairie school: Agnes Myrick, born Feb. 10th, 1920, baptized myself Aug. 15th, 1920. This girl's parents are both Roman Catholics.

Still another case is that of Sydney Mandy's two children, of Piagot band, who have been sent to Gordon school about three weeks ago. The parents are both Roman Catholics and both ex-pupils of this school.

We are not asking for any privilege not covered by the Act, but we are asking that we be given equal treatment. If the Act is to be strictly followed that Protestant children be sent only to Protestant schools and Roman Catholic children to Roman Catholic schools, we cannot see any reason why our Roman Catholic children now attending Protestant schools should remain there, and if they are to remain there we cannot see any reason why the admission of the Stevenson girls to this school should be refused.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your No. 10758 of the 21st ultimo.

The admission of the two children of Alex. Nokusis to the File Hills Indian Residential School was approved in official letters of February 16, 1931. At that time, both the father and mother desired the children placed in the File Hills School. In this regard, I would refer you to official letters of January 21, 1931, and February 16, 1931. Since that time the Department does not appear to have received any statement from the father showing that he was not satisfied with his children being in the File Hills School.

When applications for admission of children to a residential school are first received, every possible consideration is given and when a decision has been finally made regarding the school in which children should be placed, it has not been the practice of the Department to transfer them.

Stephen Ross, son of James T. Ross, was admitted to the Portage la Prairie Residential School in September, 1930. The application form forwarded at that time was presumably signed by the father and stated that his religion was "United Church Of Canada." You wrote in your letter that the parents are Roman Catholics. Do you mean that they have become adherents of the Roman Catholic Church since the time Stephen Ross was sent to the Portage la Prairie School?

The last quarterly return from the Portage la Prairie Residential School does not contain the names of Elizabeth and Eva Ross. As far as the Department is aware, these children are not at that school.

The June quarterly return of the Portage la Prairie Residential School does not show the name of Agnes Myrick, nor does the June quarterly return of the Gordon's School show the names of Sydney Mandy's children, nor have applications for their admission been received by the Department since July 1st. As far as we are aware, these children are not in the Portage la Prairie School, but, in view of your letter, the Agent will be written.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 114-0-10, dated the 26th ultimo, enclosing application for the admission of Nora Ferguson of the Wood Mountain reserve to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

I am well acquainted with this family and their circumstances and consider the girl eligible for admission to the Qu'Appelle School. The father is a member of the Wood Mountain Sioux Band. The R. C. M. Police Constable has given the religion of this child as "Indian", by this he means they still hold to their aboriginal beliefs. We usually designate those who have not adopted the Christian religion as "Pagan Indians". I am returning the application herewith.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Headquarters
(1). Advertising to the above. At 12 noon this date
Father LEONARD of the Lebret Indian Department
School at Lebret, Saskatchewan called at this
Detachment office and advised that the above
named girls had run away from the Indian School
at Lebret on Sunday night the 28th instant
at 7.30 p.m.

Sub-Division
Description of these girls as follows:

ROBSON, Veronica. Age 16 years; 5ft 2"; dark
brown hair; wearing coat with fur
collar and trimmings. Home at Fort
Alexandra, Manitoba. Came to Lebret
School one week ago. Indian.

BOUBAR, Pauline. Age 16 years; 5ft 2"; dark
brown hair; wearing coat with fur
collar and trimmings. Home at Fort
Alexandra, Manitoba. Indian. Came to
Lebret School one week ago.

IRONSTAND, Agnes. Age 16 years; Indian;
5ft; dark hair; wearing coat with
fur collar and trimmings; red face;
home at Valley River, Manitoba.

PERFECTION, Clara. Age 13 years; 4ft 6";
Indian; dark hair; wearing coat with
fur trimmings; very dark complexion;
home at Yorkton, Saskatchewan.

(2). No other description available. Father
LEONARD requests that enquiries be made at
Fort Alexandra and Valley River, Manitoba and
at Yorkton, Saskatchewan. It is thought that
these girls may be walking east along the
CNR tracks. Should any information be
received Father LEONARD requests that he be
advised by telephone at the Lebret Indian School,
that the girls be held and he will make
arrangements for their return to the school.

(3). Could enquiries be made by the respective
Detachments at the points mentioned as requested?
Copy of this report forwarded direct this date to
the NCO, A/I., RCMP, Yorkton Detachment with the
request that inquiries be made at those points. A
sharp lookout will be maintained by the members of
this Detachment for the above girls and should any
information be received concerning their whereabouts
the necessary action will be taken and report submitted.

Ottawa, November 23, 1934.

Sir:

The Department has recently received an account from the railway company covering the cost of the transportation of three children to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. Tickets had been issued on receipt of a requisition from you.

The Department does not desire transport requisitions to be used for the transportation of children to or from an Indian residential school. For this purpose transportation requisitions should only be used if necessary to obtain the reduced rate, and all such transportation costs should be paid in cash and a special account forwarded to the Department.

In the case of residential schools where children are allowed home on holidays and it is necessary to provide their return transportation, the principal of the residential school concerned should supply the funds, as the Department makes arrangements with the respective principals regarding the amount which we are prepared to allow for transportation purposes.

In the case of new children going to a residential school in your Agency whose parents are unable to pay the transportation costs, you should pay same and submit an account to the Department. In the event of your not having funds for the purpose, you should apply for an accountable cheque.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I have your letter of the 21st instant, enclosing an application and certificate of health for the admission of Steven Cappo, an Indian boy five years of age, to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

Letter # 10825.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 10th instant,
No. 114-0-10, with reference to the missing "Applications
for Admission," I beg to advise that we are awaiting the
completion of the Health Certificates by Dr. Simee.
We asked him to have these forms completed before the
end of last quarter but as yet he has not done so. We
phone him every day today he has promised to have this
week. As soon as he completes the Certificates of Health
we will forward you the forms through the Indian Agent.

The reason for transferring the four pupils from
St. Philips School was because that school is at present
overcrowded, and as we recruited from those reserves before
that school was built, the parents requested that their
children be sent here. The same applies to the pupil,
from Fort Alexander School, 0989 M.A.Alexander. Fort
Alexander School has more pupils than they can accommodate
and as we also recruited on Roseau reserve and have a
sister of this girl a pupil of this school, the parents
wished her to be transferred here.

I would also request your permission to have
pupil No. 837 J.S. McArthur readmitted to this school.
We discharged him last quarter as he had not attended
school the previous year and had not returned at the end
of the quarter. However, his father has sent him back
to school as he can get along without him and he wishes
the boy to get a little more education.

Your obedient servant,

Principal.

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I am asking the Indian Agent to send this letter on to you as the matter is of great importance to me, and while I know that Mr. Booth, the Agent, is in sympathy with me and recognises the justice of what I ask, I think the matter will require to be dealt with by a higher authority.

I am a member of Pasqua Indian Reserve, No. 79 and I was at the Industrial School at Lebret for 14 years, which were 14 years of my life wasted, although I was there during the time of Father Hougenard for whom I had the highest personal regard, but then the school was not as badly run as it is now. I learned practically nothing, but I am glad to say that after I left school I had the opportunity of studying and by reading and with the assistance of others I have attained some little education and alike for improvement. I am happily married to a half-breed woman of English descent who is a good housekeeper and a good mother to our children. I am a Pagan in religion and nothing I have been able to read and study and nothing I have heard from any denomination has caused me to change. Certainly nothing urged by Roman Catholic Priests and Nuns, taking into consideration their own conduct at the same time, would cause me to adopt that religion, and I say this with due regard for the late Father Hougenard and many other worthy priests.

In spite of my being a Pagan, I have placed all my children in the Industrial School at Lebret, but I have now withdrawn my daughter Edith, aged 14, from the school, and for reasons I will give, I do not propose to let her go back, and I wish your permission to keep her away, and I will make arrangements to send her to public school or some other arrangements to educate her. The Agents however will not agree to this as they want the money the Department pays them for pupils, and will have me prosecuted by law unless you intervene on my behalf, and as one of your wards, I crave your protection.

My youngest daughter, aged 11, was at the Industrial School at Lebret and we heard she was ill. We went there on April 21st and found her very much suffering from pneumonia, but being well looked after by Dr. Simes and an I.D. nurse. Our daughter however seemed worried as well as ill and asked us to keep the Nuns and Priests out of her room as "They were telling her that she would be sacrificed unless her father accepted Christianity". She said that as soon as Dr. Simes and the nurse were away, a nun, Sister Lacroix, and a Priest, who is a stranger and whose name I could not get, would go in and tell her she was going to die for her father's sins, that he must get her father to join the catholic faith before she died, and many other things. The child was so earnest about this that my wife stayed with her as much as possible, but the moment she might be away for meals or a little sleep, this Nun would get in and worry the child, and on my wife's return, she would find her in tears greatly upset, and she would beg her mother to keep that Nun away. I told Father Leonard about this and he
promised to tell the Nun to keep away, but he did not and she kept up her terrible work in spite of all our efforts.

My wife was told that she has passed the crisis on Friday night and that she had good prospects of recovery. However, on the Monday following, her temperature had again increased and she seemed weak and ill. I said he could not understand this, but the reason was that this Nun had again got to the child and had worked upon her, worrying and frightening her and telling her that she was dying for her father's sin in not becoming a catholic, and saying, "It is his fault you must die, because your father is a Pagan." The child cried to her mother not to leave her and not to let the Nun in again, as the Nun told her she had to die. Evelyn said to her mother "The Nun will be happy when I am dead, but my little sister will cry."

I am positive that if it had not been for this Nun, my child would be alive today. When she died, they told me, "You should be glad your daughter is in Heaven praying for you to be saved from your sins."

After stating these facts, I would be grateful if the Department grant the discharge of my two children from the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

I would also like to state my appreciation of the services rendered by Dr. Simes and the Department nurse to my daughter.

Your humble ward,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter #114-0-10, dated the 9th June, 1936, I beg to submit the following report:

I visited the school on June 13th and interviewed the Principal, the Mother Superior and Sisters Lacroix and Dalgeecle.

The Principal stated that Andrew Gordon's statements are false and that the girl received the best attention possible.

Sister Lacroix only visited the girl once as Sister Dalgeecle, who is a trained nurse is in charge of the infirmary, and was on duty all day and Nurse Graham of the Indian Department was night nurse.

Sister Dalgeecle stated that the girl was not bothered in any way at all.

As Andrew Gordon who is a very outstanding Indian on this Agency, would not be able to send his children back there to finish their education as in his own mind he is convinced that statements are true, and also as he is capable of finishing educating his children outside the reserve, I would recommend that they be discharged. If not I am afraid Andrew will be a source of trouble until his children are of age,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Rev. Sir:

In answer to your letter of the 11th inst I beg to inform you that the late Alice Hornby was number 73 Peorman Band, paid on her own ticket from years 1916 to 1930 when she commuted annuity.

I understand she was first married to a man named Guinville, and later on married John La Plante. The name of John La Plante shows on the records here first at treaty in 1925 when he came along and asked for his wife's treaty money. In 1927 the woman was shown as married to John La Plante. These transactions took her out of all benefits as a treaty person except that she could still draw the annuity.

Her family by John La Plante have been trying to get admitted to various schools operated by the Department of Indian Affairs, I have refused to have anything to do with them myself as the only way they could get onto a reserve is by trespass now, the father should keep them, he is responsible for them not the Department of Indian Affairs in my opinion. I may be wrong. Last I heard of them was that they were trying to get adopted by two old people who are on the destitute list on another reserve, I do not think the Department would approve of such an adoption, the old people cannot keep themselves without assistance. However, this is all the information I have about John La Plante family.

Yours truly,

Mr. Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, Canada.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

Enclosed please find two affidavits duly signed by the parents of four children, all baptized Catholics, who were admitted to the File Hills School, but who should now be transferred to the Lebret School.

As stated above, these children were all baptized Catholics and the parents now regret having sent them to a non-Catholic school and they absolutely wish that their will in the matter of the education of their children be considered by the Department.

At the time these children were admitted to the File Hills School, a protest was lodged with the Department but we were told that the will of the parents in matters of education was supreme and had to be respected. Today, as these same parents, without any undue influence or pressure from others, have changed their minds and if the will of the father in the matter of admission to a school is the supreme rule by which the Department decides religious cases, it stands to reason that the transfer of these children to a Catholic school should be approved of.

As registration day is on the 16th instant, the parents are anxious to have their case settled by the Department for that date.

Yours very truly,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing communication from the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School with reference to the children of Alex. Nokosis. The declaration signed by Alex. Nokosis refers to four children, viz.: Maurice, Mildred, Archibald and George.

On reviewing the return from the File Hills Residential School, I can find no record of George Nokosis.

Maurice and Mildred were admitted to the File Hills Residential School in 1931. As stated in your letter, this was a contentious case and there was considerable correspondence at that time, but the admission of these two children to File Hills was finally approved.

In August, 1935, Alex. Nokosis applied for the admission of Archibald to the File Hills School. The application form submitted stated that he was Protestant.

As you are aware, it has not been our practice, in the past, to transfer children from one

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 15th instant, in which you refer to the establishment of a mink farm at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan.

I may state that Father de Bretagne, who is an unusually active and capable Principal, is making provision for the establishment of a small mink farm at his school, in the hope that this will add to the attractiveness and worthwhileness of his educational programme. In an interview with Father de Bretagne a few weeks ago, he expressed the view that a little training in domestic fur farming should prove of great value to Indian pupils upon their return to the Indian reserves.

Father Plourde, of Winnipeg, discussed the desirability of such a farm with the officials here a few months ago. Of course, no objection whatever was raised to the proposal. This farm, however, will be established by the Principal and maintained by him without any additional cost to the Government. I would suppose that it is his intention to establish the farm and purchase the foundation stock out of the per capita grant allowances or out of any profits that may have accrued to him as the result of his farm operations. In any event, we are making no contribution whatever

School To Help Start Fur Farms for Indians

(Special Despatch)

LEBRET, Sask., Oct. 17.—Fr. M. de Bretagne, O.M.I., Lebret Indian school principal, has started mink farming in connection with the school. This is considered the forerunner of an industry which will be expanded so that will assist them in becoming self-supporting. Fr. de Bretagne is engaged in a project to cage 40 nutria, Quebec mink, in a coulee, between the school and the Seymore farm. This will be foundation stock, and other schools will later start mink farming. Upon success of this venture will depend to what extent Indian schools and Indians will continue in fur-farming.

Hon. T. A. Crean, minister of the interior from Ottawa, has looked with interest on the project and believes Indians should take a natural interest in fur-farming. It is proposed later to start mink farming and later again to branch out in other fur-bearing animal raising. On account of the Indians, it is pointed out by the federal minister, know the animals through habits and their characteristics. They would be best qualified under proper supervision to raise thousands of animals every year, and supply a great part of the world demand.

Fr. de Bretagne has the distinction of being the first pioneer in the fur-farming industry among the Indians.

INDIAN SCHOOL FUR FARM OPEN

Establishment of a mink farm at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan, marks another progressive step in the vocational training of Indian children. While boys of 'teen age in areas where the livelihood of the Indians depends largely upon the game resources have for some time past been afforded opportunities for practical training in hunting and trapping, the starting of a fur farm at the Qu'Appelle School is considered the forerunner of an industry that may eventually make many of the Indians self-supporting. BINDING HISTORY OF SIX NATIONS

LONDON, Ont. (CP)—Today lonely country school-teacher and historic martyr Isabella Grant Gilkison, born in 1846, was made a Princess of Six Nations Indians in 1913 and given the name Sashawhahm, which means "One who makes a research." The first sash of honor given to a woman was presented in 1888 to Col. Gilkison, her father, long superintendent of the Indians at Brantford.

Miss Gilkison has worn it at times — red, with a blue border, interwoven with beads, three yards long. The Sash is spun, woven and dried by Indian women.
A Good Idea

An innovation in Indian vocational training is the establishment of a mink farm at the Qu'Appelle Indian residential school. It is a good idea because it is a natural and a progressive step.

What could be more reasonable than turning an Indian who is a born trapper and huntsman with an inherited knowledge of furbearing animals, into a fur farmer? Having an instinctive appreciation of the characteristics of wild life, he should be naturally interested in the problems of fur farming and should develop into an expert in the line.

This experiment will be watched with interest. It reveals the alertness of the Indian department of the Government. And when the idea is in general operation it should go one further step in making the Indian self-supporting—and happy and contented into the bargain, which is just as important.

The Principal has engaged a man who is thoroughly familiar with raising and caring for mink to take charge of this activity at the school and as a result the teen age boys will receive training which should be of very practical value to them after they leave school.

The salary of the above member of the staff will, of course, be paid by the school management from school funds and in addition they supplied all the labour required for the erection of the necessary buildings to house the mink.

They request the Department to pay for the mink (50 head --- $1200.00) and the cost of the material for the buildings amounting to $290.51.

Funds for the above purpose are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year and as I feel you will agree that this is a very desirable training to afford the boys I should appreciate receiving the approval of the Honourable the Minister to pay the accounts mentioned.

Director.

I beg to inform you that the stock of Minks at the Ranch started at our School under your auspices consists of the following number:

Originally bought from Mr. M. Arkins-Winnipeg by the Indian Affairs Branch as a foundation stock:

Number of males .....15
- females .....25

Since November we have to sustain the following losses:
Jan. 1-39 1 male cause determined by Veterinarian
- 16-39 2M.38 acidosis
- 16-39 1 male - penis enlargement
- 7M.38
Febr. 3-39 1 male - acidosis
- 5M.38
- 5-39 1 male 10M.38 do-
- 7 1 - 12M.38 do-
- 8 1 - 1 M.38 do-
- 8 1 - 6 M.38 do-
- 8 1 - 4 M.38 do-
- 9 1 - 9 M.38 do-

9 total were so lost by death.

Since that date we have numerous births increasing our stock by an average guessed number of 110. The exact number of them will be reported as soon as we will know it. For the time being it is impossible to disturb the mothers to secure a more accurate enquiry.

As you might notice, these 9 minks that died this spring practically died from the same disease the origin of which has to be blamed from a wrong way of nutrition. With the help of Veterinarians in that line we detected it and changed accordingly. The manager of the ranch cannot, as assured me specialist in the matter, be too much blamed because there is always a certain amount of experience to acquire and we are always at the mercy of disease easily spread among animals in captivity.
Moreover these animals that died were all male. So the school took the means to replace them in a way that the consequences of these deaths would not cause any prejudice in the breeding of the females. It was a question of time, not a day could be lost, the time in which these deaths occurred being the breeding season. We did not want call for any help from you who had been already so generous to us in paying the original stock. Consequently we secure ELEVEN proven breeders from Winnipeg. THE LIVE STOCK OF MINKS in the ranch at the time of the visit of Mr. T.G. Willis was not 46, but 50 less 9 what makes 41 plus 11 what makes 52 if we figure these eleven males, lent then by Mr. Arkins.

I beg to report that Mr. T.G. Willis asked the manager of the ranch how many minks he was taking care, but put that question without seeming to put any other importance in his questions than the curiosity's sake. He never put to me any question and he probably never got that answer of 46 from the manager.

If you never got any report from us about the ranch it was because you did not determine any special date at which you wish to have this report made up and we were waiting for the results of the increase by births to do it. I intended as well to show you the cost of upkeep and the expectation this experiment could afford for the settlement of our graduates on their reserves.

We have sold the pelts of these dead males but they have not yielded much because they came from dead animals and because it was no more the season of pelting.

I am at your disposal to give you any more information and wish to tell you that in spite of the many difficulties encountered in the perpetual improvement of our School, I am always ready to cooperate with the Department for the betterment in the education of our children.

I remain yours very obediently,

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

I am forwarding herewith letter for your signature to the auditor General in reply to his inquiry respecting a decrease in the number of mink at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School farm.

I cannot help feeling that the Auditor General's request for an explanation in this matter has entailed a considerable amount of unnecessary work on the part of the already fully occupied staff of the Training Division. I do not presume to dispute the right of the Auditor General to request such explanations. I would point out, however, that the Indian Affairs Branch makes periodic returns of many thousands of head of livestock of different varieties throughout the country. Fluctuations large and small occur from day to day in their numbers. It would be a serious matter to us if we were called upon to give an explanation of every increase or decrease which naturally occurs in the ordinary course of stock breeding.

Director.

May 29th 1939

Dear Sir,

In connection with the Mink Ranch established at our School, I wish to inform you that some decision should be taken henceforth about the future of this new Branch attached to our School.

Experience had proved us that the first year is a costly one for the upkeep of the ranch and would bring only a deficit for the School even if we are authorized to sell pelts from the pelting kits or adults after selection made for the increase of the livestock. The School should be as least partly reimbursed for these expenses from the natural increase of the livestock.

Now, if we remember that the primary aim of that institution is to help and cooperate with the Department in the education of our children as well as the success of them when they become ex-graduate, we have to consider that this institution of the ranch should be detached from the School and made self-sustaining without however breaking all bonds that necessarily have to link them together.

The training of children (I say children and not students because they are, the Department should always remember it, children in the full strength of the word, leaving us when they just start to learn a little about work and moral education really start) in that particular branch should require 5 years. At the age of sixteen they cannot be trusted for keeping such a delicate stock on their own name. Moreover the bad habits prevailing amongst most of our Indians in Saskatchewan of the South, living nomadically in summer and spending some good time at the Regina Exhibition and local picnics, cannot allow the waste of such a precious source of revenue. Very few would be able to keep a very little number of these animals at home. This source of activity and probable source of income has to be put in a community business and with a good manager at the head until they show initiative and consistency enough to be trusted themselves. For the time being a white man alone can do it for that management. These people need bread to live and especially when young need to be taught how one has to manage his own money to secure a more certain and more plenty source of it.

Who will give them that bread when starting a business that will yield only 2 or 3 years after?
A residential School only can do it when equipped like ours with people ready to sacrifice something of their time and money. Nothing on the Reserve, where Officials of the Department have already enough to do for the most essentials of the very life itself of their wards, can be apparently expected except if the Department is ready to supply what required... and God knows how far it might go when Indians expect that the "Government" is behind.

This is my point of view in which I might be wrong. I do not want of course say that the Department is not capable of fulfilling its duties, but I think that an experience of this kind should have a certain "loose string" to prove that this particular industry is available for our ex-graduates.

Another point, that has to be brought up now, is to ask you what the Department expects from the School in return for the investment made by the Minister in the purchase of the foundation livestock and of a good part of the material used in the erection of the buildings? I suppose that it is only the help to start and occupy the youngsters fit to that work.

Many of our boys will pass through that training or help in the work on the ranch and be recognized as unfit. This takes the time of a man to supervise and instruct them. That man has to be well paid if we want him interested in that kind of occupation. Shall the School pay all expenditures and never see any revenue? Or would it not be more convenient to entrust that manager of the whole business in abandoning him the whole thing and exacting from him a bond sufficient to cover the School and by the way the Department, which both have contributed to the building of the present livestock?

I think advisable to settle so during the course of next Fall, with the charge of course for that man to continue to draw from the School or amongst our ex-graduates his help for giving these Boys the necessary training. He should be exacted of course to take care of that ranch in the same way as he does actually and provide after the three years training either money for the establishment of the graduate from his course of training or rather some tries to start with, or a partnership in the ranch, as will be decided by the Department and the Principal.

I feel like offering the Department that if a Boy after his 16th year of age would be authorized to come back to the School for that training and the Department grants to the School on the behalf of that Boy a grant of the same amount as the one paid for the other children, the School will keep them and continue their education and be able to save enough from that grant to endow the said Boy when settling up.
Not more than a few could be taken at the time, but I think that it will be the only way to settle for them the problem of self-sustaining life, and with an easy way for the Department to find a source of funds for it.

I am rather sorry to have been so long and wish to have made the matter clear enough to be understood.

Hoping to hear soon from you in a way that a settlement of that question could be foreseen before holidays, I remain

Yours very obedient servant,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I had a long talk yesterday with Father M. de Bretagne on the mink ranch which he has, with your generous help, established in connection with the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

This new school activity is still groping for light and it will likely be a few years before the right methods of operation have been evolved. The balance sheet to date is very much unbalanced, showing a very decided unfavourable condition. The sale of pelts next November should help to defray some of the expenses incurred within the last twelve months, although not near enough to balance off the cash outlay to date; and conditions should improve each year as the natural increase in the ranch population will make that possible.

The question of help is not quite as simple as we had esteemed it would be. We find that the ranch must be in the hands of a competent manager and that the management of the ranch must be a full-time job. The ranch, therefore, must be large enough to provide revenue for the salary of the manager.

The training of the oldest school boys in mink ranching involves various problems of a practical nature and there again our early conceptions have suffered greatly. We find, for instance, that only a very few select boys...
are susceptible of learning the art of mink ranching; that at the age of 16 Indian boys are too young to be accorded much confidence; that only boys who have attained their 18th year and who have otherwise given proof of stability of character should be selected for this activity.

As in practice all boys at the present time are dismissed from residential schools at the age of 16 it would seem that some exception should be made in favour of boys that the Principal might wish to train as mink ranchers, and that whilst they would be nominally on the school roll, they would be exempt from all ordinary school activities and allowed to spend all their time with the manager of the ranch. May I hope that you will give this matter your kind attention.

Yours very truly,

Dear Doctor Robertson:

You are no doubt aware that about a year ago a mink ranch was established by the Department at the Qu'Appelle Indian residential school. The cost of the mink and the building in which they are located was borne by the Department.

This experiment was undertaken after the matter had been very fully discussed with Father Plourde and referred to the Minister. The Minister expressed the view at that time that the care and feeding of fur-bearing animals might well form a part of the course of study at an Indian residential school. It was not the intention of the Minister, nor was it our intention, that these boys should establish mink ranches immediately following their graduation from school. The thought was that the care and feeding of animals would create, or be apt to create, in the Indian pupil a more kindly disposition toward the care and feeding of animals in general.

I am today in receipt of a letter from the principal in which he states that the experiment has been in no sense a success. He states it is costly, too costly to be borne by the institution, and that he has been called upon to engage a man to devote the whole of his time to the supervision of the ranch. The food of the mink, he states, is also very costly in that particular section of Saskatchewan.

It is my personal opinion that a mistake was made at the outset in the purchase of so many mink. In the light of the experience we have had it would have been much better if the Church authorities had purchased two or three pairs of mink rather than fifty. However, in

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
most things it is comparatively easy to be wise afterwards. I am anxious that you should visit the Qu'Appelle school at your earliest convenience and discuss with the Principal the best ways and means of disposing of these mink at a price that will not involve too great a financial loss to the Department. The suggestion made by the Principal that these mink should be transferred to other schools or to Indians is wholly unsatisfactory to the Department. If the Principal of the Qu'Appelle school, having received these mink without cost, is unable to operate a ranch profitably then it is simply absurd to ask other schools or other Indians to take up mink ranching in the hope that it will prove a success. The mink purchased by the Department should be sold to the best possible advantage and the money returned to the Department. The increase that has taken place might be disposed of by the school and the money received given to the school to compensate the Principal for any loss he has sustained in the operation of the ranch.

I regret very much indeed that this experiment has proved to be so unsuccessful. I know that the news of its failure will be a source of great disappointment to the Minister. I am gradually being forced to the conclusion that our residential schools, with one or two exceptions, are not equipped to undertake with any hope of success projects other than the elementary instruction of Indian boys and girls in reading, writing and arithmetic. You are more familiar than I am with their farming operations. The auditor's report suggests that these operations, except in the case of one or two schools, are in no sense profitable. The Principal of the Qu'Appelle school is, in my judgment, one of the ablest Principals we have anywhere in the Dominion and if he cannot make a success of a project such as mink ranching the outlook at the other schools is in no sense encouraging.

Yours truly,
