Dear Reverend Father:

In answer to your letter of the 16th instant, I have carefully read the quotation you made about Mr. Hoey's letter and following the remarks therein made, I wish to call the attention of the Department on the following observations.

All the courses of training referred to were always taught in our school, in as much as circumstances allowed us to do so; for the girls, sewing, crochet work, the tailoring of their own dresses were always in favor, and the proof might be found in the fact that we always obtain for them a great number of prizes at the Provincial Exhibitions.

Aside of this they are good helpers in the housekeeping and they are a big help in the kitchen, the laundry and the different up-keep of the house. Here they are very active and the neat appearance of the school is in great part due to the splendid direction given by the Sisters, very devoted and very particular about that kind of work.

It is now true that the finishing touches making more thorough that training would be improved by the center of Domestic Science which we are actively considering and for which plans have already been made, but in as much as the many managements of a house of this scale allows me to do so.

The graduates of our school, without the pretention of becoming white women, have however in the past already improved considerably the up-keep of their own homes especially when these youngsters have been encouraged by local officials. The unhappy circum-
Father Plourde

2 September 20th

stances very often must have prevented these officials from giving to these people the means of starting on a good footing and this was probably the cause of the falling back of some girls into their rather primitive state.

As in every enterprise, we have to figure with a certain number of "second" products but our work of civilizing these people is a work of generations.

Now for the boys, a very good training was always given in the care of live-stock and agriculture. It is true that we might contemplate some means of giving them more initiative and enthusiasm by interesting directly the boys and girls in the raising of calves, chickens and maybe individual garden plots but here we are facing a big difficulty which arises from the fact that the children need a contact with the home called holidays, during which time they will abandon the garden work and the fruit of their efforts will be lost.

The results obtained in the past have not to be altogether overlooked. Moreover the first bad impression given by the sight of many failures in different reserves on difficult cases must be analysed before jumping too early to the conclusion that Residential School graduates would have failed on account of a too ineffective training.

We do not think that the old missionary had thoroughly expected to transform the Indian into a white man and if criticism could find room in this new field of observation, we realize that justice should be given to their efforts and very often their self-sacrificed applied to their compulsory transformation of these people, formerly nomads into settlers animated by ideals of comfort in life and a christian code of morals.

The ideal crowning of our course of training is the settlement of our boys and girls on a little farm where they will receive encouragement, substantial help and this in a new place in as much as possible located away from the parents. The colony near File Hills has given proof in the past of real success when well supervised and intelligently managed in a period of prosperity. Indian families successful in their agricultural projects here were mostly produced by Residential Schools where habits of discipline were given them.

The Qu'Appelle Indian School has produced in the past Carpenters and Blacksmiths who now-a-days, sometimes, do not put in practice their trade for reasons that do not depend on actual Principals or missionaries.

I repeat that we always have to figure with the natural incli-
nation of Indians to go back to their nomadic life rather than to be under the regular life of the white man.

There is no room in Canada for Indians living like their ancestors, and to my knowledge, the Catholic missionaries have always attempted to adapt them to the conditions that will surround them in the future. It is always a hard task for them because they have to struggle against the natural tendency of human beings to take the most easy way to reach their end.

To conclude, I must assure the Department that, in my rather important school, I intend to work in close cooperation with the Branch of Welfare and Training of our Department, and adapt our teaching to their practical aims. I will try to use all means dictated by my past experience to conduct these children in the direction pointed out by Mr. Hoey. I have done my best to keep healthy and even, to often improve the health of these children. We try to make them enjoy that life of discipline by games and sports.

When occasionally we have the chance of keeping some big boys after 16 years of age, we give them the chance of training in elementary work of carpentry and blacksmithing. The conclusion of the experience of the past seems to make us avoid shoemaking and tailoring for the boys, as well as spinning and weaving for the girls because of competitive facilities in low prices for the same kind of goods coming from manufacturing centers.

The only future of our people stands in the settling of our boys and girls, kept away from their family in colonies of small self-sustaining farms, where the first effort of education given in school will be continued by intelligent and devoted officials.

But the sojourn in Residential Schools for youngsters who leave at the brim of their 16 years in very beneficial to them and far more effective than in the Day School where attendance is almost never regular, and will certainly be improved by a practical training crowning their education if made in the way indicated by Mr. Hoey, especially if we have a chance to do it in the conditions enumerated above.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

M. de Bretagne, O.M.I.,
Principal.
Dear Sir,

Re: Yours 114-C-11 Aug. 24th and 109-1-5 June 7th

Kindly allow me to make different remarks about your state of mind concerning this Mink ranch business as well as the judgment you thought necessary to pass on Residential Schools in your letter to Dr. Robertson. I wish indeed to defend myself because I consider that our Mink ranch was in some sense a success. If we consider the ranching point of view and the average crop in other ranches it was a success. An average of three kits is a success. That you chose the point of view of teaching our pupils the care and feeding of fur-bearing animals, as well as creating interest and a more kindly disposition toward the care and feeding of animals in general as you mentioned in your letters, here yet we ascertain that we had a success too. The only point left to be considered is the financial loss involved to the Department.

Nobody could say what will be the price of these pelts or breeders now that the war broke out, but it was no doubt that no loss would have had to be involved to the Department without this last circumstance but it would have been a loss for the School to have undertaken this experiment because it is a fact recognized by all ranchers that to manage a self-sustaining ranch one has to get the greatest possible pelt value of mink. Father Plourde took advice from prominent Manitoban ranchers who told him so, and if, as you think, we would have been wiser in purchasing some three pairs of mink rather than fifty, I do not see why now it is (as you said) absurd to transfer to other Schools or Indians such a small number to constitute so many experiments on a smaller scale than ours.

The country and individuals where I had proposed the Department to transfer the original stock of our foundation would have been I think a better way of disposing of these mink than to declare our trial a failure. The great cause of our worries lies in the too great cost of food in our part of Saskatchewan, a fact that I had more or less considered before we started but that was however one of my intimate reasons why I reluctantly accepted to make that experiment and secondly because, as I have mentioned above, to have this business profitable or at least self-sustaining, I needed to hire an extra full time hand who would take care of a great number of mink.

The conclusion seems to be that personally I had realized that in our conditions we would never make the ranch much profitable and even probably compel me to operate it at a loss. So I have submitted to you a scheme by which it seemed to me that the Department would have been able to continue the experiment in a wiser manner. In doing so I had in mind your remark expressed on page 2, letter 109-1-5, saying "If it cannot be made self-supporting, serious consideration will have to be given to the disposal of the mink."

I had accepted the eventuality of losing money in the operation of a mink ranch that in our conditions proved to be impossible to manage otherwise; I had advised the Department in a way that it would be possible to attempt an experiment in the sense that yourself by chance think that we should have started; I think wise yet now to dare to call again your attention upon this last proposition and see if even now after that state of war of our nation, it would not be advisable to contemplate another scheme for the disposal of our original stock than to declare...
ourselves vanquished. It would certainly be less humiliating than to avow to the Minister a supposed failure.

In the example illustrating my comparison in my letter of Aug. 17th, I had pointed out to you the possibility of finding places where our Schools and Indians could keep mink at a very low cost. Experiment on a small scale could be undertaken there without much difficulty it seems to me.

When Dr Robertson would be back from his holidays I will discuss the matter with him according to your wishes, but formerly I would wish to have your opinion again on that matter.

Now, with all the respect that I owe you, and without prejudice for the kind dispositions you never failed to show me, I have to tell you that the remarks you thought necessary to pass on our Schools in your letter to Dr Robertson are in my point of view the conclusion of a premature judgment.

As you seem to give here a strong argument to Dr Robertson against Schools for which he has already many prejudices, I think that you will not object that I personally interfere in the discussion to put my word.

You conclude that the Residential Schools are generally not equipped to "undertake with any hope of success projects other than the elementary instruction of Indian boys and girls in reading, writing and arithmetic," that "their farming operations are generally in no sense profitable."

These two statements are no doubt preposterous for the following reasons:

1. Would it be for most of the reserves' expectation that the residential schools would provide to the children, that the department according to the Indian Act is supposed to send to school, these elements of instruction it would already be a success if compared with the results obtained in some reserves by the day school. If I mention this comparison it is because that argumentation directs exclusively to the choice between these two kinds of school. Many reserves and the nomadic life of many Indians do not leave any margin for another choice. If we are interested in the welfare of Indians we have to realize that the basis of life is education, a word that means far more than a mere teaching of reading and speaking a language. Your special Branch being welfare & training there is no doubt that you wish to see this purpose executed. It had been realized in the past in no other way was left to educate the future of the Indians for the betterment of the race than to take the children from their surroundings and in spite of many difficulties try to change what had to be changed. Owing to the fact that in taking their country we were changing their races we were bound to exterminate them or to adapt them to new circumstances. It would be too long to make you understand that assimilation has only that purpose in mind, because the betterment of the new life of the Indian was at the same time doing a parallel result in their soul. It might seem to a newcomer into that work that the result was not equal to what could be expected and that apparently mistakes were made in that line, but experience will teach him that if it's good to be sometimes progressive, it is dangerous to be too premature in one's judgment. That kind of work is a slow work and a work of generations and sometimes of assimilation. For your own edification may I be permitted to refer you to a copy of a letter sent a year ago to P. Plourde. In it you will see what we consider to have done on behalf of preparation of our children to their future life in the reserves.

2. It is a fact that most of the farms owned by White farmers did not bring much profit. Today after the economic problems of the nation farmers are becoming slowly but surely proletarians whose losses are absorbed by the Commonwealth. And when these farms are rented, they often do not bring back any yield to their owner because in many cases of them last years, when they were not well situated they were given only to their manager a profit comparable to simple wages, when they had not to be sold for taxes to no buyer... Now farm operated by Residential school is not there for the mere purpose of bringing profit. It is there as was my Mink ranch for the purpose of teaching the children habits of working, ways of doing it etc... The Auditor's report cannot always show the good and profitable
side of the School farming operation. For instance the value of the by-products of the farm that help for reducing the cost of food etc...

-3- If the Indian Act would be effectively put in force in details that would uproot some bad habits of the Indian wards, and if some change would be made to prevent bad conduct in the wardlock, there is no doubt that the post-scholar problems would be solved by the very fact that discipline and morality would exist in the families where our children are supposed to go back. This problem is not the problem of the residential schools and consequently could not be blamed to not adapting themselves to the future surroundings of their graduates. But however here is arising the question: Shall we attempt to better the Indian problem or shall we be satisfied with half-measures and blame indiscriminately those who devote themselves with encouraging results (for those who have the time to wait) to the welfare and training of the Indian Youth?

Elementary instruction, better knowledge of their duties and obligations, better health, knowledge of discipline in as much as their discharge age allows them to have, knowledge in some art as drawing, music etc., knowledge for girls of housekeeping science and for boys of good habits of working.... all this for children leaving at the brim of their youth. Such is a gross enumeration of quite a change in children taken from the wilderness and they constitute quite an asset for those in charge of continuing that work in the time of their whole life, since the organization of the Indians' life is the share of the Department in hands of whom is trusted the care of the Queen's wards.

Yours obediently,

Rev. M.de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

Ottawa, September 14, 1938.

Dear Father de Bretagne:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, in which you ask the Department to reconsider the desirability of distributing the mink now at your school to a number of other residential schools in the prairie provinces.

A few weeks ago I received a request from Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, province of Manitoba, for the establishment of a number of mink ranches at residential schools in Manitoba. This request was due, no doubt, to the pressure exercised upon the Inspector by mink ranch owners in Manitoba, who were anxious to dispose of mink at a good price for breeding stock. I intimated to Inspector Hamilton that we had at Lebret a number of mink that we were anxious to dispose of, to the greatest possible advantage. I did state, however, that in my judgment it would be almost impossible to make a success of a mink ranch at a residential school. I take the position that the Lebret school is one of the most efficient, if not the most efficient, in the Dominion, and, if the mink ranch under the direct personal supervision of yourself could not be operated successfully at the institution, there is little chance of it being a success at other schools. However, I would have no serious objection to the transfer of a few of the mink to one or two residential schools in the prairie provinces that might be selected by Dr. Robertson and Inspector Hamilton. This transfer would have to be made on the distinct understanding that the school receiving the mink

Rev. M. de Bretagne, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.
would become responsible for the construction of the pens and any other incidental expenses that might arise. In view of the war conditions now confronting us, there is no money in this Department at the present time, nor is there likely to be any in the immediate future, for the promotion of such projects.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to Dr. Robertson.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Regina, Sask., Sept. 26, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Reference your 114-0-11 of August 24.

I regret to report that, owing to recent work as well as to the fact that for a couple of weeks I wasn't very well and able to cover as much ground as I should have, I did not get an opportunity to visit the Lebret School with reference to Mink until yesterday when I discussed the matter fully with Father de Bretagne. The Principal has gone to a great deal of trouble and to considerable expense in fitting out and establishing this Mink Ranch. His increase has been equalized to the records of the best commercial ranches. Consequently he has demonstrated that Mink Farming can be carried on successfully under his personal supervision. It isn't through any fault of his that the project has not proved a financial success but, due to the fact that he has to have a man especially for that purpose and the high cost of food.

I have paid considerable attention to Fur Farming as I have a number of friends who have been engaged in it for years both in the West and in the East. It is a business that requires a great deal of study and strict personal attention to make it a financial success under present conditions. Only recently I was talking to a friend of mine from Lloydminster who has been conducting a Fur Farm of both Fox and Mink for some years and they informed me that it is only by giving his strict personal attention and watching all expenditures very carefully that they are able to make a profit, they also state that with good stock and the closest

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.
supervision their profit is not more than $5.00 a piece, at present prices.

In considering what action should be taken with regard to these Mink, I think the first problem we have to consider is, will the ultimate benefit to the Indian warrant the expenditures necessary to continue the Ranch, personally I do not believe it will as stated before Fur Farming demands constant care and attention. We find it very difficult to get the Indian to milk cattle, they do not want to be tied down. We might possibly find an Indian here and there who would do this, but, that the few successes would not compensate for the expenditure in the great number of failures we would have, I am of the opinion that we should confine our efforts in Fur Farming to Beaver and Rats. These do not require constant supervision, they rustle for themselves and we have found that where a Band has Rats or Beavers on their Reserves they will protect them each member becoming a Game Guardian to see that other members of the Band do not destroy them.

With regard to transferring a number of these Minks to other schools at points where food would be cheaper, I entirely disagree as these schools would be in the North where we have very little supervision of the Indian except right at the School and to operate a Ranch at a School for the teaching of these Indians Fur Farming, with the establishing of them in that business after they left school would, in my opinion, simply be a waste of money. The Indian of the North moves around much more than the Indian of the South, they would not be tied down continually in one place consequently, would not give the attention necessary. I am strongly convinced that any efforts that are made to get the Indian to take up Fur Farming should be made in our Southern districts where the Indian no longer traps and has more or less accustomed himself to staying at home. I am also convinced that the time is not yet ripe to do this in view of these circumstances, the fact that we are now at war will, no doubt, greatly reduce the present price of fur, I do not believe that we would be warranted in making the expenditure necessary to continue this Ranch at Lebret and if we cannot hope to make a success of it there with, I think, the ablest and most competent Principal in the Dominion of Canada, I fail to see how we could make a success of it elsewhere. I have talked this matter over with Father de Bretagne and, I think, he is of the same opinion as myself, that we should as soon as the furs prime, pelt the stock on hand and close the Ranch unless in the meantime we should be able to find
buyers for them which is very improbable as I do not think anyone will go into Mink, or increase their stock by purchasing while this war is on.

I did not discuss with Father Bretagne the matter of allowing him the increase for the purpose of recuperating his personal expenditures but, I think it should be done as he has devoted a great deal of time and attention as well as being out considerable money in the project.

Re your remarks that you were forced to the conclusion that our residential schools, with one or two exceptions, are not equipped to undertake with any hope of success projects other than the elementary instruction of Indian boys and girls in reading, writing and arithmetic. I am in full accord with you in the opinion. I am also strongly of the opinion that the Day Schools will do much more in the solving of our Indian problem than the Residential Schools, at the same time I am satisfied that much more can be done in our Residential Schools than is being done at present. For example at Lebret School yesterday I visited a building that they had fitted up for the purpose of instructing the girls in Domestic Science. This building is completely furnished with furniture such as any Indian could purchase. They have a cook stove, cupboards, wash tubs, wash boards, irons for heating on the stove, etc. These girls are taught how to cook, bake, wash, iron and carry on the work just as they should in their own home. They have a nice Dining Room and I had the pleasure of having lunch there yesterday, prepared and served by these girls. If this work was carried on in our other schools and the boys given the same instructions they are receiving there in Manual Training, Agriculture, etc., more of their time given to this work and less to higher education, I think the girls and boys would leave the school much better prepared for life on the Reserve than under the program now being carried on by most of our other residential schools.

If we could get a few more Principals like Father de Bretagne, I think, a great improvement could be made for the benefit of all.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, September 30, 1939.

Re: Mink ranch - Lebret School

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein. The views you express are very much in accord with my own, in respect to the operation of mink farms at Indian residential schools.

I am still of the opinion, however, that a certain amount of misunderstanding still exists in your mind and in the mind of the Principal in respect to the purpose for which this mink ranch was established. In this regard, may I again refer you to the second paragraph of my letter of August 24, 1939. The thought in establishing the ranch was the feeding and care of these animals to develop a tendency in the Indian pupil to be more kindly disposed toward animals in general. It was never our thought or intention that pupils graduating from Indian residential schools should go in extensively, if at all, for mink farming.

I am disposed to think, also, that some misunderstanding exists at Lebret with respect to the feeding of these animals. There are large mink ranches comparatively close to Ottawa, and an official of the Department, who retired a year or two ago, has been operating a successful mink ranch in the Gatineau country. I have visited a number of these ranches and the men in charge inform me that the cost of the food supply is comparatively insignificant. They smiled when I informed -

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
I informed them that horse flesh was purchased for the mink at Lebret. Most of them attributed the remark to my Irish humor and asked me how many horses mink usually killed and devoured in their natural state. In any event, I do not know that any good purpose can be served at this date in reviewing the factors that have contributed to the non-success of the project. It is not at all likely that we shall make a similar experiment at any time in the immediate future.

You are authorized to proceed with the disposal of these mink in such a manner that the loss will be kept down to the lowest possible figure. I concur in your recommendation that the increase that has taken place should be allowed the Principal for the expenditures he has already made in the operation of the ranch.

I was interested in your reference to the Model Indian Home, operated by the girls at Lebret. A number of Indian schools have adopted such homes and there is no reason whatever why the principals of other schools in Saskatchewan should not follow the example of Lebret in establishing such a home for the training of girls. In view of war conditions, of course, expenditures will have to be kept very low.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Re: Yours Dec. 19th 1939 -

I have received the correspondence you mentioned therein and beg to submit to your kind consideration that the remarks you make to Dr Robertson are in the correct sense. A mink ranch should start in a small way and operated under competent management and then could be measurably successful, if the fur business is normal.

We have overcome the drawback of the fur business at large. It was successful, our average being 5 by female. Their yield would have been extremely good because they were of a good strain.

Now, their feeding cost was lower than the one experienced on the Morley U.C Residential School. Our total cost of feed amounts to $852.63 for an initial stock of 50 mink raised to the 126 figure in Spring—amounting to 37/40 daily ration, which puts our daily ration of food to 2,264 in other words $8.24 a day—a saving of $1.24 on the Morley feeding cost of $9.00—with the same kind of food.

I intend to submit to you soon a general report on the operation of our mink ranch as soon as we will get the return on our pelts trusted to the Hudson Bay Co for sale. You will judge by yourself at the reading of the figures that we could not make any money in the bad year in which we started. We had indeed to figure with the wages of the labour employed & the management of that ranch as Inspector Scott himself is mentioning in his report, as well as some other indispensable expenditures.

With the collapse of the fur market you will easily imagine that more profitable investment of money than to bury one's scarce funds in a business that with proper management costs 2 dollars for each dollar invested and collected after the operation, could be made.

In spite of this apparent failure I take opportunity of this letter to thank you for having trusted me to experience this branch, feeling well that in reading my answer you will realize that no effort was spared by us for a success of the Minister's plan to improve our Indian self supporting problem.

Yours very obediently,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal

Dear Sir,

Re- The enclosed report - Mink Ranch

I beg to submit to you for your kind consideration the report of our expenditures for the management of our Mink ranch.

Following my letter Dec. 26th 1939, in which I drew a comparison between the cost of feed at the U.C Morley School and ours, I wish to call your attention upon the fact that our management was not successful on the point of view of profits.

As I cannot share the responsibility of that loss due in great part to the adverse conditions met with, particularly the market suddenly failing on account of the European war, I would ask you if there would not be any possibility for me to keep the proceeds of the sale in reimbursement of the loss sustained in the operation of the ranch; as you suggested to Dr Robertson in your letter dated August 24th, for the increase of the ranch.

In that letter indeed you gave order to Dr Robertson that the mink purchased by the Department had to be sold to the best advantage and the money returned to the Department, and that the increase be given to the School to compensate our loss.

Now, Dr Robertson, after his visit to our ranch authorized me on Oct. 11th to dispose of these mink. After advertising, on his advice I tried to sale some mink for breeding purpose, but customers were scarce and very cautious on account of war conditions and poor prospects for the market. Consequently I had to accept what I could secure and got for them an average price of $11.00. It looked bad, but I expected that the pelt market would yield better, especially on account of the encouraging remarks made by visitors included the Inspector appointed by the Department of Natural Resources of Saskatchewan, on the good quality of our mink.

But, it was written that our experiment was doomed to unsuccess. Winter practically did not exist in our beautiful Valley and unhappily the pelts seemed to take time to "prime".

The latest possible in December we started to
pelt in a way to arrive on time on New York market for the mid January sale, supposed to be a good one.

Here again, no chance, we yielded around $497.00 for 90 pelts, by the report of Lampson, Fraser & Ruth a good firm of Montreal to which we were directed by the Hudson Bay Co., that found our pelts of a good grade.

I wish that these explanations will show to you how hard it is for me to present such a report after so many efforts made by the Department and by the School. Like I told you already I am proud to have been chosen for that experiment but, today, I have to add that I expect some token of your appreciation in helping us by the authorization to keep the sum that will soon be into my hands.

Dear Sir,

MEMORANDUM: MR. HOEY,

In the fiscal year 1938-39 the Department gave financial assistance to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask., toward the establishment of a mink farm at that school. Expenditures were made from appropriation approximating $1600.00, being for the purchase of fifty mink $1200.00 and various other material amounting to $300.00.

You will recall that in 1939 the Auditor General, on reading the report of April 22, 1939, from our Mr. Willis, raised the question as to the number of mink then at the school. Mr. Willis had reported the number as 46. The Department wrote the Principal asking for a report on the matter and were advised that 9 mink had died and that they had replaced these by obtaining 11 male mink from Mr. Arkins.

From the correspondence on file it would appear that the experiment in mink raising has not been a financial success and that in August of 1939 it was deemed advisable to dispose of the mink on hand and to discontinue the experiment. According to the report on the file under date of February 13, 1940, from the Principal of the School, the proceeds from sales are shown as $982.51. In the audit report furnished by Mr. Willis under date of September 10, 1940, the proceeds of sales are shown as $1,111.98. It is quite possible that between the time of the report by the Principal of the school and the time of the report by Mr. Willis, further sales of pelts had increased the amount of the proceeds.

I would appreciate being advised if it is the intention of the Department to request the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Residential School to refund the amount of the proceeds to the credit of the Receiver General.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

I am sending forward herewith correspondence relating to the establishment and operation of a mink ranch at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask.

You will note that this ranch was established early in the year 1939 and that expenditures were incurred by the Department in this connection amounting to approximately $1,500. You will note also that the experiment was never wholly satisfactory. It would appear that from the outset the cost of food, particularly horse flesh, was very high and that 9 mink died early in the history of the project. Then it was learned here that the price of mink pelts had fallen approximately 50% immediately following the outbreak of the war, the Department decided to dispose of the mink, under the direction and guidance of Dr. Robertson. The mink were disposed of in due course and the question now arises as to what equitable settlement should be effected, in view of all the circumstances.

This mink ranch was established on the assumption that it would continue in operation from year to year and that the school authorities would be allowed to keep the yearly increase to compensate them for the additional expenses incurred, such as the salary of the manager of the ranch, cost of food, etc. It was agreed also that the school would distribute to a number of graduating pupils mink to the number of 50 and thus reimburse the Department for the Department's initial outlay of $1,200. Dear Sir:

The extra $45.32 was exchange on American money. If you will refer to the Principal's statement you will note that he reported a credit of $982.51, also that there is a notation stating that 90 pelts sold by the Hudson Bay Company through Lampson, Fraser, and Ruth Encorp., amounting to $497.56 were to be paid for at the end of February. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith correspondence relating to the sale and disposal of a number of mink purchased by the Department early in the year 1939, for the establishment of a mink ranch at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask. This correspondence, you will note, is self-explanatory.

The establishment of a mink ranch at the Qu'Appelle School, Lebret, Sask., and a somewhat similar ranch at the Morley Indian Residential School, Morley, Alberta, was part of a vocational program, designed to provide a practical course of training at our residential schools. The Brandon Residential School experimented at the same time in the keeping of bees and the Fort Alexander School in the breeding of goats. For a period of years, criticism was widespread that the course provided at our schools was altogether too academic and abstract and that students graduating from these institutions had not the training or equipment to enable them to return to the reserves with any hope of making a success of life.

The Lebret School was selected for this experiment, in co-operation with the church authorities. Father de Bretagne is looked upon as one of the best, if not the best, residential school principal in the Dominion. He is a man with a very practical turn of mind. The Lebret School at this date has reached a very high state of efficiency. There is nothing on file here to indicate that he was at any time against the introduction of this experiment, and I am inclined to think that he -
that he was not only willing but exceedingly anxious to secure from the Department the mink necessary for the establishment of the ranch. Mr. Christianson's statement, therefore, that Father de Bretagne was not in favour of going into the mink farming business, must be the result of incomplete or misleading information. It cannot be said, however, that the mink ranch at Lebret was at any time a success. Drought conditions in the Qu'Appelle district made it exceedingly difficult for the Principal to secure meat at a reasonable cost and it would appear that most of the carcasses had to be shipped in. In addition to this, a few of the animals died. The drastic reduction in the existing price of mink pelts, however, was the chief reason for the failure of the experiment. Had the prices remained at the pre-war level, I am disposed to think that the project would have been reasonably successful.

You will note Mr. Christianson's recommendation with respect to the disposal of the money secured by the Principal from the sale of the pelts. This recommendation appears to be supported by an excerpt from a letter written by Dr. Robertson to the Principal. The original understanding was that the school would be allowed the annual increase after so much had been distributed to graduating pupils. This understanding, of course, was based on the assumption that the ranch would be in continuous operation from year to year.

The conclusion reached by Mr. Christianson in the last paragraph of his letter of November 15 is scarcely borne out by the facts. The school has at this date a fully modern building worth at least $200 and a building that is equipped for the production of poultry. If it is considered advisable to allow the Principal to retain the proceeds of the sale, now in his possession, I recommend that this allowance be made on the understanding that the Principal will utilize the funds so released for the extension of the barn at the Lebret School. Reports reaching the Department for a number of years indicate
that this barn is too small for the steadily growing needs of the institution. The Lebret School has at this date an enrolment of 250 pupils. It will thus be seen that this is one of the largest residential schools operated by the Department.

Director.

Dear Father de Bretagne:

The Department is in receipt of a report on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, submitted by Mr. Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

This report is on the whole very encouraging. Mr. Christianson was very favourably impressed by the condition and cleanliness of the buildings; the addition that had been made to the house, the cost of which was provided from school funds; the course of study provided for the girls and he concludes by stating: "This is, no doubt, a very fine institution with a good staff. The Principal is an outstanding man and practical in all his work."

Mr. Christianson was somewhat surprised, however, to learn that very little manual training was provided for the boys in attendance at this school. It is just possible that you have not yet had time to adjust your program for the senior boys, immediately following the disposal of the mink. This project was organized, as you know, in response to a suggestion made by the Minister and was designed to encourage the boys to take an interest in the feeding and care of fur-bearing animals. In addition to this project, you had at one time a well organized Band, in which the boys took a keen and active interest. Inasmuch as the graduates of your school are likely to take part in agriculture and return to the reserves to engage in this industry, emphasis in your educational program, of course, should be placed on animal husbandry, the cultivation of the soil, subsistence gardens, etc. It has occurred to me that if the formerly occupied by the mink are still vacant, it might be worth while to experiment in the production and care of poultry. A number of the boys might be encouraged in a project of this character. In addition to this, a certain amount of carpentry work should be taught. I have in mind particularly the use and care of ordinary tools, the principles of elementary building construction, etc.

I note from the reports that have reached me on our residential and day schools in British Columbia that approximately 2 hours of each day is set apart for vocational instruction - carpentry work, boat building, blacksmithing, auto mechanics, etc.

Principal,

Dear Sir,

Re- Yours 114-0-11 Dec. 6th -

I beg to acknowledge reception of same and to thank you for the kind and encouraging remarks you made to me.

No doubt I will try to carry on the instructions and advices you gave me, but I wish to call your kind attention upon the fact that there must have been an answer to the question that Mr. Christianson made to me and that provoked a misunderstanding between us about the manual training of the Boys.

We make a lot of work around where the Boys are mostly used, sometimes alone, sometimes to accompany a member of the Staff, often the Principal himself when economy has to be put in practice and a man is for that fact unprocureable. All the big Boys have their share in the different kinds of work performed around the School, and God knows that we cannot take a rest if we wish to keep everything in order and constantly improve our buildings or repair some other. They paint, they help the carpenters in all their work, they do all the chores of the farm and of the land, they do the work of the garden that is large, they haul coal, wood, straw, hay etc... But to say that they learn a special trade (carpentry, blacksmithing etc.) we cannot say so. In the past I have done my best for it but now our Boys have left us at 16 years, and at 15 an Indian Boy is not a white Boy; moreover we need them for the different works mentioned hereabove. If one day after the War, funds are available and that I could be granted 275 pupils I would have sufficient money to engage the teacher in some of these lines and have children devoting time to learn some of these trades more efficiently.

Our stables are a place of show, not by the only beauty of the buildings that are neat, in good order and practical however, but by their outstanding appearance. There the Boys learn animal husbandry far better than they would do unhappily in some of the stables of Indian Agencies. Our animals are not abused by the children and it is obvious that their quietness is due to the good behavior of the Boys around them. Our herd is giving to our children much milk what contributes so much for their good health.

The boys work extensively to the garden, but I would wish more revenue here too from a larger pupilage in a way to find the money to pay better wages to a better gardener who would be able to teach practical gardening to the girls, who are mostly called to take care of garden on the reserves once they quit the School. With the time I expect to be able one day to start something more practical for them.

I have done nothing with the pens of the mink yet, the war with the
with the departure of 5 members of our Staff to the Army, had brought some disturbance in our plans, because I intended to take care of chickens and tame rabbits in these pens. I would resume these activities as soon as possible however within the range of our means.

Now in mentioning the Band of the School, I am afraid that you would think that we have abandoned it. Far from it our Band, in spite of the losses sustained by the War in the Staff and the annual loss of our best players, specially this year where I had to get rid of more pupils than ever on account of the regulations of the Department, is going on better than ever.

Our name is good yet and we have been to different parades last Summer for the Red Cross, in November even to Regina for the parade of the film on the Mounties of the N.W. where our Boys were very popular again. Their director Rev. F. Laviolette is very capable and devoted and we have teachers of music who cost me much money. We do not appear to any place and our little Band are the object of surprise for many Whites. We are requested to go to the Exhibition of Regina every year but we have to decline the invitation on account of the Holidays. We consider that this activity is one of our principal ones for the recreational point of view and for the education of will power as well as the developing of their taste and good manners.

I am at your disposal to put in practice any suggestion you find proper to give me and be sure that in spite of the difficulties of the War-time we do our best to keep to our School the same efficiency with reduced means than I had tried to give in the last few years of my principalship.

Yours very obediently,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

Dear Sir:

As I have not, up until now, made Monthly Reports on the Manual Training of my boys, I will at this time make a general report covering the work done up till now, and will in the future endeavor to make monthly reports.

Until October, last, the training I was able to give was very limited, as it had to be given in the classroom, where the furniture had to be protected and few boys could work at one time.

In October we were given the use of the large shop outside. Here considerable time was taken up in building a cupboard to hold our new tools received last year, as well as additional workbenches. The bigger boys did good work here in the construction of the benches.

As I have an enrolment of 33 boys, I have divided them into two groups for Manual Training. Each group goes to the shop once...
a week for half a day. While one group is in the shop, the other group works at the barn, with the chickens, or wherever there is some special work to be done which will have training benefits. We find this system to work better than to take all the boys into the shop at once, where adequate attention could not be given to all.

For quite some time at the beginning, I found the boys exceedingly slow in performing the various jobs; some are still so. Perhaps my standards are too high for them. However, they have and are improving greatly. Many are really turning out good work. What is more important, they like this Manual Training. For the greater part, I allow the boys to choose their own projects, unless I feel that what they have chosen is too difficult at the time, or sometimes we have not the material necessary. Then, often too, I assign certain jobs or articles to be made for which there is an immediate need—card tables and stools, for example. Furthermore, considerable repair jobs are done, as well as outside construction jobs.

Some of the main outside construction jobs on which the bigger boys worked...
were a Pig Barn, Haying equipment Implement Shed, Cow Barn, and Car Garage. This was done last summer. These I have listed on the report sheet although they are not objects made by a boy individually. On larger jobs several boys participate.

In choosing projects, I encourage the boys to make articles which will be useful in a household, as well as beautiful. My main object is to try to train them to improve their homes by constructing articles such as small tables, stands, cupboards, shelves, etc.

So much for woodwork. Besides this, under my supervision, these boys handle the poultry raising. Last year we received 300 hatchery chicks which we successfully raised. The cockerels were killed to provide food, leaving 142 pullets. About half of these are laying eggs throughout the winter. We are again expecting 300 chickens on March 31st.

I am also giving the boys quite a thorough training in Gardening. Last year, our school garden was a success; this year we are enlarging it, to provide...
for more canning as well as more fresh vegetables.

The majority of the boys like all these activities; better in fact than any classroom work than I can give them. However, we try to correlate the classroom work with these other activities—for example Natural Science and Gardening.

So many activities besides the regular Curriculum subjects, does not give me as much time for preparation as I might like, or rather would need, but I try to do my best under the circumstances. If my boys will carry at least part of the training home, and apply it to their lives after they leave school, to better their living conditions, I shall be satisfied and happy.

Yours faithfully,
Joseph Sherberger,
Instructor, Senior Boys.

ATTENTION MR. A. DOUCET:

Dear Mr. Doucet,

Enclosed are the reports of basic operations mastered by our students in the different activities. Would you kindly send us other forms for these monthly reports.

Your lectures at our school, during the last summer have aroused a great enthusiasm for the Manual Training among the teaching staff. Again I wish to express to you and to the Department my heartfelt thanks.

Three different instructors are employed in the Manual Training for the boys. These pupils are receiving special and more elaborate training in the kind of work in which they show more interest. The three boys to whom the Department has granted a school extension are doing well.

Willie Luziciri (16 yrs) is taking a course in mechanics and is given a special programme of studies with the following subjects: Business Fundamentals; Language; Indian Economy; Typewriting.

George Lavallee (17 yrs) has been trained in Leatherwork and is now in a position to handle the shoe-shop.

Patrick Gogginirel (17 yrs) has given all his interest in farming work. He has learned to drive the tractor.

We have a special home near the school for these three boys. An old Indian lady is staying with them to take care of the house and of their clothes. They take their meals at the school and they go to their home for the night. They greatly appreciate the freedom and the responsibility we are giving them. I consider this arrangement to be a good transition from the school life to their future life at home. They are happy, reliable and industrious.

We have not yet received confirmation of the acceptance of Mr. Doll as Instructor of Manual Training. Mr. Doll has been working for us in that position since October 15th. If he is accepted, how soon can we expect to receive this special grant towards his salary? We wish to thank you for the invoice of all the books we have ordered. The parents of our pupils are constantly demanding us to teach Mechanics to their boys. QU'APPELLE:

It will be recalled that the Qu'Appelle School was authorized to make improvements to the shop. I wish to state here that they have at present a splendid shop. It will, however, require interior decorating which they hope to be able to do before the opening of the school next September. There are three Manual Training Instructors at this school. The problem of integration is rather different when the Instructors have not been trained for this work, (one of the Instructors followed the course given by the Department last November).

This school has a good start and I hope that by next visit the improvements will be more prominent. It must be kept in mind that the shop was repaired by the pupils themselves. Greater benefits would have been obtained from this work if the Mathematics, etc had been integrated to a greater extent. It was, however, as far as it went very good training for the young people and I wish to state again that they have made a lot of their shop and encouraged a qualified teacher at this school to attend the general shop course to be given in Brandon or Winnipeg this summer.

The Manual Training students deserve commendation for the work done on their shop. This was good training for them. More planning, however, should have been done by the pupils themselves. In fact, a class discussion followed by a sketch competition would have brought into play many educational factors. The pupils plan to paint the interior of their shop this fall.

There are three Instructors employed at this school. One of these assisted at the short course given by the Department last November. The problem of integration is rather difficult when the instructors have no training for this work.

A.J. DOUGET.

Dear Sir:

We wish to thank the Indian Affairs Branch for purchase of material for enlargement of our Manual Training Shop. The plan which has been suggested is to enlarge our actual Manual Training Shop. But, now, all the members of the staff are unanimous in suggesting a more practical plan.

On account of the large number of buildings that the Indian Affairs Branch has in view throughout Canada, we presume that the Department will not consider the construction, for our school, of an auditorium or gymnasium for some years to come, notwithstanding the need for one.

Our new plan would be to build the Manual Training Shop large enough so that we could use it occasionally for Cadet Drilling, Physical Training, Band and Choir practice and finally, on certain occasions such as on Christmas and Easter, as parlour for Indian parents.

May I say, that at the present, because our parlour for the parents is only a hall of 20x22 ft., we are very often obliged to set benches in the corridors of the school and in the laundry room. This causes much inconvenience and trouble.

For all these reasons, we suggest that instead of uniting the actual workshop with the Bakery Shop, an extension be made to a building which actually serves as Club House for the senior boys and as a storeroom. This building measures 36x24 ft. In annexing to it a building of 70x56 ft., we would have a first class Manual Training Shop which could also be used for the purposes already mentioned. All the necessary benches for the Manual Training could be set around the hall and as the tools are kept in lockupboards when not in use, they would be conveniently out of the way.

The lumber for the 40x24 ft. building already approved amount to $1138.95. The additional quantity of lumber needed for the 70x56 building we propose, would amount to $1395.45 plus the new price increase now in effect.

We feel that this additional cost would prove to be a saving if we consider the services that this building would give us and the small difference in labor that it would require.
Indian Residential School

LEBRET, SASKATCHEWAN

Another advantage is that this building being closer to the school, it could be heated by the central heating system of the school.

You will find enclosed the list of the additional supplies needed and the price of same.

We sincerely hope that you will give our suggestion, your most earnest consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Father Piche:

We have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to the employment of Mr. Doll. Provided he is prepared to devote twenty-five hours per week to actual teaching and training of the pupils who will take the course, the Department is prepared to allow a salary for him.

It should be further understood that each pupil taking the course would receive a minimum of three hours per week training.

Sir,

re Lebret Industrial School

In going through the stable to inquire into the milk supply conditions, I found a pedigree bull which had been purchased from the Van Horn Farm near Selkirk. This animal has an enlarged joint with a running sore, and the Priest told me on enquiring what it was, that the animal must have been shot, but when I asked him he was not sure of that being the case. In my opinion it is a tubercular joint. I would advise that it be tested and if such disease be pronounced, that the animal be destroyed. I know that tuberculosis was among the Van Horn cattle on the Van Horn Farm. It is a matter which I think should be attended to at once.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Mr. Scott:

With reference to the matter of supplying milch cows for the Qu'Appelle Industrial School and the File Hills Boarding School, I beg to say that I have been unable to locate in this Province or in Alberta or Manitoba, the breed of cows we require. There are only two breeds that can be used either the Holstein or the Ayrshire and the nearest place that I know of that they can be purchased is in the Province of Ontario. I could pick up other breeds but from the advice I have and from what I know personally, I think it would be a mistake to depart from the breeds mentioned as the Holstein will give at least twice the quantity of milk of any Shorthorn that we might pick up, or in other words one good Holstein will give as much milk as two good Shorthorns, therefore we should use nothing but the Holstein.

My suggestion is that the Department might arrange through Doctor Ruddick of the Agricultural Department, Ottawa, to procure for us the cattle we require in the East. He no doubt has a man whom he could send out to pick up these animals. As I have said before I could get a Shorthorn breed here but it would be very inadvisable to do so as it would not be profitable. This advice I also have from the Dairy Commissioner here and from other experts on dairy cattle. The Provincial Government institutions here use dairy herds entirely for their milk supply.

Yours very truly,

W. M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner.

I beg to enclose herewith a report on
the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, which was recently
inspected by Mr. Murison.

There does not appear to be a sufficient
number of cows to supply milk for this institution.
You are aware we supplied some cows a few years ago

The horse and cow barns are good buildings. A silo has been built between the two barns. It was tried out this winter for the first time and has proven very satisfactory. The cow barn provides accommodation for 24 cows, and a calf pen. They have 23 milch cows, 1 bull, and 21 head of young stock. A shed is provided for the young stock. They should have at least 35 milch cows at an institution of this size, and in order to accommodate this number it would be necessary to extend the barn at least 30 feet. At the time of my visit they were milking 14 cows, which is not sufficient to provide milk for approximately 250 persons. They should have at least 35 in order to keep at least 20 milking steadily. I may say that the cattle are all Holsteins.
Sir:-

I have received a letter from the Provincial Government drawing attention to the Dairy Convention to be held in Prince Albert, January 29-30-31 next, and in this connection to the work of one of their Field Staff who has greatly interested himself in herd improvement work at one or two of our Indian schools, particularly at Crooked Lake and Lebret. The Field Inspector states that he has found the boys at these schools keenly interested in live stock and is anxious to see a team of Indian boy contestants in the Dairy Cattle Judging Competition this year. Father Leonard is equally enthusiastic that the boys should go to Prince Albert.

I am sure that the training which they will receive in taking part in such a contest will be of great educational value to the boys, and I wish to recommend that a team of boys be allowed to go from Lebret. I think the only expenditure in connection with the arrangement would be that of their transportation and perhaps one day's board at Prince Albert. I shall be glad if the Department will sanction and provide for the small expense which will be entailed.

EXTRACT from Inspector Hamilton's Report regarding his inspection of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School on the 7th and 8th of March, 1932.

Original on File 114-0-6.

The cow barn was clean and the 26 head of milk cows in splendid condition. The Reverend Father now has over 100 head of good Holstein cattle. He is certainly crowded for stable room and at present is renting a barn. His calves and young stock were in excellent condition and are being well fed and looked after. The Reverend Father is anxious to obtain a good herd of milk cows sufficient to supply milk and butter for the school, about 260 people, consequently more barn accommodation is necessary. The girls are given lessons in milking during the late spring and in the fall when the weather is good. I understand that the girls, on being discharged, are able to milk.

The horse barn is in good repair and was clean. The horses are in excellent condition and are receiving the best of care.

At present, they have about thirty growing pigs and during the recent months sixty fat hogs had been butchered. Six or eight brood sows are kept.

Poultry is also kept and with fair success. The proceeds from this branch are entirely consumed by the school.

Extract from Annual Report of Rev. Paul Fiche, O.M.I., Principal, Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, for fiscal year ended March 31, 1946.

Notwithstanding the many difficulties, the School is bringing progress among the Indians. The progress is noticeable from one generation to another. In judging the Indians' problems, one must never forget that the work of civilization is a work of generations. Men are not remade overnight. The process of full adjustment of a people to a civilization finds itself handicapped by centuries of traditions, ways of living, habits which are deeply rooted in the very soul. We cannot expect the Indians to have achieved a transition from the bow and arrow to the atomic age in sixty years.

We consider that it would be one of the Department's duties to establish a plan for the post-scholar aid to the school graduates. When boys and girls are dismissed at 16 years of age, they are too young to have acquired during their school years either a trade or a training which can fit them to undertake the task of earning their own living. Nowadays it is left to the parents to continue the graduates' training. Whereas many parents are not in an economical position to give this help, the graduates are left to themselves, destitute of any means towards this end. It falls the Indian Affairs Branch to provide these graduates with a follow-up system that could fit them to earn their living.

The Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School wants to experience the following plan: We have rented a farm near the school. This farm has 360 acres under cultivation. Our aim is to have the graduates who want to continue their training at school work this land under our supervision. The net profit would create a fund to help not only the graduates who would be working on the land but all those who would stay at school for a higher training. The aid to be given to each graduate when leaving could be based on the length of time he has remained in school after 16 years of age, also on his character and good behavior and his sense of responsibility.

......... These boys
These boys staying for post-school training would not be under the same regulations as the other pupils. I am satisfied with the following experience made with the three boys to whom the Department has granted, this year, a school extension: I provided them with a home near the school building. An old reliable Indian lady stays with them to take care of the house and to supervise them. They sleep there but take their meals at the school. They have a radio, books, reviews. They are given more freedom in order to develop their sense of responsibility.

The satisfaction that this system has brought this year inclines me to think that such a plan could be a solution to that difficult period of transition the graduate has to go through when leaving school:- that of a followed-up supervision at school to a total freedom at home.

Our School will always try to co-operate with the Indian Affairs Branch to the welfare of the Indians especially of the Indian children.
Mr. Philip Phelan  
Chief, Training Division,  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Ottawa, Ont.

In response to your request for additional information with respect to the purchase of a tractor at the Qu'Appelle Indian residential school, I am sending forward herewith file No. 114-0-14.

The desirability of providing additional training for graduates of this school has been under consideration for a number of years. The project now under consideration represents an attempt to provide practical instruction in agriculture for a group of boys who have reached the age of sixteen, but who have not the resources or necessary experience to undertake farming operations without careful supervision. This matter was referred to Inspector Ostrander on April 17th and you will notice his reply dated April 20, 1946. In view of all the circumstances, if a tractor can be secured at this time, I would recommend that the project be given a fair trial and that reports on its success be submitted by Inspector Ostrander from time to time.

With respect to the earload of cement requisitioned for the Fort George R.C. school, I may state that this is a small church-owned building, with an authorized pupilage of twenty and a per capita rate of $300.00. You will note that in the 1946-47 estimates there is an item of $400.00 for repairs and maintenance at this school. The project now under consideration represents an attempt to provide practical instruction in agriculture for a group of boys who have reached the age of sixteen, but who have not the resources or necessary experience to undertake farming operations without careful supervision. This matter was referred to Inspector Ostrander on April 17th and you will notice his reply dated April 20, 1946. In view of all the circumstances, if a tractor can be secured at this time, I would recommend that the project be given a fair trial and that reports on its success be submitted by Inspector Ostrander from time to time.

With respect to the earload of cement requisitioned for the Fort George R.C. school, I may state that this is a small church-owned building, with an authorized pupilage of twenty and a per capita rate of $200.00. You will note that in the 1946-47 estimates there is an item of $400.00 for repairs and maintenance at this school. The reports from our officials indicate that the basement and foundation of the building should be re-built. The proposal is to purchase the cement from this year's appropriation, on the understanding that the

... repairs will be
repairs will be undertaken by the church authorities. The item in the estimates will be insufficient to meet the total cost of the cement and a request will have to be made to Bishop Belleau to provide the additional amount required. Mr. Doucet has visited this school on a number of occasions and is anxious to have vocational courses provided for the Indian boys and girls, particularly the Indian boys, who will in all probability engage in hunting and trapping after graduation. The records indicate that we have spent little on repair work at this school since its establishment by the Bishop, and I am disposed to think the repairs now requested should be undertaken if this cement can be secured.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Paul Piché, O.M.I., of the above school, in which he expresses his great disappointment at the refusal of the Department to purchase, for his older boys and former pupils, a tractor with which to help them start farming on their reserve.

Father Piché has often mentioned his conviction that something must be done for these former pupils if we do not want to allow them to spend five or six years at least in useless seeking for jobs and in the persuation of habits which are far from being a credit to the school which had charge of their early training.

He now proposes to pay half of the purchase price of a tractor, out of missionary funds which he has been able to gather and suggests that the Department pay the other half. Furthermore, he would like, for the coming year, to be authorized by the Department to take in up to ten boys of sixteen or over that age, who are willing to continue their mechanical training in his school, on condition that the Department pay for their upkeep the ordinary per capita grant allowed for regular school pupils, and $15.00 extra, per pupil, per month. This amount of $15.00 will be placed to the credit of each boy at the end of each month, and remitted to him, in a lump sum, on his leaving the school at the end of two...
years.

Moreover, a small sum will be credited each month, so as to give each boy $500.00 when leaving the school, at the end of this two year training period. He will try to supervise the spending of this money, in the building of homes for each of these boys or in the purchase of machinery, horses or any other farm implements which he will judge useful for their start in life. He further states that he would have no objection to be guided in this work by the recommendations of the Agent or Superintendent of Indian Agencies in Regina.

In other words, his sole purpose for proposing to the Department this method of training for these boys, is to try some scheme whereby the work so ably conducted at the school will not be completely lost and the boys be given a chance to utilize their training immediately upon reentering the reserve.

Please let me know what your reaction to this offer can be, at your earliest convenience, so that I may be able to so advise the Reverend Father.

Very truly yours,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

PATHOLOGY REPORT

Patient Victor Sugar
Doctor A.B.Simes
Hospital ward Qu'Appelle

HISTORY

Age of patient 16 years
Situation of growth Heart, pericardium, lung

LABORATORY FINDINGS

The whole condition present is tubercular. There is a tubercular nodule, about the size of a fibert, in the apex of the lung, and some smaller nodules, about the size of grains of shot.

The heart, with the pericardium, is enormously enlarged, and when filled with fluid must have been the size of a football. The surface of the heart is covered with a layer of tubercular tissue, and the lining of the pericardial sac also shows a layer of tubercular tissue. Sections of this tissue are typically tubercular, and many tubercle bacilli were found in stained smears. Around the trachea and its bifurcation, and the large vessels, are many tubercular glands.

The pleura also shows a tubercular exudate.

I have never before seen a heart and pericardium so markedly involved as this specimen.

Signed, Frances G. McGill

We got the bale and the sewing machine out from Yorkton last Saturday. While we have not yet tested the machine, I am sure that it is all that could be desired. The ladies here think it a splendid machine.

Will you convey to the Toronto ladies our very hearty thanks for this splendid supplementary bale of clothing.

I have also to report that measles of a very mild type has broken out in School. So far only one girl has taken it. The doctor happened to be on the Reserve at the time. He and Mr. Jones decided that the best thing to do was for the children to go home at once, with the hope that we could have the family to come back without its spreading further. This has been done. If any child who has gone home gives signs of taking the measles it is to be brought back to the School at once and nursed here.

We hope there may be no more cases, and that by the New Year we may have them all back again. We are having very severe weather, and the school building is very cold. Round Lake Boarding School

Situation:
This school is beautifully situated at the East end of Round Lake and on the North side of the River, it is in the Qu'Appelle Valley, 70 miles East of Fort Qu'Appelle, and in the Crooked Lake Agency, Treaty Number 44. The P.O. Address of the school is Whitewood, Alta., N.W.T.

Religion:
It is a Presbyterian School conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church.

Buildings:
These consist of two separate buildings of wood and stone. One contains school rooms, class rooms, boys sleeping rooms and teachers rooms. It is well ventilated and heated by furnaces. The other building contains principal rooms, kitchen, parlor, dining rooms, girls dormitories, etc. Room, etc. The last mentioned building is also well ventilated and heated by furnace. Besides these there is also a barn 24 x 40 ft with stone stable under, with room for 12 cows or 6 horses. There is also a workshop and an implement shed.

There is a good well from which a supply of pure water can always be obtained and for fire protection.
Buildings (contd)

is two chemical engines and also pails which are kept filled with water and stationed at convenient places throughout the building.

History of School

The Boarding School at Round Lake was first opened during the winter of 1884-5 and was conducted for 3 months. It had an average of 15 pupils. In the winter of 1885-6, it was again opened and conducted for a period of four months with an attendance of 20 pupils. It was also opened for 6 months during the winter of 1886-7 with an attendance of 30 pupils.

The school was during this time conducted under the management of Rev. Hugh McKay, a Presbyterian minister who has continued as Principal of the school up to the present time. The school during the above mentioned period did not receive any grant or assistance from the Deptt. But was conducted solely at the expense of the church authorities and by voluntary subscriptions.

It was conducted in a log building which the Church authority had from time to time been improving and making additions to. During 1884, the Church expended $800.00 in improvements and also a like amount of $80.00 during 1896.
The children attending the school came principally from the Crooked and Round Lake Reserves.

The Rev. M. McKay stated that as the old building was very much overcrowded, that the Church Authorities proposed building during the summer (1887) and he requested that a grant be given them by the Dept. towards helping them carry on the work. He stated in his letter that there were 60 children of school age on the Reserve who were willing to attend the school providing suitable accommodation was provided.

During the summer of 1887 extensive additions and improvements were made to the old building and when completed the new building consisted of a fine wooden structure with solid stone foundation and fine basement and heated with hot air. The whole cost of this work was $5000.00 the funds for which the Presbyterian Church supplied them but afforded ample accommodation for 60 pupils.

On the 18th May 1887 the Indian Comm. was notified that provision was made in the Supplementary Estimates for 1887-8 for a resident at the rate of $30.00 per annum for each of 50 pupils at the Round Lake.
History of School Control

Lake Boarding School

The new building was opened for the reception of boarders on the 12th December 1887. It then began to earn the per capita grant which it has continued to receive annually ever since that date.

During the year 1889 another building was erected in connection with the Boarding School. It was a frame building on a stone foundation well plastered inside. It is situated 50 yards from the main building. The first floor is used as a school room for all the scholars and the second floor is used as a dormitory for the boys and also rooms for the employees. This building was also erected at the expense of the Presbyterian Church authorities.

A new wing 24 x 18 ft was added to the main building during 1897 at a cost of $600. The expense was also borne by the Church authorities.

In a statement showing the assets and liabilities of the Round Lake Boarding School for the year ending Dec 31st 1897, the total value of the buildings is given as $7,600.00.

Dear Dr. MacKey;

Yours, and copy of letter from Ottawa, received. We generally keep two span of working horses in the stable, and a span of drivers, besides giving stable room to the ponys of the Indians who come to visit us. We have a few other horses growing up to take the place of those in use when they become disabled or disposed of. We had to shoot five of our best horses last spring for gliders. We were glad to have a little herd on the prairie to help fill the rank. The horses on the prairie trouble no one summer or winter as they feed out all winter as well as in summer. There are about 50 head of cattle at Round Lake at present, a number of which are cows which we need to supply the school with milk and butter. We make no butter to sell, and from the rest of the herd we have to take our beef for the school, and it is largely due to the abundance of fresh milk and butter, and fresh beef that our children are so healthy, having only one death in eight years, and not a sickly child in the school when we left on December 14th.

In regard to the condition in which our cattle are at present, I am not able to speak, but have always two men hired to look after the heavy work about the school.

We have always insisted on our boys and girls in the school doing two hours manual work each day in the school, as reported to the Indian Department, and any further work is optional and paid for at the rate of ten cents an hour for driving a team or any other work on the farm. Last summer I bargained with an Indian who lives 30 miles from the school, to take some of our cattle and take care of them. This he did with the approval of the agent. He had any amount of hay, and it is profitable to him feeding it to cattle and of help to the school. These cattle are kept by him summer and winter, and the boys in the school never see them. About 80 are there at present, and I had a letter from Mr. MacKay, Farm Instructor for those Indians saying the cattle are in fine condition.

24 years ago Mrs. Mortimer Clark sent me $40. for the use of the school. With this money I bought a cow and now there is a herd, profitable for the school. 30 years ago we bought a mare Boss, and she is the origin of the herd of horses and the school has had the use of them. Now I trust you understand how the school is situated in regard to these things.

In regard to the future of our school, I am in the dark. I know nothing of the changes required by the Church or the Government, of the conditions under which the school is to be conducted. We are leaving for the north west next week, and will spend a day in Winnipeg and talk things over with the F.M.C. there.
Mrs. McKay has been feeling better since coming east. She joins me in kind greetings.

I am,

Yours in the work,

(signed.) H. McKay.

P.S.; We would like if the Indian Department would mention one case in which our contract with the boys has been violated in the past 27 years.
