Then this is to be remembered that whilst other schools were coming to us with deficits and financial troubles, Dr. MacKay scarcely ever did. If his crop failed and he found things unsatisfactory, he would sell a number of bullocks and make it up. It was a sort of reserve deposit in the interests of the school. Then his practice has been for many years to require two hours labor daily from each boy, and afterwards to pay for any labor done. He encouraged these lads to deposit their money and keep a bank account, which he looked after for them. If any boy wanted extra, he could get it out of his own bank. Sometimes a portion of the land was assigned to a boy and he was encouraged to cultivate it paying for any labor given by the school or the use of machinery as an ordinary farmer would, and whatever profits belonging to himself. That was his method of developing independence.

Personally may I say that I regret exceedingly that anything should have arisen to mar the happiness Dr. MacKay has had in his work for so many years. If we ever had a consecrated man in the West, he is one of them. This I say rather as an expression of personal judgment; the matter to which his letter is a reply is official and must be dealt with in that way.

Yours sincerely,

REPORT

Indians breaking into School on Cowessess Reserve.
Complaint of Mr. R. Taylor (Indian Agent).

On Monday July 26th 1919 I proceeded with Mr. Taylor the Indian Agent in his auto to the Cowessess Reserve, North of Broadview to investigate the above complaint as per the request of the Officer Commanding Southern Sask. District. I obtained the following statements from the different witnesses.

Miss Orelia Dodge stated: "I am the Matron of the Round Lake Indian Boarding School. On the night of the 15th of June 1919, I was told by an Indian named Roy Berry that 3 or 4 of our Indians were going to break into the school that night. About 1 a.m., I was in a room upstairs near the big girls dormitory, and heard footsteps on the stairs. I had a flashlight in my hand and went through the small girls dormitory, into the big girls dormitory. A man was under the bed with a quilt over him, and the pupil (Harriet Francis) was under the bed. I said to the man 'William get me out of this', which he did with the quilt over him. I tried to pull the quilt off him but only had one hand, the other holding the flashlight, and could not get it. He went down the stairs and must have got out through the window of the old dining-room. I asked some of the girls who it was, but they said they were asleep. I convinced that it was Willie Gaddie an ex-pupil of the school, who had been hanging around the school for some time. These boys are nuisances, because we have to watch them closely. He must have had a key to open the dormitory door, but to get through the small girls' dormitory, he must have got through the transom window, where the floor is open. The door from the inside was easy to make his escape. I do not know what they break into the school for. These boys who have been hanging around the school are Henry and John Crow. The boys have got into trouble before, because I have seen their tracks, and I have warned them. They are all ex-pupils of the school. I did not see William Gaddie's face, but I could tell it was him by his build and walk. He did not hang around. These boys are all about 20 years of age."

Harriet Francis, stated as follows:

Indian pupil at the Round Lake Boarding School for 8 years of age and have attended the school for 8 years. One night about the middle of June 1919, I heard a man standing beside my bed in the big girls dormitory. It was dark in the room at the time and I could not see who it was. The night before William Gaddie and Robert Bear came into the building. I did not know these boys were coming to the school. William Gaddie bought Robert Bear's quilt from his bed. Robert Bear got into Bertha's bed. Miss Dodge caught William Gaddie, the others were under the beds, and while Miss Dodge was catching the others got away. All the boys were in the dormitory that night."
Different Indian boys are getting into the school (into the big girls dormitory) nearly every night when the school is on. I know one of these boys, his name is George Kenowakesquane. He goes to see Willie Iron Bear. I think the boys get in through the window of the old dining room, and up the stairs through the small girls dormitory. I think these boys come up to have sexual intercourse with us.

Victorine Kashane, stated as follows:- I am a pupil at the Round Lake Indian Boarding School, and have been there about four years. I think I am about 16 years old. The night that Miss Dodge (The Matron) caught Willie Gaddie in the big girls dormitory which was about the 5th of June 1919, Robert Bear was standing beside my bed, while Miss Dodge was away attending to Willie. Robert hit in the bathroom. The three boys I saw in the dormitory that night was Willie Gaddie, Robert Bear & Hoderick Henry all Indians and ex-pupils of the school. They came in through the small girls dormitory, and into the big girls room. Jean Watsonson & Tom Bear sleep in the next bed to mine. Robert Bear was lying on the floor between the two beds while Miss Dodge caught Willie. They get into the school about every other night. The last time they came in was two or three days before we had our holidays, which would make it about the 25th June. When the boys come up at nights they sit on the bed and talk to us. I don't know what else they come up for.

Owing to the fact that the holidays are on at the school, these were the only witnesses I could see, quite a number of the Indians are away to the Fair at Regina & taken the girls with them. The School opens up again August the 4th so will be able to get further information. From what I can see these girls are very fond of these boys, and it is hard to get such information from them. The Principal of the Round Lake School is Doctor McKay, and although he knows that this sort of thing has been going on, does not seem to adopt any measures to prevent it. In fact he suggested that the investigations be stopped. Anything that he knows about this is of course hearsay so did not get a statement from him. Mr. Crookson Asst. Principal of the School informed me that the boys mentioned are a nuisance by hanging around the School, and I'm sure they are around for no good purpose. He seems very anxious to stop this, but everything that he know is what the Matron(Miss Dodge) tells him.

Mr. Taylor,
Indian Agent.

Sir,-

I received yours containing report of Sergt. Richardson, re Round Lake Boarding School.

Miss Dodge in her statement speaks of these boys being expupils of the Round Lake School; two of these boys are ex-pupils of our School and two of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

I feel discouraged and disappointed because of these things occurring at our school - we have been under a great disadvantage since building operations began, parts of the old building being taken down; the boys and girls deprived of their day rooms and much discomfort and worry for members of the staff. I am much to blame in not insisting that different locks be put on the doors and fanlights above the doors and windows. I am sorry if any reflection is cast upon the Matron and those who assist her in the School, the work these ladies did during building operations was more than we could expect them to do, they were willing and I allowed, when I should have engaged an assistant to help in caring for the workmen.

I could get no direct evidence against these boys for house breaking but as soon as I suspected I secured the windows and fanlights by nailing numberlock, had padlocks put on the doors and other things that I thought would make the sleeping rooms secure. I endeavored to find evidence against William Gaddie next morning, I made inquiries among the pupils who slept there, all I could find out was some one was in the room but did not know who it was. I asked Harriet Francis but all she knew was that some one was in the room. I might have prosecuted William Gaddie for vagrancy - but he is one of my boys, and so much about him that I admire his musical talent, song, his free-hand drawing, his affable and seeming kind disposition, I feel surely there is some other way besides having him placed behind the bars. I took him into my house for ten days. I talked to him pointing out the consequences of following the indolent way leading to bad times. Mrs. McKay also talked with him and pleaded with him to be a man, to go to work and make a home for himself - not a vagrant that everyone would despise; he showed penitence and promised to try and live a better life, we prayed with him and for him, after going out I went after him and walked with him to the bridge, he said, "I know you are interested in me and would like to see me do well."

It is hard for me to give him up, I still have a hope that he will reform and become a useful citizen yet had I clear evidence that he was in the girls' room I would have him prosecuted but without clear evidence I did not want to make the case public.

This school and mission has been my life work, I did not accomplish what I expected to do. During the 35 years we have been here in charge of the school there has not been a single case of a boy going away and leaving the school in disgrace. I trust no one will think that we are indifferent in regard to the honor of the school, Mrs. McKay gave 8 of her best years to the school free of charge and we have spent a few thousand dollars from our own private account in trying to lift up the people among whom we have been sent to work.

We feel it much as we are retiring from the work and younger people taking charge that we should have to take with us this disappointment, however we have tried to do our duty.

Respectfully yours,

"H. McKay"

Dear Dr. Edmison:

The report of one of the Department's travelling nurses on the Round Lake Boarding School brings to my mind the desirability of reviewing with you the conditions under which the staff is working and the Indian children are being educated.

The Department allows at Round Lake a pupilage of 75, and it is felt that the building which the Presbyterian church erected can accommodate this number. However, the heating system has been so unsatisfactory that practically the whole of the top floor is not used in winter for living accommodation. The average attendance for the December quarter was 49, and they have been sleeping in crowded dormitories and studying in a classroom much too small.

To remedy these conditions, I believe it may be necessary to make a complete change in the heating plant. The building has been so cold that school could not be held on certain days this winter.

A more satisfactory heating arrangement would permit of the utilizing of the upper rooms for dormitory accommodation. In passing - I understand that more mattresses are needed for the boys' sleeping quarters. I will make enquiries concerning mattresses in the Department's stores in Regina.

If a half-day routine is not in use at the Round Lake Boarding School during the winter months, it will be necessary to either initiate it or fit up another classroom and employ a second teacher.

Last December the Department approved of a plan for better ventilation. It was suggested that the ventilation shaft for the dormitories be equipped with an aspirating coil. From a careful perusal of the nurse's report, I am inclined to believe that this change has not been made and, if made, is not an improvement.

The church authorities would be assisted in financing, if there was paid more careful attention to the matter of attendance. In the past, holidays of long duration have been allowed for trivial reasons, and the result is an unearned per capita income. The enrolment of pupils during

At the time of my visit to Round Lake this summer, I found the repairs going on rapidly.

The new Principal, Mr. Ross, did not impress me as being very efficient. His wife appears to be a clever woman, but is not particularly optimistic about the future.

Barn accommodation is bad. There is no ice house, root house or garage at the school. When the Government buys Round Lake, we might do well to purchase the property of the Rev. Dear Dr. Scott,

Re Round Lake Indian Boarding School

I have just received a letter from the Women's Missionary Society, part of which reads as follows:

"The Executive Board of the Women's Missionary Society respectfully ask that through you as Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of our Presbyterian Church the thanks of our Society be conveyed to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, for the prompt action they took in coming to our aid at the Round Lake Indian Boarding School, Sask., the buildings of which met with such disaster in June last during a cyclone which swept through that section of our country. Our Board was not in a position to expend any money in the large amount of repairs necessary and as it was an emergency condition requiring immediate re-building, the Government took charge expending in the neighborhood of twelve thousand dollars, ($12,000.)

"The School at Round Lake is the property of our Women's Missionary Society and the Executive Board feel we are not in a position to repay the Government for its outlay in the meantime, nor are we able to face the further repairs necessary for successful work or to give to our staff the larger equipment they should have. We are, therefore, prepared to offer to the Government the whole property at Round Lake School, clear title of same, on one condition, that the Government purchase the residence of the Rev. Hugh McKay, late principal of the School, from him as a residence for our Principal and also either purchase or rent the farm attached to it. In a school so large as this a residence for the Principal and his family is a necessity and makes for better service of the whole staff. We would suggest that a small Committee be appointed to value this property, consisting of Commissioner Graham, Judge Farrell and Mr. R. J. Ross, the Principal of the School.

"If this proposition is acceptable to the Government, it will relieve our Society of much anxiety over the large sums of money frequently required to be put into capital account for Indian buildings and will enable us the better to co-operate with you by concentrating our efforts on and releasing money for the educational and missionary side of the needs and for which we are responsible in common with other Churches to the Canadian Government."

This matter has not been before the Executive of our Board as yet but I am quite sure that the proposal made by the Executive of the Women's Board will have our hearty approval.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr. Scott,

I wrote you Oct. 12th enclosing a resolution passed by the Executive Board of the Women's Missionary Society. While this had not been considered by the Executive of our Board, I gave it as my opinion that it would be approved.

Since then we have secured the judgment of members of Presbytery. While they do not oppose the action taken by the Women's Society, they expressed the hope that the Government will be willing to vote a nominal figure to the Church to cover part of our outlay in the present plant.

I gather that some of the members of Presbytery have discovered that the Department is likely to take over the Roman Catholic plant at Lebret at a fair valuation, and they feel that if this is the policy being followed in regard to taking over buildings of other churches, there is no good reason why the Presbyterian Church should hand over this building without some compensation.

The suggestions submitted to our Sub-executive on Tuesday last were as follows:

1. That the Government purchase the property from the Church at a nominal figure of say $10,000 or $12,000.
2. That the Government purchase Dr. McKay's house for $5,000.
3. That the Government purchase or rent Dr. McKay's farm, the farm to be used in connection with the School.

After discussion these suggestions were generally approved by the Sub-executive.

Judge Farrell advises us that Dr. McKay's farm and house are worth about $17,000. Do you think the Department would be willing to expend this amount on the farm and house and at the same time give a nominal sum to reimburse the Church to the extent of about $10,000?

I may say quite frankly that I do not think the Women's Missionary Society or the Sub-executive for that matter, will go back on the resolution I sent Oct. 12th, but without doubt there is a feeling that if the Government has adopted the policy of purchasing...
plants that have been in the possession of the Church, exception should not be made in the case of Round Lake. As you have already expended so much on account of the cyclone, we cannot expect that you would vote a large sum. Some of the members of Presbytery suggested as much as $15,000; others thought that $10,000 or $12,000 would, under the circumstances, be a fair figure.

To our representatives in the West it seems very desirable that Dr. McKay's house should be purchased without delay. This would make it possible for Dr. McKay to leave the Reserve and Mr. Ross would in this way be left freer to carry on the work.

Yours sincerely,

JHE/EB

I wish to bring the following matter to the attention of the Department. Last Fall Mr. J. Woodward, who was our Foreman in charge of the construction work at the Round Lake Boarding School, had occasion to proceed to Stockholm for the purpose of transacting business at the Bank there, and purchasing some material necessary for the work underway at the school. While on his way to town, he met a man coming from the opposite direction driving a vehicle being hauled by a team of horses. A third horse was following behind hitched to the vehicle. On the day in question the road was wet and muddy, and had large wagon ruts in the centre, but although the wheels of Mr. Woodward's car did become stuck in the mud for a few seconds just before he passed the conveyance referred to, he was able to extricate them and clear the vehicle with about 18 inches to spare, but as he was passing the horse was following behind the animal flung out its hind-quarters, and was struck by the car, and injured so badly that it was necessary to destroy it. The outcome of the accident was that Mr. Woodward was summoned to appear before the local Magistrate, and was fined for occupying, at the time the accident occurred, more of the road allowance than he was entitled to. The fine and the costs of the case amounted to $40.10, and in addition Mr. Woodward, who was in Regina at the time the case was called, was put to the expense of travelling to Stockholm, the return fare.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a copy of a telegram from Judge Farrell, of Regina, relative to Dr. McKay's farm, near the Round Lake Indian Boarding School.

You may inform your Western representative and Dr. McKay that it is the Department's intention to purchase the farm and house for the sum of $17,000, provided that an independent and competent valuator assures us that the property is worth at least this figure, and provided, of course, that Dr. McKay can give us clear title.

Until such time as Parliament has allowed the item, could we not arrange to operate the farm for the benefit of the school, on a rental or share basis? My suggestion for an interim arrangement is that Dr. McKay vacate the property so that the school supply all the labour and seed and take for their own purposes two thirds of the crop harvested. However, I consider that, if a transfer is completed before the crop is taken off, the school authorities should reap the entire benefit of their farming activity on the land in question.

My Dear Doctor,

I received your letter of the 21st yesterday morning, on my return from Moosomin, re Round Lake and enclosing copy of Dr. Scott's letter to you of the 20th, which would have been under the then circumstances satisfactory to me, if he had not placed the maximum price for farm and land at $17,000 and I would have endeavored to have got authority by wire to make the suggested lease.

I don't know where Dr. Scott got the figures $17,000 from. They have never come from me, as in all my correspondence with you I have placed the price of the farm lands at $40 per acre, over and above the house. The sale and price of the house was long ago settled at $5000.00 when I on behalf of Dr. McKay accepted that figure for it, being the valuation put upon it at the Commissioner's office, and I so notified the doctor, the understanding being that the Board would take over at that figure, should the Government not do so, when buying the School plant as proposed. I have considered that matter settled. Then came on the proposition for buying the farm. I reported the number of acres, and the price asked namely $40.00 per acre, and I made it quite clear that this was in addition to the house which was a separate matter.

At the same interview that the valuation of house was fixed at $5000, Inspector Murison who is fairly well acquainted with the farm, said the land in the valley was very valuable, and expressed the opinion that $40 an acre would be a reasonable price but said it would depend on what amount of the land was hill-side land, which at the time I was unable to tell him.

The price as suggested was tentative only, subject to the whole matter being gone into with greater care later. Since then I have had more information on the matter, and find that the land in the valley is worth a good deal more than $40 an acre, so much so as to lead me to the conclusion that an average of $40 per acre would be very fair, and that the Government would also be making a good buy.

For instance, this week at Moosomin, I confirmed two sales (Sheriff sales,) each at $40 an acre for the whole ½ sec. in each case and there was evidence produced of neighboring land being sold for $45 per acre a few months ago. These lands were in the vicinity of Round Lake (that is a few miles away) but not in the valley.

You understand I am not just saying that $40.00 must be paid

MEMO FOR FILE:

May 4, 1923.

The ROUND LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL was built by the Presbyterian Church, on fractional N.W. quarter of section 14, Tp. 18, Rge. 3, West 2nd. some acres had been acquired by them.

As early as 1892 church authorities, in conjunction with this Department, endeavoured, through the Department of the Interior, to secure the S. § of fractional section 23 from the C.P.R. for school purposes. This effort was abortive for some years, and correspondence was initiated with a view to securing the N. § of 13 which was held in 1896 by the Canada North West Land Company. In the course of the latter negotiations, it was found that the S. § of 23 was available, and as this was the property which was originally requested, correspondence was continued until 1899 when, by P.C. 567, dated the first of May, the property was vested in the Department of Indian Affairs for the purposes of the Round Lake Indian Boarding School.

It is proposed, at this time, to purchase the church property at this institution and, further, to secure the house and farm of the Rev. Dr. McKay, for many years the Principal of the school. A description of Dr. McKay's property is not on file. It is my opinion that he has title to the land of Section 10, some additional acreage. Dr. Edmison, in a communication dated November 25th, last, states that Judge Farrell has advised me that Dr. McKay's farm and house are worth $17,000 and he further suggests that the Department reimburse the Church for their building equity and land which it stands to the extent of about $10,000. Judge Farrell, on behalf of Dr. McKay, in a communication to Dr. Edmison dated the 26th ultimo, states that the doctor will not likely accept $12,000 for his 406 acres. Rev. Peter Strang, also of Regina, advised Dr. Edmison, under cover of the 25th ultimo, that the 406 acres is worth $18,620.

In the Estimates, 1923-24, there is an item of $27,000 for the purpose of purchasing the church and the McKay property at the Round Lake School. It is proposed by Dr. Edmison, representing the Presbyterian Church, that $10,000 be given to the Church for their equity in the buildings and for their property - roughly acres in the N.W. quarter of Section 14. $17,000 was included as the purchase price for the McKay property.

It is proposed to negotiate with Dr. Edmison, of the Presbyterian Church, with a view to getting a proper description of the church and McKay properties and to arrange with him to get the titles in order. Dr. McKay, or his Regina representative (Judge Farrell or Rev. Strang) should state whether or not $17,000 will be accepted for the entire McKay property (house and 406 acres). The Minister of Justice should be approached for the purpose of securing the name of a competent valuator in Regina. This valuator should give us a valuation of both properties, and, provided the McKay property is worth at least $17,000 and the Church's property - less the Department's expenditures for plant - at least $10,000, this Department should make arrangements for the purchase. The Department of Justice will give us the name of their agent who will search the titles and who will act for us in the matter of the transfer.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have yours of May 5th to hand me purchase of the property at Round Lake. I have turned up my letter of Nov. 23rd in which I intimated that in the judgment of Judge Farrell, Dr. McKay's farm and house were worth about $17,000. I regret to say that this is an error on my part. I have looked over Judge Farrell's letters that came to the office at the time and I find that in all of them he states that that the farm, which consists of about 425 acres should be worth $40 per acre, so my letter should have read - "Judge Farrell advises us that Dr. McKay's farm is worth about $17,000".

However, as the situation stands it seems to me that the only course to pursue is to get a fair valuation from some expert who is disinterested. What the farm is worth, it is worth, and Dr. McKay has a right to the full value of his property, and I am sure the Department is not anxious to purchase it below the figure that he might receive from someone else. If he should sell his property to an outside party, the work at the school would be rendered very difficult. In fact I do not see how the work could be continued without the use of this farm. I think it should not be overlooked that we have had the free use of this land and house for many years. I understand the farm belongs to Mrs. McKay and was the gift of her father.

I am not very sure of Dr. McKay's address. He has been at Rochester, Minn. Word reached the city a few days ago that he had intended to return last week to Round Lake, but Mrs. McKay's condition would not permit him to take the journey so soon, so I judge he is still at Rochester.

My judgment is that you ought to get in touch with Commissioner Graham and Inspector Murison who represent the Government at Regina, and secure a just valuation of the property.

Yours sincerely,

JHE/EB

Dear Sir:

Re MacKay valuations, file # 108 - l - 1

I went out on Friday afternoon last from Broadview to inspect this property and the roads were so bad we did not get back until the following day at Noon.

I suppose the valuation you want from me is a valuation as to what the land will be worth as a farming proposition though I understand the land is being valued with an idea of taking it over in connection with the Indian School.

As a farming proposition it seems to me the house is rather expensive to be just suitable for that purpose but I presume it is intended to be used in connection with the school. I intimated in a former letter that I had a little hesitation about making valuations about the buildings by myself so I carefully went over sizes, type of construction etc. and discussed the matter fully with a competent builder.

The dwelling house is on the part held off the North East Quarter of section 14, 16, 3 w. 2nd M. as is also the stable and any other out buildings. The dwelling house I understand is ten years old but has been kept in good shape. It is well painted. I understand the walls are back plastered. Everything is well finished off though not at all ornate. There is a basement under all the main part of the house with cement floor and cement and stone cistern and there is a furnace in the basement. The main part of the house is 24 X 30 feet, though a jog of 6 X 10 feet is taken out of that as a veranda and there is a lean-to kitchen, one story high 6 X 24 feet. The walls are apparently 18 feet high.
Mr. Duncan Scott.

The stable is 16 X 26 feet with a lean-to to the side. There is also an ice house of no great value.

With the assistance I have been able to obtain I have placed the value of the buildings with allowance for depreciation at $500.00. I presume you are fully aware of the composition of the different quarter sections that are owned by Mr. and Mrs. MacKay. But in case you are not I may say that the 40 acres taken from the section 14 is made up of a parcel on the East side of the North East Quarter. On the North side it is apparently only about 150 yards wide or less. There is a surveyed road from the North West corner of that parcel running South West towards the River so that the strip widens out as you go South then the River is the South and South-West boundary of the parcel. It appears to contain about the amount mentioned, namely 40 acres. The North West Quarter of section 13 of course adjoins this to the East and the North of that is the parcel of the South West quarter of 13, lying North of the River said to contain 46 acres.

This land is mostly in the Qu'Appelle Valley a portion being in the side hills and all lying in one compact block worked together. There is approximately 120 or 130 acres under cultivation in the block and about some 20 acres more could be cultivated though it would require some clearing of brush. The cultivatable land seems uniformly good. There is a fair amount of weeds among the crop but not more than is usual or a little less than is usual in farms in this Country. I would value this parcel of land outside of the buildings thereon at $24.00 per acre. The amount being 246 acres and making a total of $5904.00.

The other parcel, that is the South West quarter of 24 in the same Township though adjoining the other land cannot be so conveniently worked with it. The greater part of which is on the high land on the North side of the Valley though a portion is taken up by the side hills of the Valley. There is none of this under cultivation. The land clear of the side hills is reasonably level and appears to be good soil. I would estimate that at least about 110 acres of it is capable of cultivation though it would require considerable clearing of brush. I would think $17.00 per acre would be reasonable valuation for it, making $1870.00 for this parcel. This would make a total for farm and building of $12824.
Mr. Duncan Scott,

I am advised that Mr. McKay has spent considerable money of his own on property now belonging to the Government and I am also advised that there was some suggestion that the Government should pay Mr. and Mrs. McKay the sum of $40.00 per acre for all the land. I take it however that what you want from me is an estimate of what I consider the land worth without taking into consideration any of these questions and I think that the amount that I have mention is the full value of the land.

I enclose herewith my account in connection with this matter. The driving expenses look high but I can assure you that the driver earned his money.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

On May 25th I asked for the name and address of a competent valuator of farm lands in the vicinity of Broadview, Sask., to whom we could give the commission of valuating certain property at the Round Lake Indian Residential School. You directed that Mr. Levi Thomson, of Wolesey, Sask., be employed, and I have to inform you that Mr. Thomson's valuation was forwarded under cover of the 17th ultimo.

The property in question is owned by Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Hugh McKay, who were for many years active in the administration of the Round Lake Indian Residential School. Their homestead land is situated contiguous to the institution and has been used for school purposes for many years. In addition, Dr. McKay has donated considerable capital and stock for the maintenance of the institution. He is now advanced in years and desires to turn over his holdings to the Crown, now that the school itself is purchased by the Department.

When the matter was first mooted, $27,000 was provided in the parliamentary appropriation for Indian education for the present fiscal year. $10,000 was suggested at that time as the purchase price for the school buildings and the 22 acres of land on which they are situated, owned by the Presbyterian Church. $17,000 was mentioned as a fair price for the home of Dr. McKay and the 406 acres to which he and his wife hold title. The Round Lake school would be somewhat embarrassed if the McKay farm were sold other than to the Department, as the only other land used by the institution is 257 acres, a fractional half section owned by the Department, in which lie the hills on the north side of the Qu'Appelle valley.

Mr. Levi Thomson places the value of the McKay home and 406 acres at $12,834. Rev. Dr. McKay, when informed of this figure, was disappointed and is supported by Judge Farrell and the Rev. R. Strong of Regina, and Dr. Edmison, General Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Presbyterian Church, with whom we were negotiating during the illness of the Rev. Dr. McKay. Judge Farrell and Mr. Strong believe that the land is worth $40 an acre, as a considerable portion of it is in the Qu'Appelle valley; Mr. Levi Thomson's valuation is roughly $21 per acre.

In view of these facts and the Department's wish that a fair offer be made to Mr. and Mrs. McKay, I should be pleased if you would give me the name and address of another gentleman in the Indian Head-Moosemin area, from whom we could receive a second appraisal.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General

Rev. J. H. Edmison, D.D.,

Dear Sir,

I received yours re the purchase of our property near Round Lake Mission. We are disappointed with Mr. Thompson's valuation of the property. The house he values at $4,200.00. The house is a two story 9 feet ceiling - 24 x 24. In upper flat 3 bedrooms with closets in each, a bath room and store room. On the ground floor, kitchen, with two pantries, dining room, parlor, living room. Full basement, cement floor and cistern and splendid furnace. There are two verandas and one balcony. The house was well built for comfort - double plastered and double boarded and paper between. No frost in any room the coldest winter, although we burn only wood. I try to purchase a house of the same value in a village or town and the price is $7,000.00.

We feel that Mr. Thompson valued the valley land too low. A few years ago a farm was sold in the valley for $90.00 an acre. It is well known that the land in the valley is the best in Saskatchewan being two weeks earlier in harvest than that up on the prairie and never troubled with frost, then look at the scenery as the farmer said when renting a pasture for his neighbor's cows. If I were young like the Government, I would not sell as land will rise in value from this out, but being not young and my wife likely an invalid for life makes a difference.

I plead not a moral obligation resting upon the government being in its employ and under its control, more or equal to that of the Church for 40 years, but a business transaction. We thought $17,000.00 was a fair price for the property, but if the Government think honestly that it is too much, then we shall take one or two thousand less.

I am glad to think that Mr. Ferrier was sympathetic, and we have not forgotten your sympathy with us in our troubles, when trying to please two Masters. I have written a long letter to Dr. Strang, also a letter to Mr. Mclean.

Mrs. McKay is not making the progress I would like to see since our return from Rochester. She joins me in very kind greetings and in the prayer that God may continue to bless you in the responsible position you hold. I am, Yours in the work of our Divine Master,

(sgd.) H. McKay

Sir,

Since writing to you the other day, we own property at the Round Lake mission. I find I made a mistake in my offer without consulting my wife who holds the deed of the property and without figuring out what the farm is worth.

During the current year the property is worth the following:

- 300 bushels of wheat @ 80¢ = $240.00
- 300 " oats @ 30¢ = $90.00
- 250 " barley @ 30¢ = $75.00
- 18 tons hay @ 6¢ = $108.00
- 12 bush flour @ 12¢ = $18.00
- 6 loads green oats shaves = $36.00

Pasture for 22 heads of cattle 6 months = $132.00

Proceeds by garden = $40.00

Total = $108.00

2 gal truck per day 365 days = $146.00

Rent for house & stable @ 20¢ = $240.00

We pay taxes = $123.90

Total = $1257.00

That part of the farm under cultivation is expected to yield ½ of the crop.

Now you pardon this trouble with all the mistakes you have pardoned during the many past years.

With regard to the Dept.'s said offer, I am instructed to say that as the offer is so much below its price asked by the Rev. Doctor & Mrs. McKay, and which has been so many times communicated to the Dept. by me through Mr. Edmiston, whom you speak, that it was not accepted by them, they do not wish to sell, and are very much attached to the place and the buildings, and your offer is no inducement to them to sell, and break these strong ties of the Dept. in order to pay a sum common sense would say is too low, and often impossible to judge, and what is more, the land and other improvements considered, aside to property, worth it will be due and properly considered, the question of sale, however valuable as quick sale of the work, and I may say, that it is more to us that he should be convinced an expert valuation of farm property.
I do not need to remind you, that the offer to sell did not come from the McKay's. It was not under pressure from us that they agreed to sell. This was a year ago, and if there had been reasonable promptness in the negotiations for the property, a deal could have been arranged. I think, however, that the matter has been allowed to drift for practically a year.

I notice that Mr. Thomson in his valuation puts the desirability down at $15,000, and that such is the Government present offer, notwithstanding that the price was fixed between the Presb. H. M. Brown and Mr. McKay, both of whom asked for $15,000, and at which price, should the property be sold, the whole school property of the mission would be acquired by the Church. The Church would be expected to accept $42,000 for the property, which if not paid for within a year, would be forfeited.

Further, I cannot allow to go unchallenged the statement in your letter, that "when the matter was first worked out, it was suggested that $17,000 was a fair price for the 456 acres of the farm, but the sale of the dwelling house was fixed with the Church authorities at $15,000." Now, the sale of the farm lands to the Government was suggested, and the price of the same (after consideration with a number of persons considered competent to judge of their value) was placed at $140 per acre, and added them to the house, which, for any better price, was subsequently changed over into land in the place asked.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of Sept. 10th in reply to mine of 31st ult.

At the time of my writing I did not know of yours of the 27th ult., at which you enclosed a copy. However, as I had had letter from the Doctor subsequent to its receipt, in consequence it made no difference as to the substance of any letter to you, in another matter, it indicates on the part of the Department an intention to pay more for the McKay's property. There what the Department might consider its real value. It is because of this place of the matter that I am now taking the trouble to write you this private and confidential letter, which I wish it to be taken as a personal matter of my own and not in any official way as the agent of Mr. McKay or in any way affecting their rights or interests, and if the Department are not prepared to fall in with the proposal I make in this letter, we leave it there, and the letter can be considered as if not written at all.

The state of affairs is this, that a year ago or a little more, I squatted up negotiations with the Doctor, as to his selling his dwelling house and garden to the Royal Victorian Church, in order that it might be used as a residence for the Principal as well as the Baptist congregation with the School as residence for the Principal as well as the Baptist congregation. The question was raised whether the School was not willing to take over the farm land, but he answered that he was not, and I did this because in my opinion, I thought, under the circumstances, that case running over a number of years, which I need not go into now, that such a course would be better for the Indians, better for the School and Mission, and better for your people.

The Doctor did not want to leave, and does not yet. This Indian School has been his life work (over two years) and his heart and soul is bound up in it, and the Indians. He is entirely attached to the place and its friends. To me, anyway means that he is lost. He is a Highland Scotch man, who has that peculiar mystical feeling about a place, its people, and his occupation that is hard for the ordinary Anglo-Saxon to understand. However, it is there, and the Doctor has a strong love of this peculiar habit, and so I said before he really does not want to leave, but hopes for to continue on and end his days among these Indians.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

Re: PURCHASE OF MCKAY PROPERTY AT ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The following is a brief resume of the action taken to acquire this property: On April 20th, last, the Department wrote Dr. Edmison, stating as follows: "You may inform your western representative and Dr. McKay that it is the Department's intention to purchase the farm and house for the sum of $17,500 provided that an independent and competent valuator assures us that the property is worth at least this figure, and provided that Dr. McKay can give clear title."

Dr. Edmison replied, enclosing a communication from Dr. Strang, the District Superintendent, together with a letter from Judge Farrell, in which it was stated that the price asked was $40 per acre for the land and $5,000 for the house, and that they valued the entire property $20,000.

On May 25th the Minister was requested to furnish the name of a competent valuator, to whom the commission of appraisal of the land could be given, and on June 21st he gave the name of Mr. Levi Thompson, of Wolseley, Sask., to make the valuation.

Mr. Thompson, in a letter of July 17th, submitted a report on the valuation made by him of this property, as follows:

| House | $4,200 |
|-------|--------|
| 40 acres, N.E. & Sec. 14 | $24 per acre | $960 |
| 206 " | Frac. W. & Sec. 13 | $24 per acre | $4,944 |
| 160 " | S.W. & Sec. 24 | $17 per acre | $2,720 |

$11,824

By letter of August 2nd, Dr. McKay was informed of the valuation placed on the property by Mr. Thompson, and, in his reply of the 10th of the same month, he took exception to the valuation of Mr. Thompson, and stated "that the property is worth $18,000 so that being a fair price to the Government, and if the Government think it too much then we shall be content with one or two thousand less."

On August 22nd the Department wrote Dr. McKay, making him an offer of $18,000 for the house and farm. This allowed $4,800 for the house and roughly $26 per acre for both hillside and valley land.

Dr. McKay has turned the matter over to Judge Farrell Regina, who is now acting on his behalf. In letter of August 31st the Judge states that the offer of $18,000 is no inducement to sell. He stated: "If the Department is prepared to add $2,000 to the offer for the land and besides bring the price for the house up to $8,000, making the total for the property $17,000, I am prepared to urge upon Dr. and Mrs. McKay to accept and vacate the premises at once."
The foregoing is briefly as far as the negotiations have gone. The letters dealing with the matter are turned out on the file herewith.

Re Round Lake:

I duly recd. yours of the 8th inst., and sent at once a copy of it to the Revd. Dr. McKay. His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that in the carrying on of the work of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, in the Crooked Lake Indian agency in the province of Saskatchewan, its welfare has been dependent largely upon the fact that adjoining the school site proper there are four hundred and six acres of land, with residence and out-buildings thereon, owned personally by the former Principal, the Rev. Hugh McKay, who while employed in that capacity has permitted the property to be used for the purposes of the institution.

Upon the resignation of this incumbent of the position, there has arisen the necessity for securing the continued use of his holdings by purchase, as the Department would be seriously embarrassed in its conduct of the institution should the property be otherwise acquired and its use be thereby lost to the institution.

The Department obtained an independent valuation amounting to $12,824.00, but the owner and his legal representative protested against this valuation as being too low and represented that $21,246.00 would be fair. In view of the fact that this property was used as a productive part of the school lands for many years, the Department decided to offer $15,000.00, which, under the circumstances, it considers is a fair and equitable settlement for the property. The Department of Indian Affairs has...........
has been advised of the acceptance of its offer and has requested the Department of Justice of Canada to search title with a view to a transfer of the property to the Department of Indian Affairs.

The undersigned would recommend that the Department of Indian Affairs be authorized, upon receipt of favourable advice from the Department of Justice, to purchase the above mentioned property for the sum of $15,000.00, the money being available from the Vote for Indian Education No. 279.

Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

The following is a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by his Excellency the Governor General on the 13th November 1923.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 25th October, 1923, from the Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that in the carrying on of the work of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, in the Crooked Lake Indian agency in the province of Saskatchewan, its welfare has been dependent largely upon the fact that adjoining the school site proper there are four hundred and six acres of land, with residence and outbuildings thereon, owned personally by the former Principal, the Rev. Hugh McKay, who while employed in that capacity has permitted the property to be used for the purposes of the institution.

Upon the resignation of this incumbent of the position, there has arisen the necessity for securing the continued use of his holdings by purchase, as the Department would be seriously embarrassed in its conduct of the institution should the property be otherwise acquired and its use be thereby lost to the institution.

The Department obtained an independent valuation amounting to $12,824.00, but the owner and his legal representative protested against this valuation.

The Honourable
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
tion as being too low and represented that $21,240.00 would be fair. In view of the fact that this property was used as a productive part of the school lands for many years, the Department decided to offer $15,000.00, which, under the circumstances, it considers is a fair and equitable settlement for the property. The Department of Indian Affairs has been advised of the acceptance of its offer and has requested the Department of Justice of Canada to search title with a view to a transfer of the property to the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Minister recommends that the Department of Indian Affairs be authorized, upon receipt of favourable advice from the Department of Justice, to purchase the above mentioned property for the sum of $15,000.00, the money being available from the Vote for Indian Education No. 279.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have your letter of the 26th instant. The transfers and cheques, as I understand Mr. Procter yesterday, have arrived, as I am glad to say, and I hope there will be no further hitch, although why the cheques as you state should be made payable jointly to the vendor and the agents of the Dept. of Justice I fail to see either the necessity or object. The first thing I know the said agents will refuse to sign them as they have no interest in them whatever and their objection would be well taken. I have had all sorts of trouble and worry over this matter and from my viewpoint a little care would have avoided it all. Last week the Doctor was kicking over the traces, because everything was hung up and he was practically stranded at the Mission, when he had expected he would be away a couple of weeks before. I had told him on the 16th of Oct. to commence to get ready to leave and on receipt of yours of 23rd Oct. again wrote him matter settled and to get ready to leave in another week if he could, as I expected instructions for transfer would issue at once, and a day would be all that was necessary to search title and prepare transfers. Haste was absolutely necessary, as the weather might become any moment so inclement that Mrs. McKay could not travel. The Doctor had followed my instructions, when I had to write him of the delay of Dept. of Justice in forwarding instructions to Mundell and Co., and then the transfers had to be sent back to Ottawa for inspection, there was trouble just as I expected there would be. The Doctor was all packed up ready to go, the weather had changed considerable for the worst. I finally over the telephone got him to agree to stay on a little longer on the strength that transfer with ck's would soon be up. I also wrote Mundell and Co. again, advising them and asking them to telephone the Dr. as soon as transfer arrived back, and arrange as he was coming out at Whitewood, to have them signed there on his way out, or at Moosomin, even if the ck. had not
yet arrived at Balcarres. Mr. Proctor was good enough to telephone me on Monday (Nov. 27th.) that cks. and transfers had arrived and he had arranged that Dr. and Mrs. McKay would be in Moosomin on Wednesday (28th) and for me to be there if possible. (You see I have two districts to look after and 500 miles to travel each week for Chambers alone in these two districts, Moosomin and Melville, besides a court elsewhere each week, and it keeps me hustling to get thro my work each week.) I got to Moosomin yesterday, but it was necessary I should leave again on the afternoon train and I had a very large amount of chamber work to dispose of. This did not give me as much time as I would have liked for the Round Lake matter. I found there was a hitch over the taxes. These had not been paid for this year, and no instructions had been given Mundell and Co., that these were to be paid by Government and they were of course insisting that they be paid, and I understood that because of this the McKay's had not arrived and signed. I got that settled as I had your letter of the 23rd. of Oct. with me. However that should not have occurred as proper instructions should have been forwarded to Mundell and Co. when they were engaged. Mr. Proctor said he would see to the signing of transfer and closing deal at once. I trust he has succeeded in doing so, without any new hitch. I am XING waiting impatiently to hear that this has been done, the cks. handed over and this confounded thing off my hands.

Yours sincerely,

A. Farrell.

Ottawa, Feb. 18, 1924.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

It is my wish that the Round Lake Indian Residential School be transferred to the Department before March 31st, which is the end of our fiscal year. The understanding between your Mission Board and this Department was that $10,000 should be given for the Church's equity in the property. It is my duty to refer to the recent fire which destroyed the classroom. As this building was an important part of the property and, I trust, was covered by insurance, I feel that I should now suggest $6,000 as the consideration. I have discussed this matter with Mr. Commissioner Graham who considers this a fair adjustment.

I shall be pleased to have your reply at your earliest convenience, so that the transfer can be completed during the coming month.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

This Department proposes purchasing the Round Lake Indian Residential School from the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada. This institution is situate north of Broadview, Sask., and the property consists of land, residential school, stable and other outbuildings. The parcel of land in question is described as follows:

"All of Legal Subdivision 15 not covered by the waters of Round Lake and the West Half of Legal Subdivision 16 in Sec. 14-18-3, W. 2. 22 acres more or less except 1.50 acres for Roadway, Plan No. X-1398."

I am enclosing an abstract of the title in this connection.

It is desired that you have your Agent at Moosomin, Sask., search the title to the property and submit a draft transfer to "His Majesty as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs," with his report to you in this matter. A purchase price of $6,000 has been agreed upon by this Department and the vendors.

The address of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada is 434 Confederation Life Building, Toronto, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Two years ago a cyclone tore the roof from the Round Lake Indian Residential School, north of Broadview, Saskatchewan. This institution is owned by the Presbyterian Church and has accommodation for 75 pupils. The Department came to the rescue at the time of the disaster and under the supervision of Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, the roof was replaced and other damage repaired. Over $10,000 has been spent from the Appropriations for Indian Education during the past two fiscal years.

I did not request a lien on the property, as the Church authorities have offered us their equity in land and buildings for the very reasonable sum of $8,000, and in the appropriation for the present fiscal year there was an item of $27,000 for the purchase of the school and adjoining Malay farm. The purchase of the Malay farm for $15,000 has now been completed and I propose, with your concurrence, to have the Round Lake Indian Residential School property, consisting of 22 acres of land, the institution itself, barns and other outbuildings, transferred to the Crown. The consideration will be $8,000 and the transaction will be undertaken by the Department of Justice.

This Department owns 736 acres, which is used by the school, and $10,000 has been spent on the buildings. To purchase the Church's equity for $8,000 would be of distinct advantage to the Crown.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

Re: Your file B.5241 Purchase of Round Lake Residential School

Referring to yours of the 10th of March, 1924, we have attended and searched title in this matter, but we think there must be an error in the description of the land as contained in your letter. Title to all of legal sub-division 16, not covered by the waters of Round Lake, and the West half of the West half of Legal sub-division 16 in Section 14 in Township 18 Range 3 West of the Second stands in the name of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, excepting 1.50 acres taken for a roadway, but in your letter you refer to the West half of legal sub-division 16. So far as we can determine from an inspection of the various titles, the east half of the west half of legal sub-division 16 appears to be in Round Lake, and we think that the reference in your letter to the West half of Legal sub-division 16 should read the West half of the West half of legal sub-division 16.

Please advise us as to this as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, addressed to the Superintendent of Indian Education, with reference to the transfer of certain property to the Crown. In reply I wish to inform you that this Department has acquired the first three parcels, and is acquiring the fourth parcel, of land mentioned hereunder:

1. All that portion of the N.E. ¼ of Sec. 14, T. 18, R. 3, W. 2nd, containing 62 acres more or less, excepting thereout firstly:- L. S. 15 and the W. ½ of the W. ½ of L. S. 15 of the said section.

2. All that portion of the W. ½ of Sec. 13, T. 18, R. 3, W. 2nd, containing 206 acres more or less.

3. The S.W. ¼ of Sec. 24, T. 18, R. 3, W. 2nd, containing 150 acres more or less.

4. L. S. 15 and the W. ½ of the W. ½ of L. S. 15, Sec. 14, T. 18, R. 3, W. 2nd, 22 acres more or less.

The first parcel was purchased from Rev. H. McKay; the second and third parcels, from Selina McKay (Mrs. Rev. H. McKay); and the fourth parcel is being purchased from the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

The title to these parcels will be in "His Majesty the King in right of Canada as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs." The properties will, of course, be exempt in future from municipal taxation.
